Match the following.List I (Tech Users)(a) Digital Collaborators(b) Ambivalent Networkers(c) Media Movers(d) Roving NodesList II (Description)(i) Have a wide range of online and mobile habits, and they are bound to find or create an information nugget.(ii) Express worries about connectivity and some find that mobile devices are intrusive.(iii) Active managers of their social and work lives using their mobile device.(iv) Enthusiastic about how ICTs help them connect and confident in how to manage digital devices and information.Choose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(iv) d-(i)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)

Even with newer generation smart phones, the Web experience can be very different for users given smaller screen sizes, longer downloads, and the lack of some software capabilities (such as Adobe Flash Player on iPhones). Marketers would be wise to design simple, clear, and “clean” sites, paying even greater attention than usual to user experience and navigation.

Although a growing population segment uses mobile phones for everything from entertainment to banking, different people have different attitudes and experiences with mobile technology.

 

Given below are the segmentation of Tech users:

(i) Digital Collaborators: With the most tech assets, Digital Collaborators use them to work with and share their creations with others. They are enthusiastic about how ICTs help them connect with others and confident in how to manage digital devices and information.

(ii) Ambivalent Networkers: They have folded mobile devices into how they run their social lives, whether through texting or social networking tools online. They also rely on ICTs for entertainment. But they also express worries about connectivity; some find that mobile devices are intrusive and many think it is good to take a break from online use.

(iii) Media Movers: They have a wide range of online and mobile habits, and they are bound to find or create an information nugget, such as a digital photo, and pass it on. These social exchanges are central to this group’s use of ICTs. Cyberspace, as a path to personal productivity or an outlet for creativity, is less important.

(iv) Roving Nodes: They are active managers of their social and work lives using their mobile device. They get the most out of basic applications with their assets such as e-mail or texting and find them great for arranging the logistics of their lives and enhancing personal productivity.

(v) Mobile Newbies: This group rates low on tech assets, but its members really like their cell phones. Mobile Newbies, many of whom acquired a cell in the past year, like how the device helps them be more available to others. They would be hard pressed to give up the cell phone.

Question 45
Which among the following is/are the main platforms of social media?
  • A.Online communities and forums
  • B.Blogs
  • C.Social networks
  • D.All of the Above
Correct Answer: All of the Above

Social media are a means for consumers to share text, images, audio, and video information with each other and with companies and vice versa. It allows marketers to establish a public voice (in the form of word of mouth) and presence on the Web and reinforce other communication activities. Because of their day-to-day immediacy, they can also encourage companies to stay innovative and relevant.

There are 3 main platforms for social media: (i) online communities and forums, (ii) bloggers, and (iii) social networks (like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube).

 

(i) Online communities and forums come in all shapes and sizes. Many are created by consumers or groups of consumers with no commercial interests or company affiliations. Others are sponsored by companies whose members communicate with the company and with each other through postings, instant messaging, and chat discussions about special interests related to the company’s products and brands. These online communities and forums can be a valuable resource for companies and provide multiple functions by both collecting and conveying key information.

 

(ii) Blogs, regularly updated online journals or diaries, have become an important outlet for word of mouth. There are millions in existence and they vary widely, some personal for close friends and families, others designed to reach and influence a vast audience. One obvious appeal of blogs is bringing together people with common interests.

 

(iii) Social networks have become an important force in both business-to-consumer and business-to-business marketing. Marketers are still learning how to best tap into social networks and their huge, well-defined audiences. Given networks’ non-commercial nature—users are generally there looking to connect with others—attracting attention and persuading are more challenging. Also, given that users generate their own content, ads may find themselves appearing beside inappropriate or even offensive content.

Question 46
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Viral marketing generates excitement, creates publicity, and conveys new relevant brand-related information through unexpected or even outrageous means.Statement II:Buzz marketing encourages consumers to pass along company-developed products and services or audio, video, or written information to others online.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect

Consumers use word of mouth to talk about dozens of brands each day, from media and entertainment products such as movies, TV shows, and publications to food products, travel services, and retail stores. Some marketers highlight 2 particular forms of word of mouth: buzz and viral marketing.

Buzz marketing generates excitement, creates publicity, and conveys new relevant brand-related information through unexpected or even outrageous means. Viral marketing is another form of word of mouth, or “word of mouse,” that encourages consumers to pass along company-developed products and services or audio, video, or written information to others online.

 

Buzz and viral marketing both try to create a splash in the marketplace to showcase a brand and its noteworthy features. Some believe these influences are driven more by the rules of entertainment than the rules of selling but ultimately the success of any viral or buzz campaign depends on the willingness of consumers to talk to other consumers.

Question 47
Advertising that appears to be look in the form and function like other natural content surrounding it on web or social media platform is called
  • A.Native Advertising
  • B.Madison & Wine
  • C.Natural Advertising
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Native Advertising

Native Advertising: Advertising or other brand-produced online content that looks in form and function like other natural content surrounding it on web or social media platform.

Madison & Wine: A term that has come to represent the merging of advertising and entertainment in an effort to break through the clutter and create new avenues for reaching customers with more engaging messages.

Question 48
Creating, inspiring, and sharing brand messages and conversations with and among consumers across a fluid mix of paid, owned, earned, and shared channels is called
  • A.Shared Marketing
  • B.Content Marketing
  • C.Inspirational Marketing
  • D.Brand Marketing
Correct Answer: Content Marketing

Content Marketing: Creating, inspiring, and sharing brand messages and conversations with and among consumers across a fluid mix of paid, owned, earned, and shared channels. These channel include media that are both traditional and new, and controlled and not controlled.

Question 49
Given below are two statements - one islabeledas Assertion and the other islabeledas Reason.Assertion “A”:Although the strongest influence on consumer choice remains “recommended by relative/friend,” an increasingly important decision factor is “recommendations from consumers.”Reason “R”:With increasing mistrust of some companies and their advertising, online customer ratings and reviews are playing an important role for Internet retailers.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

Although the strongest influence on consumer choice remains “recommended by relative/friend,” an increasingly important decision factor is “recommendations from consumers.” With increasing mistrust of some companies and their advertising, online customer ratings and reviews are playing an important role for Internet retailers such as Amazon.com and Flipkart.

 

Online retailers often add their own recommendations, “If you like that black purse, you’ll love this red blouse.” Specialized software tools help online retailers facilitate customer “discovery” or unplanned purchases.

At the same time, online companies need to make sure their attempts to create relationships with customers don’t backfire, as when customers are bombarded by computer-generated recommendations that consistently miss the mark. E-tailors need to recognize the limitations of online personalization at the time that they try harder to find technology and processes that really work.

Question 50
Match the following.List I (Electronic Marketplace Types)(a)Catalogsites(b) Vertical market(c) Pure play auction sites(d) Spot MarketList II (Example)(i) Pepperfry.com(ii) Indiamart.com(iii) eBay.com(iv) Bankbazaar.comCodes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)

Companies that purchase over the Internet are utilizing electronic marketplaces in several forms:

(i) Catalog sites - Companies can order thousands of items through electronic catalogs distributed by e-procurement software, such as C1india.com. Companies can also use websites like Indiamart.com to order items online.

(ii) Vertical markets - Companies buying industrial products such as plastics, steel, or chemicals or services such as logistics or media can go to specialized Web sites (called e-hubs). Plastics.com allows plastics buyers to search the best prices among thousands of plastics sellers. For customers, websites like Lenskart.com and Pepperfry.com are available.

(iii) “Pure Play” auction sites: Apex Auction (India) is an auction side for used machinery and industrial equipment. For non-industrial purchase, websites like ebay.com are available.

(iv) Spot (or exchange) markets - On spot electronic markets, prices change by the minute. Mtlexs.com is India's first online B2B marketplace dedicated to buyers and sellers of Non-ferrous metals. For stocks and shares websites like Motilaloswal.com, BankBazaar.com, Moneycontrol.com are available.

(v) Private exchanges - Hewlett-Packard, IBM, and Walmart operate private exchanges to link with specially invited groups of suppliers and partners over the Web.

(vi) Barter markets - In barter markets, participants offer to trade goods or services.

(vii) Buying alliances - Several companies buying the same goods can join together to form purchasing consortia to gain deeper discounts on volume purchases. For example, TopSource is an alliance of firms in the retail and wholesale food-related businesses.

 

Online business buying offers several advantages: It shaves transaction costs for both buyers and suppliers, reduces time between order and delivery, consolidates purchasing systems, and forges more direct relationships between partners and buyers. On the downside, it may help to erode supplier–buyer loyalty and create potential security problems.

Question 51
What are the two types of e-hub for e-procurement around which website are organized?
  • A.vertical hubs and functional hubs
  • B.vertical hubs and horizontal hubs
  • C.operational hubs and functional hubs
  • D.operational hubs and horizontal hubs
Correct Answer: vertical hubs and functional hubs

E-procurement - Web sites are organized around 2 types of e-hubs: vertical hubs centered on industries (plastics, steel, chemicals, paper) and functional hubs (logistics, media buying, advertising, energy management).

In addition to using these Web sites, companies can use e-procurement in other ways:

(i) Set up direct extranet links to major suppliers - A company can set up a direct e-procurement account at Dell or Office Depot, for instance, and its employees can make their purchases this way.

(ii) Form buying alliances - A number of major retailers and manufacturers in USA, such as Best Buy, Carrefour, Walmart, and others formed data-sharing alliance called 1SYNC.

(iii) Set up company buying sites - General Electric formed the Trading Process Network (TPN), where it posts requests for proposals (RFPs), negotiates terms, and places orders.

Moving into e-procurement means more than acquiring software; it requires changing purchasing strategy and structure.

Question 52
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Digital marketing tools are used to engage customers anywhere and at any time via their digital devices.Statement II:The key is to blend the new digital approaches with traditional marketing to create a smoothly integrated marketing strategy and mix.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Digital and Social Media Marketing: The use of digital marketing tools - such as websites, social media, mobile apps and ads, online video, email, and blogs - to engage customers anywhere and at any time via their digital devices.

 

Although these new marketing methods have huge potential, most marketers are still learning how to use them effectively. The key is to blend the new digital approaches with traditional marketing to create a smoothly integrated marketing strategy and mix.

Therefore, both statements are correct.

Question 53
Which of the following is a form of online word of mouth that encourages consumers to pass along company developed products and services or any other information online? (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.Viral Marketing
  • B.Microsites
  • C.Interstitials
  • D.Contextual placements
Correct Answer: Viral Marketing

The correct answer is (A) Viral Marketing.

 

Viral Marketing refers to a form of online word of mouth where consumers themselves actively share company-developed products, services, or information across various online platforms. This marketing technique aims to create a self-sustaining chain reaction of user-generated content sharing, often leveraging social media networks, email, and other online channels. Viral marketing involves creating content that is so compelling, entertaining, or valuable that consumers are motivated to share it with their friends, family, and social networks. As more people share the content, it can quickly spread like a "virus," reaching a large and diverse audience. Examples of viral marketing include videos, memes, articles, or other content that captures people's attention and prompts them to share it.

 

Explanation to other options

 

(i) Microsites: Microsites are small, dedicated websites or web pages that are created to focus on specific content, products, or campaigns. While microsites can play a role in digital marketing, they are not inherently focused on encouraging consumers to share content or information online.

 

(ii) Interstitials: Interstitials are web advertisements that appear between two content pages, typically when a user clicks a link. They are not directly related to encouraging consumers to share company-developed products or services.

 

(iii) Contextual Placements: Contextual placements refer to the practice of placing advertisements in online environments that are relevant to the content of the ad. While this can improve ad targeting and engagement, it does not inherently encourage consumers to actively share content or information.

Question 54
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II: (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)List – Ia. Rich-media adsb. Pop-upsc. InterstitialsList – IIi. Online ads that appear between screen changes on a website, especially while a new screen is loading.ii. Display ads that use eye-catching techniques such as float, fly, and snapback.iii. Ads that users can block through the use of applications developed by web browser providers.Codes:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii
  • B.a-ii, b-i, c-iii
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-i
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-ii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iii, c-i

The correct matching is:

 

a. Rich-media ads- ii. Display ads that use eye-catching techniques such as float, fly, and snapback.

b. Pop-ups- iii. Ads that users can block through the use of applications developed by web browser providers.

c. Interstitials- i. Online ads that appear between screen changes on a website, especially while a new screen is loading.

 

Rich-media ads (Item a) are matched with Display ads that use eye-catching techniques (Description ii). Rich-media ads are interactive and engaging advertisements that can include elements like videos, animations, and interactive features, making them visually appealing and attention-grabbing.

 

Pop-ups (Item b) are matched with Ads that users can block (Description iii). Pop-up ads are ads that appear in separate windows or tabs and often disrupt the user's browsing experience. Many users choose to block pop-up ads using browser extensions or settings.

 

Interstitials (Item c) are matched with Online ads that appear between screen changes on a website (Description i). Interstitial ads are full-screen ads that appear while a user is navigating from one page or screen to another on a website or app. They are designed to capture the user's attention during natural transitions.

Question 55
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion A, and the other labelled as Reason R. State the correct answer from code given below. (UGC NET Management Jun 2011)Assertion A:Pure-click companies can be search engines, Internet service providers, commerce sites, transaction sites, content sites and enabler sites.Reason R:Pure-click companies are those companies that have launched a website without any previous existence as a firm.Code:
  • A.A is correct, but R is wrong.
  • B.Both A and R are correct.
  • C.A is wrong, but R is correct.
  • D.Both A and R are wrong.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct.

The correct answer is (B) Both A and R are correct.

 

Assertion A: Pure-click companies can be search engines, Internet service providers, commerce sites, transaction sites, content sites, and enabler sites.

This assertion is correct. "Pure-click companies" refer to businesses that primarily or exclusively operate online without a physical presence. These companies leverage the internet as their primary platform for business activities. The mentioned examples - search engines, Internet service providers, e-commerce sites, transaction sites, content sites, and enabler sites - all fall into the category of pure-click companies because they conduct their core operations online. For instance, companies like Google, Amazon, and Netflix are pure-click companies because their business models heavily rely on their online presence.

 

Reason R: Pure-click companies are those companies that have launched a website without any previous existence as a firm.

This reason is also correct. Pure-click companies are often startups or businesses that originate on the internet. They don't have an existing offline presence or history before launching their online operations. They are born online and build their brand, products, and services primarily through their website or online platforms.

Quiz Attempt #119618

Total Questions: 138
Question 1
Which of the following are the reasons for manufacturers and retailers to brand their offerings?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)(a) Helps to gauge the level of product quality(b) Enables premium pricing(c) Contributes to corporates identify programmers(d) Inform about the source of a product(e) Develops customer loyalty.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b, c and e only
  • B.b, c and e only
  • C.a, b, c and d only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: b, c and e only

The correct answer is option B – b, c and e only.

 

Branding is a crucial strategy for both manufacturers and retailers to distinguish their offerings in the market and create a unique identity for their products or services. The reasons for branding offerings include:

 

(b) Enables premium pricing: Strong brands can command premium pricing due to the perceived value and quality associated with them. Consumers are often willing to pay more for products from recognized and trusted brands.

 

(c) Contributes to corporate identity programs: Brands are an essential part of a company's corporate identity. They represent the company's values, mission, and image, contributing to the overall identity of the organization.

 

(e) Develops customer loyalty: Brands build a relationship with consumers and create a sense of loyalty. Customers who have positive experiences with a brand are more likely to become loyal and repeat buyers.

Question 2
Arrange the following statements corresponding to different levels of Brand Dynamics Pyramid in a sequence starting with the base of the pyramid:(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)a. Belief that the brand delivers acceptable product performance and is on the consumer’s short-list.b. Rational and emotional attachments to the brand to the exclusion of most other brands.c. Active familiarity with the brand based on post-trial, saliency or knowledge of the brand promise.d. Relevance of brand to consumer's needs in the right price range or in the consideration set.e. Belief that the brand has an emotional or rational advantage over other brands in the category.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.c, d, a, e, b
  • B.d, c, a, e, b
  • C.d, c, a, b, e
  • D.c, d, a, b, e
Correct Answer: c, d, a, e, b

Option A is the correct answer.

 

Correct sequence is option A - c, d, a, e, b.

 

The Brand Dynamics Pyramid represents the stages of consumer engagement and attachment with a brand, progressing from basic levels to deeper levels of connection.

 

Here’s the correct sequence of the statements:

 

c. Active familiarity with the brand based on post-trial, saliency or knowledge of the brand promise.

This is the foundation of the pyramid. Consumers are familiar with the brand and its promises after trying it or encountering it.

 

d. Relevance of brand to consumer's needs in the right price range or in the consideration set.

Once consumers are familiar with the brand, they assess its relevance to their needs and consider it as a potential option.

 

a. Belief that the brand delivers acceptable product performance and is on the consumer’s short-list.

As consumers find the brand relevant, they start to believe that the brand can meet their expectations and make it to their short-list of choices.

 

e. Belief that the brand has an emotional or rational advantage over other brands in the category.

At this stage, consumers attribute specific advantages or benefits to the brand, differentiating it from other options. This is where emotional or rational attachments begin to form.

 

b. Rational and emotional attachments to the brand to the exclusion of most other brands.

Finally, consumers develop strong emotional and rational attachments to the brand, often choosing it over other brands and forming a deep and loyal connection.

Question 3
Given below are two statements:(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)Statement I:If there are differences in consumers’responses, brand-name, product is essentially acommodityand competition will probably be based on price.Statement II:Brand equity is reflected in perceptions, performance and behaviour related to all aspects of the marketing of a brand.In light ofthe above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectbut Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectbut Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I isincorrectbut Statement II is correct

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Statement I: It is incorrect. It is actually the opposite. If consumers perceive little to no differences in responses to different brands, it suggests that the brands are essentially considered commodities, and competition is likely to be driven by price rather than other differentiating factors.

 

Statement II: This statement is correct. Brand equity refers to the value a brand adds to a product beyond its functional benefits. It is reflected in the perceptions, performance, and behaviors associated with the brand's marketing. Strong brand equity can lead to customer loyalty, premium pricing, and competitive advantages.

Question 4
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as Assertion (A)and the other is labelled as Reason (R).(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)Assertion (A):A brand is an important corporate resource.Reason (R):A brand embodiesall ofthe characteristics of a company's product in the mind of the consumer.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both (A) and (R) are correct and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)
  • B.Both (A) and (R) are correct but (R) is not the correct explanation of (A)
  • C.(A) is correct but (R) is not correct
  • D.(A) is not correct but (R) is correct
Correct Answer: Both (A) and (R) are correct and (R) is the correct explanation of (A)

Assertion (A) states that a brand is an important corporate resource. This assertion is correct because a brand is indeed an asset for a company. A strong brand can differentiate a company's products or services from competitors, build customer loyalty, and contribute to long-term success.

 

Reason (R) states that a brand embodies all the characteristics of a company's product in the mind of the consumer. This reason is also correct because a brand represents not only the physical attributes of a product but also its intangible qualities, such as reputation, values, and associations. In the mind of consumers, a brand serves as a symbol that encompasses all these characteristics, influencing their perceptions and preferences.

 

Both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are correct, and Reason (R) provides a valid explanation for Assertion (A). The reason explains why a brand is considered an important corporate resource—it is because it encapsulates the essence of a company's products or services in the minds of consumers.

Question 5
Under Brand Sponsorship, store brands are also known as which other names from the following?(UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. National BrandsB. Generic BrandsC. Private BrandsD. Distributor BrandsE. Manufacturers BrandsChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.B, C and D only
  • B.A, B and C only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, D and E only
Correct Answer: B, C and D only

The correct answer is (A) B, C, and D only

Store brands are also known as:

B. Generic Brands: These are often unbranded or carry simple packaging and are typically lower-priced.

C. Private Brands: These are brands owned and sold by a specific retailer or distributor.

D. Distributor Brands: These are brands owned by distributors or retailers and sold exclusively through their channels.

These terms describe brands that are not owned by manufacturers but by retailers or distributors. "National Brands" and "Manufacturers Brands" are typically associated with brands owned by manufacturers and widely distributed.

Question 6
If a company uses its company name for its entire range of products offered, then it is called (UGC NET Management Dec 2010)
  • A.Private branding
  • B.Corporate branding
  • C.Product-line branding
  • D.Specific product branding
Correct Answer: Corporate branding

If a company uses its company name for its entire range of products offered, it is called (B) Corporate branding.

 

Corporate branding, also known as umbrella branding or family branding, is a strategy where a company uses its corporate or company name to brand all its products and services. In this approach, the company's brand name becomes synonymous with the organization itself, and it is applied uniformly across all product lines and offerings.

 

A well-known example of corporate branding is Coca-Cola. Coca-Cola is the corporate brand, and it is used for a wide range of products like Coca-Cola Classic, Diet Coke, Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, and more. The corporate brand name, Coca-Cola, is prominent on all these products.

Question 7
Which of the following statement is true? (UGC NET Management Jun 2013)
  • A.A brand name is a part of brand which can be vocalised.
  • B.A brand is usually composed of a name and mark of a product.
  • C.Brand means a name, term and symbol or a mix thereof used to identify the product of a firm and to distinguish.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The true statement among the options is (D) All of the above.

 

All the statements (A, B, and C) are accurate when discussing the concept of a brand:

(A) A brand name is a part of a brand that can be vocalized.

(B) A brand is usually composed of a name and mark of a product.

(C) Brand means a name, term, and symbol, or a mix thereof, used to identify the product of a firm and to distinguish.

Question 8
The total combined customer lifetime values of all of the company's customers is known as: (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)
  • A.Customer equity
  • B.Customer-perceived value
  • C.Customer Lifetime value
  • D.Customer share
Correct Answer: Customer equity

The correct answer is Option A - Customer equity.

 

Customer Equity refers to the total value of all the relationships a company has with its customers. It takes into account the total customer lifetime value (CLV) of all customers, as well as other factors such as brand loyalty, customer satisfaction, and customer retention.

 

Customer-Perceived Value refers to the perceived benefits that customers receive from a product or service in relation to its cost.

 

Customer Lifetime Value (CLV) is the total value that a customer is expected to bring to a company over the course of their relationship with the company.

 

Customer share refers to the percentage of a customer's purchases in a particular product category that are made from a particular company.

Question 9
Match the following.List I (Brand concept)a. Brand imageb. Brand feelingsc. Brand positiond. Brand salienceList II (Meaning)i. Customer's emotional response and reactions with respect to Brandii. Image of the Brand in the customer's mind, meeting their social/psychological needsiii. How customers think of the Brand under various purchase situationsiv. Deliberate attempt on the part of marketer of the Brand to create a unique position in the mind of customerChoose the correct answer from the options given below: [UGC NET Management June 2021]Codes
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-i, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-i, d-iv
  • D.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Brand salience is how often and how easily customers think of the brand under various purchase or consumption situations.

 

Brand performance is how well the product or service meets customers’ functional needs.

 

Brand imagery describes the extrinsic properties of the product or service, including the ways in which the brand attempts to meet customers’ psychological or social needs.

 

Brand judgments focus on customers’ own personal opinions and evaluations.

 

Brand feelings are customers’ emotional responses and reactions with respect to the brand.

 

Brand resonance describes the relationship customers have with the brand and the extent to which they feel they’re “in sync” with it.

Question 10
A brand extension strategy refers to-(UGC NET Management Jun 2020)
  • A.Extending existing brand names to forms of an existing product strategy.
  • B.Extending an existing brand name to a new or modified product in a new category.
  • C.Coming out with different brands in a given product category.
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: Extending an existing brand name to a new or modified product in a new category.

A brand extension strategy refers to extending as existing brand name to a new or modified product in a new category.

 

Brand extension is a strategy where an existing brand is used to introduce a new product or product category. There are two main types of brand extensions: line extension and category extension.

  • Line Extension: In a line extension, the parent brand introduces new variations or offerings within its existing product category. These variations could include different flavors, forms, colors, ingredients, or package sizes. For example, Dannon yogurt introducing various flavors and types like "Fruit on the Bottom" or "All Natural Flavors."
  • Category Extension: It involves using the parent brand's recognition to enter a different product category. For instance, Honda uses its brand name to cover a range of products, including automobiles, motorcycles, snowblowers, and marine engines.

 

A sub brand is a new brand that is created by combining a new brand element with an existing brand. Sub brands often represent specific product lines or offerings, such as "Toyota Camry" or "American Express Blue." The parent brand is the established brand that gives rise to a brand extension or sub brand. It is the original brand that serves as the foundation for new offerings. When a parent brand is associated with multiple products through brand extensions, it can also be referred to as a master brand. This emphasizes its role in overseeing various product offerings.

Question 11
A set of all brands and brand lines a particular firm offers for sale in a particular category or market segment is known as
  • A.Brand Folder
  • B.Brand File
  • C.Brand Portfolio
  • D.Brand Tree
Correct Answer: Brand Portfolio

Brand Portfolio is the set of all brands and brand lines a particular firm offers for sale in a particular category or market segment.

 

A brand can only be stretched so far, and all the segments the firm would like to target may not view the same brand equally favorably. Marketers often need multiple brands in order to pursue these multiple segments.

Some other reasons for introducing multiple brands in a category include:

(i) Increasing shelf presence and retailer dependence in the store.

(ii) Attracting consumers seeking variety who may otherwise have switched to another brand.

(iii) Increasing internal competition within the firm.

(iv) Yielding economies of scale in advertising, sales, merchandising, and physical distribution.

 

The hallmark of an optimal brand portfolio is the ability of each brand in it to maximize equity in combination with all the other brands in it. Marketers carefully monitor brand portfolios over time to identify weak brands and kill unprofitable ones. If they can increase profits by dropping brands, a portfolio is too big; if they can increase profits by adding brands, it’s not big enough.

Question 12
Which of the following is NOT a role played by a brand as part of a portfolio?(i) Flankers(ii) Cash-cow(iii) Low-end entry level(iv) High-end prestige(v) Watch dogsChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (v)
  • B.(ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • D.(i), (iii), (iv), (v)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (iv)

Brand Portfolio is the set of all brands and brand lines a particular firm offers for sale in a particular category or market segment.

 

Brands can also play a number of specific roles as part of a portfolio. They are:

 

(a) FLANKERS: Flanker or “fighter” brands are positioned with respect to competitors’ brands so that more important (and more profitable) flagship brands can retain their desired positioning. Marketers walk a fine line in designing fighter brands, which must be neither so attractive that they take sales away from their higher-priced comparison brands nor designed so cheaply that they reflect poorly on them.

 

(b) CASH COWS: Some brands may be kept around despite dwindling sales because they manage to maintain their profitability with virtually no marketing support. Companies can effectively “milk” these “cash cow” brands by capitalizing on their reservoir of brand equity.

 

(c) LOW-END ENTRY LEVEL: The role of a relatively low-priced brand in the portfolio often may be to attract customers to the brand franchise. Retailers like to feature these “traffic builders” because they are able to “trade up” customers to a higher-priced brand.

 

(d) HIGH-END PRESTIGE: The role of a relatively high-priced brand often is to add prestige and credibility to the entire portfolio.

Question 13
Which of the following is/are the advantage of brand extension?
  • A.Brand extension improves odds of new-product success
  • B.Brand extension provides feedback benefits
  • C.Both A and B
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Both A and B

Brand Extension is when a firm uses an established brand to introduce a new product. For example, Emami, which makes personal care products has extended into edible oils.

 

2 main advantages of brand extensions are:

(a) Improved Odds of New-Product Success: Consumers form expectations about a new product based on what they know about the parent brand and the extent to which they feel this information is relevant. For example, when Sony introduced a new personal computer tailored for multimedia applications, the Vaio, consumers may have felt comfortable with its anticipated performance because of their experience with and knowledge of other Sony products. By setting up positive expectations, extensions reduce risk, reduce launch costs, avoid the difficulty and expense of coming up with a new name and allow for packaging and labeling efficiencies.

 

(b) Positive Feedback Effects: Brand extensions can also provide feedback benefits. They can help to clarify the meaning of a brand and its core values or improve consumer loyalty to the company behind the extension. Line extensions can renew interest and liking for the brand and benefit the parent brand by expanding market coverage. For example, the goal of Kimberly-Clark’s Kleenex unit is to have facial tissue in every room of the home. This philosophy has led to a wide variety of Kleenex facial tissues and packaging, including scented and ultra-soft, boxes with drawings of dinosaurs and dogs for children’s rooms; colorful and stylish designs to match home décor etc.

 

In Line Extension, the parent brand covers a new product within a product category it currently serves, such as with new flavors, forms, colors, ingredients, and package sizes. For example, Kurkure has introduced several types of flavours through the years.

Question 14
_________ occurs when consumers no longer associate a brand with a specific or highly similar set of products and start thinking less of the brand.
  • A.Brand melting
  • B.Brand dilution
  • C.Brand dissociation
  • D.Brand concoction
Correct Answer: Brand dilution

Brand dilution occurs when consumers no longer associate a brand with a specific or highly similar set of products and start thinking less of the brand. It is one of the disadvantage of Brand Extension.

 

On the downside of it, Line Extensions may cause the brand name to be less strongly identified with any one product. Al Ries and Jack Trout call this the “line-extension trap.” For example, by linking its brand to mainstream food products such as mashed potatoes, powdered milk, soups, and beverages, Cadbury ran the risk of losing its more specific meaning as a chocolate and candy brand.

Question 15
Statement I: If a firm launches extensions consumers deem inappropriate; they may question the integrity of the brand.Statement II: If sales of a brand extension are high and meet targets, the revenue may be coming from consumers switching to the extension from existing parent-brand offerings.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Both the statements are true

Brand Extension is when a firm uses an established brand to introduce a new product. For example, Emami, which makes personal care products has extended into edible oils.

 

Disadvantages of Brand Extensions:

(i) If a firm launches extensions consumers deem inappropriate; they may question the integrity of the brand or become confused or even frustrated asking themselves about which version of the product is the “right one” for them Retailers reject many new products and brands because they don’t have the shelf or display space for them.

 

(ii) The worst possible scenario is for an extension not only to fail, but to harm the parent brand in the process. Fortunately, such events are rare. “Marketing failures,” in which too few consumers were attracted to a brand, are typically much less damaging than “product failures,” in which the brand fundamentally fails to live up to its promise. Even then, product failures dilute brand equity only when the extension is seen as very similar to the parent brand.

 

(iii) Even if sales of a brand extension are high and meet targets, the revenue may be coming from consumers switching to the extension from existing parent-brand offerings—in effect cannibalizing the parent brand. For example, Intrabrand shifts in sales may not necessarily be undesirable if they are a form of preemptive cannibalization. In other words, consumers might have switched to a competing brand instead of the line extension if the extension had not been introduced.

 

(iv) One easily overlooked disadvantage of brand extensions is that the firm forgoes the chance to create a new brand with its own unique image and equity.

Question 16
Statement I:Successful brand extensions occur when there is a perception of fit between the parent brand and the extension product.Statement II:An unsuccessful extension prevents a firm from “backtracking” and introducing a more similar extension.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Statement I is true and Statement II is false

Marketers must judge each potential brand extension by how effectively it leverages existing brand equity from the parent brand, as well as how effectively, in turn, it contributes to the parent brand’s equity.

 

Research Insights on Brand Extensions:

(i) Successful brand extensions occur when the parent brand is seen as having favorable associations and there is a perception of fit between the parent brand and the extension product.

(ii) There are many bases of fit: product-related attributes and benefits, as well as non-product-related attributes and benefits related to common usage situations or user types.

(iii) Depending on consumer knowledge of the categories, perceptions of fit may be based on technical or manufacturing commonalties or more surface considerations.

(iv) A brand that is seen as prototypical of a product category can be difficult to extend outside the category.

(v) Consumers may transfer associations that are positive in the original product class but become negative in the extension context.

(vi) It can be difficult to extend into a product class that is seen as easy to make.

(vii) A successful extension cannot only contribute to the parent brand image but also enable a brand to be extended even farther

(viii) An unsuccessful extension hurts the parent brand only when there is a strong basis of fit between the two.

(ix) An unsuccessful extension does not prevent a firm from “backtracking” and introducing a more similar extension.

(x) Vertical extensions can be difficult and often require sub-branding strategies.

(xi) The most effective advertising strategy for an extension emphasizes information about the extension (rather than reminders about the parent brand).

Question 17
Statement I: The customer equity perspective focuses on bottom-line financial value.Statement II: Brand equity tends to emphasize strategic issues in managing brands and creating and leveraging brand awareness and image with customers.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Both the statements are true

The Brand equity and Customer equity perspectives certainly share many common themes. Both emphasize the importance of customer loyalty and the notion that we create value by having as many customers as possible pay as high a price as possible.

 

In practice, however, the 2 perspectives emphasize different things. There are generally fewer financial considerations put into play with brand equity than with customer equity. Nevertheless, both brand equity and customer equity matter. There are no brands without customers and no customers without brands.

 

Customer Equity: The sum of lifetime values of all customers.

Brand equity refers to a value premium that a company generates from a product with a recognizable name when compared to a generic equivalent. Companies can create brand equity for their products by making them memorable, easily recognizable, and superior in quality and reliability.

Question 18
The ____________ defines which other brands a brand competes with and therefore which brands should be the focus of competitive analysis.
  • A.Positioning frame of reference
  • B.Competitor frame of reference
  • C.Competitive frame of reference
  • D.Product frame of reference
Correct Answer: Competitor frame of reference

The Competitive Frame of Reference defines which other brands a brand competes with and therefore which brands should be the focus of competitive analysis. Decisions about the competitive frame of reference are closely linked to target market decisions. Deciding to target a certain type of consumer can define the nature of competition, because certain firms have decided to target that segment in the past (or plan to do so in the future), or because consumers in that segment may already look to certain products or brands in their purchase decisions.

Question 19
When defining a competitive frame of reference for brand positioning, first determine Category Membership, which means(a) the products or sets of products with which a brand competes(b) the products or sets of products with which function as close substitutes(c) the products or sets of products with which function as close supplementsChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (c)
  • C.(a) and (c)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: (a) and (b)

The Competitive Frame of Reference defines which other brands a brand competes with and therefore which brands should be the focus of competitive analysis.

 

A good starting point in defining a competitive frame of reference for brand positioning is to determine category membership—the products or sets of products with which a brand competes and which function as close substitutes. It would seem a simple task for a company to identify its competitors. For example, PepsiCo knows Parle’s Kinley is a major bottled-water competitor for its Aquafina brand; Nestle knows Sunfeast Yippe is a major competitor for its Maggie NoodlesBut the range of a company’s actual and potential competitors, however, can be much broader than the obvious. For a brand with explicit growth intentions to enter new markets, a broader or maybe even more aspirational competitive frame may be necessary to reflect possible future competitors. In addition, a company is more likely to be hurt by emerging competitors or new technologies than by current competitors. Thus, firms should identify their competitive frame in the most advantageous way possible.

Question 20
Statement I:Points-of-parity (POPs) are attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand.Statement II:Points-of-difference (PODs) are attribute or benefit associations that are not necessarily unique to the brand but may in fact be shared with other brands.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both statements are true
  • D.Both statements are false
Correct Answer: Both statements are false

Once marketers have fixed the competitive frame of reference for positioning by defining the customer target market and the nature of the competition, they can define the appropriate points-of-difference and points-of-parity associations.

 

(a) Points-of-difference (PODs) are attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate, and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competitive brand. For example, for Apple iPhone users, its design, ease-of-use and bold attitude are some points-of differences.

 

(b) Points-of-parity (POPs) are attribute or benefit associations that are not necessarily unique to the brand but may in fact be shared with other brands. For example, people believe that VIVO, OPPO and XIOMI phones offer almost same features at similar prices.

Therefore, both Statements are false.

Question 21
To keep the brand live, contemporary, and relevant, marketer uses a variety of measures such as (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)(a) Brand extension(b) Brand rejuvenation(c) Brand relaunch(d) Brand proliferationWhich of the following is correct?
  • A.(a) and (b) only
  • B.(a) and (c) only
  • C.(a), (b) and (c) only
  • D.(a), (b) and (c) and (d) only
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c) only

To keep the brand live, contemporary and relevant, marketer uses a variety of measures such as:

 

1. Brand Extension: When a brand looks stale after a lapse of time, strategies must be developed to keep it alive. Keeping the brand alive is possible through brand extension. It is a marketing strategy in which a firm marketing a product with a well-developed image uses the same brand name in a different product category. There are 3 types of brand extensions:

(i) Extension to other items in the same product line,

(ii) Extension to items in a related product line, and

(iii) Extension to items in an unrelated product line.

 

2. Brand Rejuvenation: Breathing new life by adding value attributes to products is called brand rejuvenation. Ex: Words such as New, Super, Special, Premium add value to existing brand as the attributes are improved and overall appeal will be enhanced. Brand rejuvenation helps in revival of a brand, which may be showing signs of decline.

 

3. Brand Relaunch: Many a time in marketing, there comes a stage in the life of a brand when it needs to be re-worked and relaunched to take it to a different level. This happens not only for brands, which may not be doing well but also for brands that are doing well but would like to do better. There are 3 ways in which brands can be relaunched: (i) Repositioning (ii) Change in channel and distribution strategy and (iii) Revamping of whole marketing mix.

 

4. Brand Proliferation: Brand proliferation is opposite of brand extension. In this case, more items/products are brought in with new brand names. In other words, the firm has several brands in the same product or product category. It means that the list of independent brands increase. Hence, brand proliferation cannot be considered as a measure to revive a brand as it is about adding new brands rather reviving an existing brand.

Question 22
Which of the following criteria determine whether a brand association can truly function as a Point-of-Differences?(a) Desirability(b) Categorization(c) Differentiability(d) Deliverability(e) CompetitivenessChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(a), (b) and (c)
  • B.(a), (c) and (d)
  • C.(a), (b) and (e)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: (a), (c) and (d)

Points-of-Difference (PODs) are attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate, and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competitive brand.

 

3 criteria determine whether a brand association can truly function as a point-of-difference— desirability, deliverability, and differentiability. Some key considerations follow:

(i) Desirable to consumer: Consumers must see the brand association as personally relevant to them.

(ii) Deliverable by the company: The company must have the internal resources and commitment to feasibly and profitably create and maintain the brand association in the minds of consumers. The product design and marketing offering must support the desired association.

(iii) Differentiating from competitors: Consumers must see the brand association as distinctive and superior to relevant competitors.

Question 23
The basic forms of Point-of-Parity are(a) Desirability(b) Categorization(c) Differentiability(d) Deliverability(e) CompetitivenessChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (e)
  • C.(c) and (d)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: (b) and (e)

Points-of-parity (POPs) are attribute or benefit associations that are not necessarily unique to the brand but may in fact be shared with other brands

 

2 basic forms of point-of-parity are:

(a) Category points-of-parity are attributes or benefits that consumers view as essential to a legitimate and credible offering within a certain product or service category. In other words, they represent necessary—but not sufficient—conditions for brand choice. Category points-of-parity may change over time due to technological advances, legal developments, or consumer trends. For example, consumers might not consider a travel agency truly a travel agency unless it is able to make air and hotel reservations, provide advice about leisure packages, and offer various ticket payment and delivery options.

 

(b) Competitive points-of-parity are associations designed to overcome perceived weaknesses of the brand. A competitive point-of-parity may be required to either negate competitors’ perceived points-of-difference or negate a perceived vulnerability of the brand as a result of its own points-of-difference.

Question 24
A short phrase that captures the irrefutable essence or spirit of the brand positioning is referred to as:
  • A.Brand melody
  • B.Brand psalm
  • C.Brand mantra
  • D.Brand verse
Correct Answer: Brand mantra

A Brand Mantra is an articulation of the heart and soul of the brand and is closely related to other branding concepts like “brand essence” and “core brand promise.” They are short, phrases that captures the irrefutable essence or spirit of the brand positioning. Their purpose is to ensure that all employees within the organization and all external marketing partners understand what the brand is most fundamentally to represent with consumers so they can adjust their actions accordingly. For example, TATA Tea’s brand mantra is “Jaago Rey!” (Arise! Awake!) and Surf Excel’s brand mantra is “Daag Acche Hai” (Stains are good).

 

Brand mantras are powerful devices. They can provide guidance about what products to introduce under the brand, what ad campaigns to run, and where and how to sell the brand. Brand mantras must economically communicate what the brand is and what it is not.

Question 25
Statement I:Brand slogans are designed with internal purposes in mind.Statement II:Brand mantra is an external translation that attempts to creatively engage consumers.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both Statements are true
  • D.Both Statements are false
Correct Answer: Both Statements are false

Brand mantras are designed with internal purposes in mind. A brand slogan is an external translation that attempts to creatively engage consumers. For instance, Nike’s internal mantra was “authentic athletic performance,” its external slogan was “Just Do It.”

 

A Brand Mantra is an articulation of the heart and soul of the brand and is closely related to other branding concepts like “brand essence” and “core brand promise.”

Therefore, both Statements are false.

Question 26
Which of the following is NOT a key criterion for a brand mantra?
  • A.Brand mantra should communicate the uniqueness of the brand
  • B.Brand mantra should be memorable
  • C.Brand mantra should be challenging to competitors
  • D.Brand mantra should inspire the employees
Correct Answer: Brand mantra should be challenging to competitors

A Brand Mantra is an articulation of the heart and soul of the brand and is closely related to other branding concepts like “brand essence” and “core brand promise.”

 

The 3 key criteria for a brand mantra:

(a) Communicate: A good brand mantra should define the category (or categories) of business for the brand and set the brand boundaries. It should also clarify what is unique about the brand.

(b) Simplify: An effective brand mantra should be memorable. For that, it should be short, crisp, and vivid in meaning.

(c) Inspire: Ideally, the brand mantra should also stake out ground that is personally meaningful and relevant to as many employees as possible.

 

Brand mantras typically are designed to capture the brand’s points-of-difference, that is, what is unique about the brand. Other aspects of the brand positioning—especially the brand’s points-of-parity—may also be important and may need to be reinforced in other ways.

Question 27
Brand positioning ______ provides content and context to improve everyone’s understanding of the positioning of a brand in the organization.
  • A.Aim
  • B.Bull’s eye
  • C.Mark
  • D.Objective
Correct Answer: Bull’s eye

A brand positioning bull’s-eye provides content and context to improve everyone’s understanding of the positioning of a brand in the organization. Following is a hypothetical Starbucks example:

 

(i) In the inner two circles is the heart of the bull’s-eye—key points-of-parity and points-of-difference, as well as the brand mantra.

(ii) In the next circle are the substantiators or Reasons-to-Believe (RTB)—attributes or benefits that provide factual or demonstrable support for the points-of-parity and points-of-difference.

(iii)The outer circle contains two other useful branding concepts: (a) the brand values, personality, or character—intangible associations that help to establish the tone for the words and actions for the brand; and (b) executional properties and visual identity—more tangible components of the brand that affect how it is seen.

 

3 boxes outside the bull’s-eye provide useful context and interpretation:

(i) To the left, two boxes highlight some of the input to the positioning analysis: One includes the consumer target and a key insight about consumer attitudes or behavior that significantly influenced the actual positioning.

(ii) The other box provides competitive information about the key consumer need the brand is attempting to satisfy and some competitive products or brands that need suggests.

(iii) To the right of the bull’s-eye, one box offers a “big picture” view of the output—the ideal consumer takeaway that would result if the brand positioning efforts were successful.

Question 28
Assertion “A”:The typical approach to positioning is to inform consumers of a brand’s membership before stating its Point-of-difference.Reason “R”:Consumers need to know what a product is and what function it serves before deciding whether it is superior to the brands against which it competes.
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct
  • C.A is correct, but R is incorrect.
  • D.A is incorrect, but R is correct.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The typical approach to positioning is to inform consumers of a brand’s membership before stating its point-of-difference. Presumably, consumers need to know what a product is and what function it serves before deciding whether it is superior to the brands against which it competes. For new products, initial advertising often concentrates on creating brand awareness, and subsequent advertising attempts to create the brand image.

Hence, both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Points-of-difference (PODs) are attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate, and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competitive brand.

Question 29
Which of the following is NOT a way to convey a brand’s category membership?
  • A.Announcing category benefits
  • B.Positioning brand as inexpensive
  • C.Comparing to exemplars
  • D.Relying on the product descriptor
Correct Answer: Positioning brand as inexpensive

There are 3 main ways to convey a brand’s category membership:

(i) Announcing category benefits: To reassure consumers that a brand will deliver on the fundamental reason for using a category, marketers frequently use benefits to announce category membership. Thus, industrial tools might claim to have durability, and antacids might announce their efficacy. For example, a brownie mix might attain membership in the baked desserts category by claiming the benefit of great taste and support this claim by including high-quality ingredients (performance) or by showing users delighting in its consumption (imagery).

 

(ii) Comparing to exemplars: Well-known, noteworthy brands in a category can also help a brand specify its category membership. When Tommy Hilfiger was an unknown, advertising announced his membership as a great U.S. designer by associating him with Calvin Klein, and other big brands, who were recognized members of that category.

 

(iii) Relying on the product descriptor: The product descriptor that follows the brand name is often a concise means of conveying category origin. Ford Motor Co. invested more than $1 billion on a radical new 2004 model called the X-Trainer, which combined the attributes of an SUV, a minivan, and a station wagon. To communicate its unique position—and to avoid association with its Explorer model—the vehicle, eventually called Freestyle, was designated a “sports wagon”.

Question 30
Many of the attributes or benefits of a product that make up the points-of-parity and points-of-difference are
  • A.Negatively correlated
  • B.Positively correlated
  • C.Unrelated
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Negatively correlated

One common difficulty in creating a strong, competitive brand positioning is that many of the attributes or benefits that make up the points-of-parity and points-of-difference are negatively correlated. For example, it might be difficult to position a brand as “inexpensive” and at the same time assert that it is “of the highest quality.”

 

Some examples of negatively correlated attributes and benefits are:

(i) Low price vs. High Quality

(ii) Powerful vs. Safe

(iii) Nutritious vs. Good Tasting

(iv) Taste vs. Low Calories

(v) Varied vs. Simple

Question 31
Statement I:Consumers typically want to maximize both of the negatively correlated attributes or benefits of a product or service.Statement II:Much of the art and science of marketing is dealing with trade-offs, and positioning is no different.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Both the statements are true

Consumers typically want to maximize both of the negatively correlated attributes or benefits of a product or service. Much of the art and science of marketing is dealing with trade-offs, and positioning is no different. The best approach clearly is to develop a product or service that performs well on both dimensions. For example, Royal Philips launched its “Sense and Simplicity” advertising campaign for its Philips brand of electronics, using print, online, and television advertising.

 

Some marketers have adopted other approaches to address attribute or benefit trade-offs: launching two different marketing campaigns, each one devoted to a different brand attribute or benefit; linking themselves to any kind of entity (person, place, or thing) that possesses the right kind of equity as a means to establish an attribute or benefit as a POP or POD; and even attempting to convince consumers that the negative relationship between attributes and benefits, if they consider it differently, is in fact positive.

Question 32
Match List I with List II (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)List I (Branding Strategy)(a) Line Extension(b) Brand Extension(c) Multi Brands(d) Co-brandingList II (Meaning)(i) New product category and existing brand name(ii) Existing product category and existing brand name(iii) Existing product category and new brand name(iv) Putting two established brand names of different companies on the same productChoose the correct option from the given below:
  • A.(a)-(i), (b)-(ii), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)
  • C.(a)-(iii), (b)-(i), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
  • D.(a)-(i), (b)-(iii), (c)-(ii), (d)-(iv)
Correct Answer: (a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv)

The correct matching of List I (Branding Strategy) with List II (Meaning) is as follows:

 

(a) Line Extension - (ii) Existing product category and existing brand name

(b) Brand Extension - (i) New product category and existing brand name

(c) Multi Brands - (iii) Existing product category and new brand name

(d) Co-branding - (iv) Putting two established brand names of different companies on the same product

 

So, the correct option is (B) (a)-(ii), (b)-(i), (c)-(iii), (d)-(iv).

Question 33
A ________ advantage is one that a company can use as a springboard to new advantages. For a brand to be effectively positioned, however, customers must see any competitive advantage asa_______ advantage.
  • A.customer; leverageable
  • B.competitive; customer
  • C.leverageable; customer
  • D.leverageable; profitability
Correct Answer: leverageable; customer

A leverageable advantage is one that a company can use as a springboard to new advantages, much as Microsoft has leveraged its operating system to Microsoft Office and then to networking applications. In general, a company that hopes to endure must be in the business of continuously inventing new advantages.

 

For a brand to be effectively positioned, however, customers must see any competitive advantage as a customer advantage. For example, if a company claims its product works faster than its competitors, it won’t be a customer advantage if customers don’t value speed. Companies must also focus on building customer advantages. Then they will deliver high customer value and satisfaction, which leads to high repeat purchases and ultimately to high company profitability.

 

Competitive advantage is a company’s ability to perform in one or more ways that competitors cannot or will not match. Michael Porter urged companies to build a sustainable competitive advantage.23 But few competitive advantages are sustainable. At best, they may be leverageable.

Question 34
According to Brand Consultant MarcGobé,Emotional Brands share 3 specific traits. Identify them among the following:(a) Strong people-focused corporate culture(b) Larger market share(c) Distinctive communication style and philosophy(d) Compelling emotional hookChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(a), (b) and (c)
  • B.(a), (c) and (d)
  • C.(a), (b) and (d)
  • D.(b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (c) and (d)

Many marketing experts believe a Brand Positioning should have both rational and emotional components. In other words, a good positioning should contain Points-of-difference and Points-of-parity that appeal both to the head and to the heart. To do this, strong brands often seek to build on their performance advantages to strike an emotional chord with their customers.

 

Brand consultant Marc Gobé believes emotional brands share 3 specific traits:

(i) Strong people-focused corporate culture,

(ii) A distinctive communication style and philosophy, and

(iii) A compelling emotional hook.

Question 35
According to Kevin Roberts, Brands that arelovemarks, command both respect and love and result from a brand’s ability to achieve _____, _______ and ________.
  • A.longevity, mystery and originality
  • B.mystery, sensuality and intimacy
  • C.longevity, sensuality and originality
  • D.mystery, intimacy and originality
Correct Answer: mystery, sensuality and intimacy

According to Kevin Roberts, Brands that are lovemarks, command both respect and love and result from a brand’s ability to achieve:

(i) Mystery draws together stories, metaphors, dreams, and symbols. Mystery adds to the complexity of relationships and experiences because people are naturally drawn to what they don’t know.

(ii) Sensuality keeps the 5 senses of sight, hearing, smell, touch, and taste on constant alert for new textures, intriguing scents and tastes, wonderful music, and other sensory stimuli.

(iii) Intimacy means empathy, commitment, and passion. The close connections that win intense loyalty as well as the small perfect gesture.

Question 36
An alternate form of branding that is based on deep metaphors that connect to people’s memories, associations and stories, is known as
  • A.Narrative branding
  • B.Emotional branding
  • C.Historical branding
  • D.Fictional branding
Correct Answer: Narrative branding

As observed by Randall Ringer and Michael Thibodeau, Narrative branding is based on deep metaphors that connect to people’s memories, associations, and stories. Some marketing experts describe positioning a brand as telling a narrative or story rather than outlining specific attributes or benefits.

 

There are 5 elements of Narrative branding:

(a) The brand story in terms of words and metaphors,

(b) The consumer journey in terms of how consumers engage with the brand over time and touch points where they come into contact with it,

(c) The visual language or expression for the brand,

(d) The manner in which the narrative is expressed experientially in terms of how the brand engages the senses, and

(e) The role/relationship the brand plays in the lives of consumers.

Question 37
Just like a story, a brand narrative has the following essential components:(a) Setting(b) Cast(c) Narrative arc(d) Language(e) Director(f) Producer(g) MusicChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(a), (c), (d) and (e)
  • B.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
  • C.(a), (e), (f) and (g)
  • D.(a), (c), (d) and (f)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c) and (d)

Narrative branding is based on deep metaphors that connect to people’s memories, associations, and stories.

Based on literary convention and brand experience, following is the framework for a brand story:

(i) Setting: The time, place, and context.

(ii) Cast: The brand as a character, including its role in the life of the audience, its relationships and responsibilities, and its history or creation myth.

(iii) Narrative arc: The way the narrative logic unfolds over time, including actions, desired experiences, defining events, and the moment of epiphany.

(iv) Language: The authenticating voice, metaphors, symbols, themes, and leitmotif.

Question 38
_____ views brands as complex belief system.
  • A.Primitive branding
  • B.Primal branding
  • C.Value branding
  • D.Emotional branding
Correct Answer: Primal branding

Patrick Hanlon developed the related concept of “Primal branding” that views brands as complex belief systems. According to him, diverse brands such as Google, MINI Cooper, Starbucks, Apple, and UPS all have a “primal code” or DNA that resonates with their customers and generates their passion and fervor. He outlines 7 assets that make up this belief system or primal code: a creation story, creed, icon, rituals, sacred words, a way of dealing with nonbelievers, and a good leader.

Question 39
A chronicle of the varied things that happen in our brand world, throughout our day, throughout the years is called
  • A.Brand News
  • B.Brand Magazine
  • C.Brand Journalism
  • D.Brand Channel
Correct Answer: Brand Journalism

According to Larry Light, “Brand Journalism is a chronicle of the varied things that happen in our brand world, throughout our day, throughout the years. Our brand means different things to different people. It does not have one brand position. It is positioned differently in the minds of kids, teens, young adults, parents and seniors. It is positioned differently at breakfast, lunch, dinner, snack, weekday, weekend, with kids or on a business trip. Brand Journalism allows us to be a witness to the multi-faceted aspects of a brand story. No one communication alone tells the whole brand story. Each communication provides a different insight into our brand.

Question 40
For Positioning and Branding which of the following is/are the guideline(s) for a small business?
  • A.Creatively conduct low-cost marketing research
  • B.Focus on building one or two strong brands based on one or two key associations
  • C.Create buzz and a loyal brand community
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

For small businesses with limited resources behind the brand, both focus and consistency in marketing programs are critically important. Creativity is also paramount i.e. finding new ways to market new ideas about products to consumers.

 

Some specific branding guidelines for small businesses are as follows

(a) Creatively conduct low-cost marketing research - There are a variety of low-cost marketing research methods that help small businesses connect with customers and study competitors. One way is to set up course projects at local colleges and universities to access the expertise of both students and professors.

(b) Focus on building one or two strong brands based on one or two key associations - Small businesses often must rely on only one or two brands and key associations as points of difference for those brands. These associations must be consistently reinforced across the marketing program and over time.

(c) Employ a well-integrated set of brand elements - Tactically, it is important for small businesses to maximize the contribution of each of the 3 main sets of brand equity drivers. They should develop a distinctive, well-integrated set of brand elements that enhances both brand awareness and brand image. Brand elements should be memorable and meaningful, with as much creative potential as possible. Innovative packaging can substitute for ad campaigns by capturing attention at the point of purchase.

(d) Create buzz and a loyal brand community - Because small businesses often must rely on word of mouth to establish their positioning, public relations, social networking, and low-cost promotions and sponsorship can be inexpensive alternatives. Creating a vibrant brand community among current and prospective customers can also be a cost-effective way to reinforce loyalty and help spread the word to new prospects.

(e) Leverage as many secondary associations as possible - Secondary associations in terms of any persons, places, or things with potentially relevant associations, are often a cost-effective, shortcut means to build brand equity, especially those that help to signal quality or credibility.

Question 41
Arrange the levels from top to bottom, of the Brand Dynamics Pyramid given under the Brands Model of brand strength:(i) Bonding(ii) Performance(iii) Presence(iv) Advantage(v) RelevanceSelect the correct option:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • B.(i), (iii), (iv), (v), (ii)
  • C.(i), (v), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • D.(i), (iv), (ii), (v), (ii)
Correct Answer: (i), (iv), (ii), (v), (ii)

Marketing research consultants Millward Brown and WPP have developed the BrandZ model of brand strength, at the heart of which is the Brand Dynamics pyramid.

 

According to this model, brand building follows a series of steps:

(a) Presence: Active familiarity based on past trial, saliency, or knowledge of brand promise.

(b) Relevance: Relevance to consumer’s needs either in the right price range or in the right consideration set.

(c) Performance: Belief that it delivers acceptable product performance and is on the consumer’s short-list.

(d) Advantage: Belief that the brand has an emotional or rational advantage over other brands in the category.

(e) Bonding: Rational and emotional attachments to the brand to the exclusion of most other brands.

 

“Bonded” consumers at the top of the pyramid build stronger relationships with and spend more on the brand than those at lower levels. There are more consumers at the lower levels, so the challenge for marketers is to help them move up.

Question 42
The specific mix of human traits that we can attribute to a particular brand is known as:
  • A.brand personality
  • B.consumer trait
  • C.product attribute
  • D.consumer choice
Correct Answer: brand personality

By Personality, we mean a set of distinguishing human psychological traits that lead to relatively consistent and enduring responses to environmental stimuli (including buying behavior).

Personality can be a useful variable in analyzing consumer brand choices. Brands also have personalities, and consumers are likely to choose brands whose personalities match their own. We define brand personality as the specific mix of human traits that we can attribute to a particular brand.

Stanford’s Jennifer Aaker researched brand personalities and identified the following traits:

(i) Sincerity (down-to-earth, honest, wholesome, and cheerful)

(ii) Excitement (daring, spirited, imaginative, and up-to-date)

(iii) Competence (reliable, intelligent, and successful)

(iv) Sophistication (upper-class and charming)

(v) Ruggedness (outdoorsy and tough)

Question 43
Given below are two statements labelled as Assertion A and Reason R. Read the statements and answer the question that follows: (UGC NET Management Dec 2019)Assertion A: Every product or service should be branded otherwise they will be treated as commodity.Reasons R: If the product or service is branded then it always commands a higher price.Which of the following is correct?
