  • A.Both the statements A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A
  • B.Both the statements A and R are correct but R is not the right explanation of A
  • C.Statement A is correct, but statement R is incorrect
  • D.Both statements A and R are correct
Correct Answer: Statement A is correct, but statement R is incorrect

Assertion A states that every product or service should be branded, otherwise, they will be treated as commodities. This is a valid point, as branding helps differentiate products and services in the market, creating a unique identity and perception among customers.

 

Reason R suggests that if the product or service is branded, it always commands a higher price. This is not universally true. While branding can create value and allow companies to charge premium prices, it doesn't guarantee that every branded product will command a higher price. Pricing is influenced by various factors, including competition, perceived value, and market dynamics.

 

Since the reason provided in statement R is not accurate in all cases, option (C) is the correct choice, indicating that statement A is correct, but statement R is incorrect.

Question 44
_________ consists of all brand-related thoughts, feelings, perceptions, images, experiences, beliefs, attitudes, and so on that become linked to the brand node.
  • A.Brand link
  • B.Brand association
  • C.Brand relatedness
  • D.Brand connection
Correct Answer: Brand association

Brand associations consist of all brand-related thoughts, feelings, perceptions, images, experiences, beliefs, attitudes, and so on that become linked to the brand node. We can think of marketing as a way of making sure consumers have product and service experiences to create the right brand knowledge structures and maintain them in memory.

 

Companies such as Procter & Gamble like to create mental maps of consumers that depict their knowledge of a particular brand in terms of the key associations likely to be triggered in a marketing setting, and their relative strength, favorability, and uniqueness to consumers.

Question 45
Match the items of List – I with the items of the List – II:List – I(Company Name)a. HULb. ITCc. Nestled. CadburyList – II(Brand)i.Cerelacii.Eclaresiii.Viveliv.SunsilkCodes:
  • A.a-iv b-iii c-id-ii
  • B.a-ib-ii c-iii d-iv
  • C.a-iv b-ii c-iii d-i
  • D.a-iv b-iii c-ii d-i
Correct Answer: a-iv b-iii c-id-ii

HUL (Hindustan Unilever Ltd) - Hindustan Unilever Limited (HUL) is the Indian subsidiary of Unilever. Sunsilk shampoo is a product of HUL.

 

ITC (Indian Tobacco company)- ITC is an Indian company headquartered in Kolkata. Vivel is bathing range from ITC.

 

Nestle- Cerelac is the baby food product by Nestle India.

 

Cadbury is a British multinational confectionery. Eclairs candy is a product of Cadbury.

Question 46
An offering from a known source is
  • A.Brand
  • B.Positioning
  • C.Wants
  • D.Marketplace
Correct Answer: Brand

A brand is an offering from a known source. It is an identifying symbol, mark, logo, name, word and/or sentence that companies use to distinguish their product from others. All companies strive to build a brand image with as many strong, favorable, and unique brand associations as possible.

Question 47
The total combined customer lifetime values of all the company’s customers is called
  • A.Customer total Value
  • B.Customer total Lifetime Value
  • C.Customer Equity
  • D.Customer Brand
Correct Answer: Customer Equity

Customer Equity: The total combined customer lifetime values of all the company’s current and potential customers.

 

The ultimate aim of customer relationship management is to produce high customer equity. It is a measure of the future value of the company’s customer base. Clearly, the more loyal the firm’s profitable customers, the higher its customer equity.

Question 48
Consider the following statements-(UGC NET Management Jun 2014)(i) Brand equity is essentially the same as brand valuation.(ii) Market segmentation and product differentiation are alternative marketing strategies.(iii) Durable goods normally require less personal selling, after sales service and seller guarantees, than the non-durable goods.(iv) Price discrimination in all forms is illegal in India.Choose the correct statements:
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (d)
  • C.(c) Only
  • D.None
Correct Answer: None

The given question presents four statements related to marketing concepts and strategies. The correct answer is (D) "None," as none of the provided statements are accurate.

 

(i) Brand equity is essentially the same as brand valuation: This statement is incorrect. Brand equity refers to the intangible value and strong associations a brand has in the minds of consumers, while brand valuation involves assigning a monetary value to a brand based on various factors.

 

(ii) Market segmentation and product differentiation are alternative marketing strategies: This statement is incorrect. Market segmentation and product differentiation are not alternative strategies but rather complementary ones. Market segmentation involves dividing the market into distinct groups based on specific characteristics, while product differentiation aims to create unique features or benefits to make a product stand out in the market.

 

(iii) Durable goods normally require less personal selling, after-sales service, and seller guarantees than non-durable goods: This statement is incorrect. Durable goods, being more expensive and having longer lifecycles, often require more personal selling, after-sales service, and seller guarantees to assure customers of their value and performance over time.

 

(iv) Price discrimination in all forms is illegal in India: This statement is incorrect. Price discrimination, under certain circumstances, is not illegal in India or other countries. It becomes illegal when it leads to unfair competition or violates antitrust laws. In some cases, price discrimination is allowed and is considered a common practice in business.

Question 49
Consider the following statements (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)(a) All marketing strategy is built on segmentation, targeting and positioning.(b) A brand mantra must communicate both what a brand is and what it is not.(c) Goal incompatibility is one of the major causes of conflict among distribution channel members.(d) Physical goods, services and stores can have a brand name, but ideas and people cannot.Which of these statements are true?
  • A.All of them
  • B.(a) and (b)
  • C.(b) and (c)
  • D.(a), (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

All three statements (a), (b), and (c) are true, making option (D) - "(a), (b), and (c)" the correct answer.

 

Statement (a) - "All marketing strategy is built on segmentation, targeting, and positioning":

This statement is true. Segmentation, targeting, and positioning (STP) are fundamental concepts in marketing. Segmentation involves dividing a market into distinct groups with similar needs and characteristics. Targeting involves selecting one or more of these segments as the focus of the marketing efforts. Positioning involves creating a unique image and value proposition in the minds of the target customers. These three concepts are interconnected and form the basis for developing an effective marketing strategy.

 

Statement (b) - "A brand mantra must communicate both what a brand is and what it is not":

This statement is true. A brand mantra is a short, three-to-five-word articulation of the core essence and identity of a brand. It should convey not only what the brand stands for but also help differentiate it from competitors. By communicating what the brand is not, it helps to set clear boundaries and expectations for the brand, making it distinct and easily understandable to both internal stakeholders and consumers.

 

Statement (c) - "Goal incompatibility is one of the major causes of conflict among distribution channel members":

This statement is true. Goal incompatibility refers to situations where the goals and objectives of different members within a distribution channel conflict with each other. For example, a manufacturer may want to maximize production efficiency by producing in large quantities, while a retailer may want to minimize inventory costs by ordering smaller quantities. Such conflicts can lead to tensions and disagreements among channel members.

 

Statement (d) - "Physical goods, services and stores can have a brand name, but ideas and people cannot":

This statement is true. Branding typically applies to tangible products, services, and physical entities such as stores or locations. While ideas and people can have a reputation or a public image, they are not typically referred to as having a "brand name" in the same way that products or services do.

Question 50
Which one of the following is a potential drawback ofmultibranding? (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.The company’s resources may be spread over too many brands.
  • B.Consumers may become confused about the image of the main brand.
  • C.An over-extended brand name might lose its specific meaning for consumers.
  • D.Different product features can appeal to consumers with different buying motives.
Correct Answer: The company’s resources may be spread over too many brands.

Multibranding is a brand development strategy that involves a company producing multiple brands within a specific product category.

 

Potential Drawback of Multibranding: The Company's Resources May Be Spread Over Too Many Brands (Option A)

 

When a company adopts a multibranding strategy, it introduces several brands within a single product category. This can lead to a division of the company's resources, both financial and human, across all these different brands. As each brand competes in the market, it requires investment in terms of marketing, advertising, research, development, and distribution.

 

However, spreading resources too thinly across numerous brands can have negative consequences. It might prevent the company from dedicating substantial resources to building a few brands to a highly profitable level. The risk is that none of the brands achieve a significant market share or become truly profitable due to the limited resources allocated to each. The company may find it challenging to create strong brand identities, provide sufficient marketing support, and maintain consistent product quality across all these brands.

 

For instance, if a company produces multiple brands of consumer electronics, each catering to a slightly different segment, it could struggle to invest enough in product innovation, marketing campaigns, and customer support for each brand. As a result, consumers might not perceive any of the brands as being particularly strong or dominant in the market, leading to reduced brand loyalty and market share.

Question 51
Evaluate the statements according to Brand Asset Valuator Model of Brand Equity: (UGC NET Management Nov 2017)Statement I:Knowledge measures the degree to which a brand is seen as different from others as well as its pricing power.Statement II:Esteem measures perceptions of quality and loyalty or how well the brand is regarded and respected.Choose the correct option-
  • A.Both the Statements are correct.
  • B.Both the Statements are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct while Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect while Statement II is correct.

According to the Brand Asset Valuator Model of Brand Equity, Statement I is incorrect as it misrepresents the concept of Knowledge, while Statement II is correct in accurately describing the concept of Esteem. Let us assess the provided statements according to this model:

 

Statement (I): Knowledge measures the degree to which a brand is seen as different from others as well as its pricing power.

This statement is incorrect. In the Brand Asset Valuator Model, Knowledge refers to the extent to which consumers are aware of and knowledgeable about the brand. It assesses consumers' familiarity with the brand, its associations, and its presence in the market. It does not directly measure how different a brand is from others or its pricing power.

 

Statement (II): Esteem measures perceptions of quality and loyalty or how well the brand is regarded and respected.

This statement is correct. Esteem in the Brand Asset Valuator Model indeed measures how consumers perceive the brand's quality, loyalty, and the level of respect and admiration they hold for the brand. It reflects the positive reputation and strong consumer sentiment associated with the brand.

Question 52
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II and indicate the code of correct matching: (UGC NET Management Jan 2017)List – Ia. Brand elementsb. Brand linec. Brand personalityd. Brand promiseList – IIi. The marketer’s vision of what the brand must be and do for consumers.ii. All products, original as well as line and category extensions, sold under a particular brand name.iii. Those trademarkable devices that serve to identify and differentiate the brand.iv. The specific mix of human traits that may be attributed to a particular brand.Codes:
  • A.a- iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a- iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i

The correct code for matching is (A) a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i.

 

(a) Brand elements - (iii) Those trademarkable devices that serve to identify and differentiate the brand.

(b) Brand line - (ii) All products, original as well as line and category extensions, sold under a particular brand name.

(c) Brand personality - (iv) The specific mix of human traits that may be attributed to a particular brand.

(d) Brand promise - (i) The marketer’s vision of what the brand must be and do for consumers.

 

(a) Brand elements: Brand elements collectively refer to various elements that make up a brand's identity. They include visual and auditory cues like brand name, logo, symbol, tagline, and more. These elements help consumers identify and differentiate the brand.

 

(b) Brand line: A brand line encompasses all products, including original products and their various extensions, that are sold under a particular brand name. This concept is broader than individual products, as it considers the range of offerings under a single brand.

 

(c) Brand personality: Brand personality involves attributing human traits and characteristics to a brand to give it relatable and distinct qualities. These traits can include qualities like sophistication, friendliness, excitement, or trustworthiness, and they contribute to how consumers emotionally connect with the brand.

 

(d) Brand promise: The brand promise is the vision that marketers have for what the brand should deliver to its consumers. It is the commitment and value proposition the brand provides, influencing consumer expectations and their decision to choose that brand.

Question 53
If Mr. X pays a well-known fashion innovator such as Calvin Klein for the right to use its name on his apparel and accessories, then Mr. X is using which type of branding? [UGCNET Management June 2019]
  • A.Co-branding
  • B.Private branding
  • C.Manufacturer's branding
  • D.Licensed branding
Correct Answer: Licensed branding

The scenario described involves Mr. X, who wants to use the name of a well-known fashion innovator like Calvin Klein on his apparel and accessories. This situation is a common business practice known as "Licensed branding." It occurs when an individual or company pays for the right to use a well-known brand's name, logo, or other brand elements on their products or services. In this scenario, Mr. X is seeking to obtain a license from Calvin Klein to use the Calvin Klein brand name on his apparel and accessories. This is precisely what licensed branding entails.

 

(A) Co-branding: Co-branding is a strategy where two or more established brands collaborate to create a product or service together. Each brand's name is typically displayed prominently on the product to showcase the partnership. In this scenario, Mr. X is not collaborating with Calvin Klein to create a joint product; instead, he is seeking the right to use the Calvin Klein brand name on his own products. Co-branding does not apply here.

 

(B) Private branding: Private branding, also known as private label or store brand, is when a retailer or individual company creates its own brand to be used exclusively on its products. This option doesn't fit the scenario because Mr. X is not creating a new brand; he is interested in using the existing Calvin Klein brand name on his products. Private branding is typically about establishing a separate, in-house brand identity.

 

(C) Manufacturer's branding: Manufacturer's branding refers to products that carry the brand name of the company that manufactures them. In this case, Mr. X is not the manufacturer of the products; he is a business owner who wants to use the Calvin Klein brand name on his products, but the manufacturing may still be done by Calvin Klein or another entity. Therefore, manufacturer's branding is not the right choice.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) Licensed branding, as it accurately describes the scenario where Mr. X is using the Calvin Klein brand name on his products through a licensing agreement.

Question 54
Evaluate the statements according to Aaker model of defining brand identity/equity:Statement I: A particularly important concept for building brand equity is brand identity thatrepresents what the brand stands for and promises to customersStatement II: The core identity is most likely to change as the brand travels to new markets and products.Which of the following options is correct? [UGC NET Management Jun 2019]
  • A.Both the statements are correct
  • B.Both the statements are incorrect
  • C.Statement (I) is correct while Statement (II) is incorrect
  • D.Statement (I) is incorrect while Statement (II) is correct
Correct Answer: Statement (I) is correct while Statement (II) is incorrect

Building brands involves the development of a unique meaning that holds value which is also known as Brand Identity. A positive brand identity can result in adding more value to brand equity which then leads to an increase in brand loyalty. They work together. Therefore, Statement (I) is correct.

 

Statement I: "A particularly important concept for building brand equity is brand identity that represents what the brand stands for and promises to customers."

It is consistent with the Aaker model of brand identity and equity. According to this model, brand identity is a central and vital component in the process of building brand equity. Brand identity encompasses the following key elements:

  • Brand Essence: The core values, attributes, and characteristics that define what the brand stands for.
  • Brand Promise: The commitments and assurances the brand makes to its customers regarding the benefits or value it will deliver.
  • Brand Associations: The unique associations and perceptions that customers have about the brand, including its personality, image, and reputation.

In essence, brand identity is the foundation upon which brand equity is built. A strong and consistent brand identity helps create customer loyalty, recognition, and preference, which, in turn, contribute to brand equity.

 

Statement II: "The core identity is most likely to change as the brand travels to new markets and products."

It is not consistent with the Aaker model. The Aaker model typically suggests that the core brand identity remains relatively stable over time, even as the brand expands into new markets or product categories. The core identity represents the timeless aspects of the brand, such as its fundamental values, mission, and brand promise.

 

While brands may adapt certain elements of their identity to align with the preferences and cultural nuances of different markets, the core identity remains a consistent anchor that ensures continuity and helps customers recognize and trust the brand across various contexts.

Question 55
Singapore Airlines offer personalized service at airport, excellent service in flight, menu of customer's choice, personal TV etc. It is an example of [UGC NET Management June 2019]
  • A.Functional brand
  • B.Justified brand
  • C.Image brand
  • D.Experience brand
Correct Answer: Experience brand

The correct option is (D) Experience brand.

An Experience brand is centered around creating memorable and unique experiences for customers. Singapore Airlines' offering of personalized service, in-flight amenities, and choice-based services aligns well with the concept of an Experience brand.

 

Functional Brand: A functional brand focuses on highlighting the functional benefits and features of the product or service. It emphasizes practicality and utility rather than emotional or experiential aspects.

 

Justified Brand: This term is not commonly used in branding concepts, and it doesn't match the description of Singapore Airlines' offering.

 

Image Brand: An image brand focuses on creating a specific perception or image associated with the brand. While Singapore Airlines certainly emphasizes its image, the question specifically mentions personalized service and unique experiences, making "Experience brand" a more appropriate fit.

Question 56
How often and how easily customers think of the brand under various purchase or consumption situations, is known as: (UGC NET Management June 2022)
  • A.Brand salience
  • B.Brand resonance
  • C.Brand feelings
  • D.Brand imagery
Correct Answer: Brand salience

The correct option is (A) Brand salience.

 

Brand salience refers to how often and easily customers think of a brand in various purchase or consumption situations. It represents the level of awareness and prominence a brand has in the minds of consumers. Essentially, brand salience reflects the brand's ability to come to the forefront of consumers' minds when they consider making a purchase or consuming a product.

 

Brand resonance: Brand resonance refers to the deep and enduring relationships that customers have with a brand. It involves strong brand loyalty, positive attitudes, and a high level of engagement with the brand.

 

Brand feelings: Brand feelings relate to the emotional connections and associations consumers have with a brand. It involves the emotional responses that a brand evokes in consumers.

 

Brand imagery: Brand imagery refers to the set of perceptions and mental associations that consumers have about a brand's physical attributes and intangible benefits.

Question 57
Which of the following are the myths of brand communities?I. Build the brand and the community will followII. Focus on opinion leaders to build a strong communityIII. Brand communities exist to serve the businessIV. Online social networks are the best way to build communityV. Social networks are one community tool, but the tool is not the strategyChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Management June 2022)
  • A.I and V only
  • B.II, V, IV only
  • C.I, II, III only
  • D.I, II, III, IV only
Correct Answer: I, II, III, IV only

The correct option is (D) I, II, III, IV only.

 

Brand communities are groups of consumers who share a common interest or passion for a particular brand. However, there are certain myths associated with brand communities that need to be clarified. Let's go through each option to understand the myths:

 

I. Build the brand and the community will follow: This is a common misconception that just creating a brand will automatically attract a community of loyal customers. Building a brand community requires active engagement, value creation, and meaningful interactions to foster a sense of belonging among consumers.

 

II. Focus on opinion leaders to build a strong community: While opinion leaders can play a role in influencing others, relying solely on them to build a strong brand community overlooks the importance of creating connections among all members and fostering a sense of shared identity.

 

III. Brand communities exist to serve the business: This myth suggests that brand communities are primarily for the benefit of the business. In truth, successful brand communities are built around meeting the needs and desires of the community members, not just serving the business's interests.

 

IV. Online social networks are the best way to build community: While online social networks can facilitate communication and interaction, a strong brand community can also exist offline through events, gatherings, and other activities that bring members together.

 

V. Social networks are one community tool, but the tool is not the strategy: This recognizes that while social networks can be a valuable tool for building brand communities, they are just one aspect of a comprehensive community-building strategy. The strategy should focus on fostering connections, creating value, and nurturing a sense of belonging among members.

Question 58
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:Luxury brands command price premiums and do not have a strong lifestyle component.Reason “R”:Luxury brands do not require any special considerations in how they are sold.Codes:
  • A.Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.
  • B.Both“A”and“R”are correct, but“R”is not the right explanation of“A”.
  • C.“A”is correct, but“R”is incorrect.
  • D.Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of“A”.
Correct Answer: Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.

The provided assertion and reason statements both contain inaccuracies, which is why the correct answer is (A) Both "A" and "R" are incorrect.

 

Assertion "A" claims that luxury brands command price premiums and do not have a strong lifestyle component. This assertion is incorrect because luxury brands are known for commanding higher prices precisely due to their exclusivity, craftsmanship, and the prestige they offer to consumers. Additionally, luxury brands often have a strong lifestyle component associated with them, which contributes to their appeal and helps shape the image they portray.

 

Reason "R" states that luxury brands do not require any special considerations in how they are sold. This reason is also incorrect. Luxury brands do require special considerations in their selling strategies. They need to carefully manage their distribution channels, maintain brand consistency across touchpoints, offer a unique and personalized customer experience, and often have to adopt strategies that preserve their exclusivity while reaching their target audience effectively.

Question 59
Match List I with List II (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)List I (Marketing Concept)A. Brand EquityB. Brand IdentityC. Brand ImageD. Market PotentialList II (Description)I. The maximum possible demand for a product when marketing expenditure in the industry is infinite.II. The mental perception and associations of consumers related to a brand.III. The peculiar distinguishingcolor, design, label of a brand which distinguish brand of a firm.IV. A pool of goodwill consumers have related to a brand.Choose the correct answer from the options given below.Codes
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

The correct matching of List I with List II for the given Marketing Concepts is (A) A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

 

A. Brand Equity (IV) - A pool of goodwill consumers have related to a brand.

Brand equity refers to the value and goodwill that a brand holds in the eyes of consumers. It represents the positive perception, trust, and loyalty that consumers have towards a brand. It is the result of the overall consumer experience and the association they have with the brand.

 

B. Brand Identity (III) - The peculiar distinguishing color, design, label of a brand which distinguishes the brand of a firm.

Brand identity encompasses the visual and sensory aspects that help distinguish a brand from others. This includes elements like logo, color schemes, design styles, taglines, and other visual and auditory elements that create a unique and recognizable image for the brand.

 

C. Brand Image (II) - The mental perception and associations of consumers related to a brand.

Brand image refers to the mental perceptions, beliefs, and associations that consumers hold about a brand. It is shaped by various factors, including brand messaging, past experiences, advertising, product quality, and the overall reputation of the brand.

 

D. Market Potential (I) - The maximum possible demand for a product when marketing expenditure in the industry is infinite.

Market potential refers to the highest level of demand that a product or service can achieve in a market under ideal conditions, assuming that marketing efforts are unlimited and all potential customers are aware of the product's availability.

Question 60
Which one of the following is not true for introducing multiple brands in a category? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)
  • A.Attracting consumers seeking variety who may otherwise have switched to another brand
  • B.Yielding economies of scale in advertising, sales, merchandising and physical distribution
  • C.Increasing shelf presence and retailer dependence in the store
  • D.Decreasing internal competition within the firm
Correct Answer: Decreasing internal competition within the firm

The correct answer is (D) Decreasing internal competition within the firm.

 

Introducing multiple brands in a category often increases internal competition within the firm rather than decreasing it. Each brand is intended to cater to a specific market segment, consumer preference, or price point, creating differentiation and potentially competing with other brands within the same company. The aim is to capture a larger market share by serving various consumer needs and preferences effectively.

Question 61
From the following two statements of Assertion (A) and Reason (R), indicate the correct code: (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)Assertion ‘A’:A transformational appeal of communication elaborates on a non-product related benefit or image.Reasoning ‘R’:Transformational appeals often do not attempt to stir up emotions that will motivate purchase.Codes:
  • A.A and R both are correct.
  • B.A is correct R is not correct.
  • C.A is not correct R is correct.
  • D.A and R both are incorrect.
Correct Answer: A is correct R is not correct.

The correct answer is (B) A is correct, R is not correct.

 

Assertion (A) states that a transformational appeal in communication elaborates on a non-product related benefit or image. This is correct. Transformational appeals focus on the psychological or emotional benefits associated with the product or service rather than its tangible features.

 

Reason (R) states that transformational appeals often do not attempt to stir up emotions that will motivate purchase. This is not correct. Transformational appeals indeed aim to evoke emotions and feelings that can motivate a purchase by connecting the product or service with the desired emotional experience.

Question 62
Which of the following marketing strategies is/are based on the principle of stimulusgeneralisation? (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)(a) Product line extension(b) Family branding(c) Licensing(d) CounterfeitingCodes:
  • A.a and b
  • B.b and c
  • C.a, b and c
  • D.a, b, c and d
Correct Answer: a, b, c and d

Marketing strategies based on the principle of stimulus generalization include:

 

(a) Product line extension: This strategy involves introducing new products or variations of existing products within the same product line. Consumers are expected to associate the new offerings with the existing brand, benefiting from the positive associations and loyalty they have with the brand.

 

(b) Family branding: Family branding, also known as umbrella branding, involves marketing different products or product lines under a common brand name. Consumers tend to generalize their positive perceptions of one product within the brand to other products bearing the same brand name.

 

(c) Licensing: Licensing involves granting another company the right to use a brand or trademark for its products. This strategy relies on the established brand's positive associations being transferred to the licensed products.

 

(d) Counterfeiting: Counterfeiting is not a legitimate marketing strategy but rather an illegal activity where unauthorized copies of branded products are made. However, it can be argued that counterfeiters attempt to mimic the branding and packaging of genuine products to take advantage of the stimulus generalization associated with the authentic brand.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) "a, b, c, and d" because all of these marketing strategies can be related to the principle of stimulus generalization in different ways, whether by extending product lines, utilizing family branding, licensing brand names, or even counterfeiting genuine brands.

Question 63
Match the following: (UGC NET Commerce Aug 2016)List- Ia. Brand Portfoliob. Brand Equityc. Brand Communityd. Brand ValuationList- IIi. A set of all brands and brand lines a firm offers for sale in a particular category or market segment.ii. An estimate of financial value of the brand.iii. Customers and employees whose identification and activities focus around the brand.iv. The added value endowed to products and services.Codes:
  • A.a- ii, b- iv, c- iii, d-i
  • B.a-i, b- ii, c- iii, d- iv
  • C.a-i, b- iv, c- iii, d- ii
  • D.a- iv, b- iii, c- ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-i, b- iv, c- iii, d- ii

The correct matching of the terms in List-I with their descriptions in List-II is as follows:

 

a. Brand Portfolio - i. A set of all brands and brand lines a firm offers for sale in a particular category or market segment.

Brand portfolio refers to the collection of all the brands and brand lines that a company offers within a specific category or market segment. It's like the company's "portfolio" of brands.

 

b. Brand Equity - iv. The added value endowed to products and services.

Brand equity is the added value that a brand brings to products and services. It represents the intangible assets, such as brand recognition and customer loyalty, that contribute to a brand's overall value.

 

c. Brand Community - iii. Customers and employees whose identification and activities focus around the brand.

A brand community is a group of customers and sometimes even employees who share a common interest and strong identification with a particular brand. They engage in activities related to the brand and often form a sense of belonging.

 

d. Brand Valuation - ii. An estimate of the financial value of the brand.

Brand valuation involves determining the financial value of a brand, typically in monetary terms. It assesses how much the brand contributes to a company's overall worth and can be essential for various business purposes, such as mergers and acquisitions or financial reporting.

 

So, the correct code is (C) a- i, b- iv, c- iii, d- ii.

Question 64
Delphi method of estimating future demand for a product or service is associated with:
  • A.Past Sales Analysis
  • B.Expert Opinion Method
  • C.Market Test Method
  • D.Composite of Sales Force Opinion
Correct Answer: Expert Opinion Method

The correct answer is (B) Expert Opinion Method.

 

The Delphi method is a forecasting technique that relies on the opinions and expertise of a panel of experts or knowledgeable individuals. It involves a structured and iterative process where experts provide their opinions and estimates regarding future demand or other relevant factors. The responses from the experts are collected, summarized, and then fed back to the experts for further rounds of estimation until a consensus or convergence is achieved. This method is particularly useful when historical data may be limited or unavailable, and it relies on expert judgment and insights.

Question 65
Which one of the following represents ‘Penetrated market’?(UGC NET Management Jul 2023)
  • A.The part of the qualified available market the company decides to pursue.
  • B.The set of consumers who are buying the company’s product.
  • C.The set of consumers who have interest, income, and access to a particular offer.
  • D.The set of consumers with a sufficient level of interest in a market offer.
Correct Answer: The set of consumers who are buying the company’s product.

The correct answer is (B) The set of consumers who are buying the company's product.

 

A penetrated market refers to the portion of the target market that the company has successfully reached and where consumers are currently purchasing the company's products or services. It represents the actual customer base that the company has acquired within its target market.

Question 66
Consider the following statements (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)(a) All marketing strategy is built on segmentation, targeting and positioning.(b) A brand mantra must communicate both what a brand is and what it is not.(c) Goal incompatibility is one of the major causes of conflict among distribution channel members.(d) Physical goods, services and stores can have a brand name, but ideas and people cannot.Which of these statements are true?
  • A.All of them
  • B.(a) and (b)
  • C.(b) and (c)
  • D.(a), (b) and (c)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

All three statements (a), (b), and (c) are true, making option (D) - "(a), (b), and (c)" the correct answer.

 

Statement (a) - "All marketing strategy is built on segmentation, targeting, and positioning":

This statement is true. Segmentation, targeting, and positioning (STP) are fundamental concepts in marketing. Segmentation involves dividing a market into distinct groups with similar needs and characteristics. Targeting involves selecting one or more of these segments as the focus of the marketing efforts. Positioning involves creating a unique image and value proposition in the minds of the target customers. These three concepts are interconnected and form the basis for developing an effective marketing strategy.

 

Statement (b) - "A brand mantra must communicate both what a brand is and what it is not":

This statement is true. A brand mantra is a short, three-to-five-word articulation of the core essence and identity of a brand. It should convey not only what the brand stands for but also help differentiate it from competitors. By communicating what the brand is not, it helps to set clear boundaries and expectations for the brand, making it distinct and easily understandable to both internal stakeholders and consumers.

 

Statement (c) - "Goal incompatibility is one of the major causes of conflict among distribution channel members":

This statement is true. Goal incompatibility refers to situations where the goals and objectives of different members within a distribution channel conflict with each other. For example, a manufacturer may want to maximize production efficiency by producing in large quantities, while a retailer may want to minimize inventory costs by ordering smaller quantities. Such conflicts can lead to tensions and disagreements among channel members.

 

Statement (d) - "Physical goods, services and stores can have a brand name, but ideas and people cannot":

This statement is true. Branding typically applies to tangible products, services, and physical entities such as stores or locations. While ideas and people can have a reputation or a public image, they are not typically referred to as having a "brand name" in the same way that products or services do.

Question 67
A brand personality is the specific mix of human traits that may be attributed to a particular brand. The 5 brand personality traits are:
  • A.sincerity, commitment, competence, sophistication, innovativeness
  • B.sincerity, excitement, competence, sophistication, ruggedness
  • C.sincerity, commitment, competence, loyalty, ruggedness
  • D.sincerity, commitment, competence, loyalty, innovativeness
Correct Answer: sincerity, excitement, competence, sophistication, ruggedness

The brands also have personalities, and consumers are likely to choose brands with personalities that match their own. A brand personality is the specific mix of human traits that may be attributed to a particular brand. One researcher identified 5 brand personality traits:

 

1. sincerity (down-to-earth, honest, wholesome, and cheerful);

2. excitement (daring, spirited, imaginative, and up-to-date);

3. competence (reliable, intelligent, and successful);

4. sophistication (upper class and charming); and

5. ruggedness (outdoorsy and tough).

Question 68
Match the following.List-I (Type of Product Placement)a. Stealth Placementb. Evocative Placementc. Classic Placementd. Corporate PlacementList-II (Description)i. It is discreet and subtle placement where the logo or name of the brand is not visual or neither mentionedii. It can be easier to put in a brand instead of a product in a movie for instance by putting the brands logo in the background of a movieiii. Integrated into the scene of a movie or a TV show very subtlyiv. brand appears in the camera’s view and is almost naturally integrated into the scenario of the movie or TV-showCodes:
  • A.a-ib-ii c-iii d-iv
  • B.a-ii b-iii c-id-iv
  • C.a-iii b-ic-iv d-ii
  • D.a-iv b-ii c-id-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii b-ic-iv d-ii

The impact that a Product Placement can have to the audience is based on the appearance of the placement and it can be divided into 4 different types of appearance: classic placement, corporate placement, evocative placement and stealth placement.

 

Classic Placement

The first type of placement is the classic placement that has existed since the practice of product placement was first derived. In this type of placement, the brand appears in the camera’s view and is almost naturally integrated in to the scenario of the movie or TV-show. For example, when Will Smith is wearing Converse shoes in the movie.

 

Corporate Placement

With a corporate placement the placement is focused on the brand and not a certain product. It can sometimes be easier to put in a brand instead of a product in a movie for instance by putting the brands logo in the background of a movie, such as the big billboard of McDonalds in the movie The Fifth Element. This kind of placement is best to use if the brand is a recognizable brand for the audience, otherwise it may never be noticed.

 

Evocative Placement

An evocative placement is a discreet and subtle placement where the logo or name of the brand is not visual or neither mentioned. With this kind of placement, it is important to have an original and unique design or packaging that can be associated and recognized to a brand by the audience. For example, including a scene in a movie which has a Ferrari car, without showing the logo. The design of a Ferrari car is such that even without seeing the logo, viewers can identify what car it is.

 

Stealth Placement

The last type of placement is stealth placement that is a highly discreet and subtle placement that sometimes almost can be undetectable. This type of placement is often well integrated into the scene that can generate a positive effect when the brand is identified due to that it is placed in a movie or TV-show in a natural way that the audience can perceive as more credible. This type of placement does often concern fashion, for example in the movie Drive where Ryan Gosling is wearing a pair of sunglasses from Selima Optique.

Question 69
What is a corporate brand strategy in context of deciding a branding strategy for a product?
  • A.A branding approach that focuses on the company name and individual brand name.
  • B.A brand strategy whereby the firm makes its company name the dominant brand identity across all of its products.
  • C.A brand strategy whereby the firm develops separate product range names for different families of product.
  • D.Abusiness strategy involving a company marketing several similar products as competitors, each with their own individual brand name.
Correct Answer: A brand strategy whereby the firm makes its company name the dominant brand identity across all of its products.

Corporate brand strategy- A brand strategy whereby the firm makes its company name the dominant brand identity across all of its products.

 

Company and individual brand strategy- A branding approach that focuses on the company name and individual brand name.

 

Range branding strategy- A brand strategy whereby the firm develops separate product range names far different families of product.

 

Multi brand strategy- A business strategy involving a company marketing several similar products as competitors, each with their own individual brand name.

Question 70
Which of the following is NOT a desirable feature of a brand name?
  • A.It can help develop brand loyalty amongst buyers
  • B.It can facilitate the introduction of new products.
  • C.It can make possible for the firm to engage in non-price competition
  • D.It can be used as a generic name for all products in a category
Correct Answer: It can be used as a generic name for all products in a category

A brand name have several desirable features such as to develop brand loyalty among buyers and also helps in facilitating introduction of a new product. It helps a firm in engaging non price competition on the basis of brand value. But on the other hand it cannot be used as a generic name for all the products in a category as the products might be differentiated and can have different uses so a brand name won’t be suitable for each of them. For Example, people started using Xerox for photocopying, where Xerox is the photocopy machine brand and not the actual process of getting photocopy done. Xerox became synonymous to photocopy which makes it difficult this brand name for anything else.

Question 71
Arranging for a market offering to occupy a clear, distinctive, and desirable place relative to competing products in the minds of target consumers is known as:
  • A.Brand Equity
  • B.Brand Dilution
  • C.Brand Positioning
  • D.Brand Repositioning
Correct Answer: Brand Positioning

The major brand strategy decisions involve brand positioning, brand name selection, brand sponsorship, and brand development.

 

 

Brand Positioning: Brand positioning consists of arranging for a market offering to occupy a clear, distinctive, and desirable place relative to competing products in the minds of target consumers.

 

Brand Repositioning: the process in which the marketers try to change the identity of the existing product or brand

 

Brand Equity: Brand equity is the differential effect that knowing the brand name has on customer response to the product and its marketing. It’s a measure of the brand’s ability to capture consumer preference and loyalty. A brand has positive brand equity when consumers react more favorably to it than to a generic or unbranded version of the same product. It has negative brand equity if consumers react less favorably than to an unbranded version.

 

Brand Dilution: Brand dilution happens when a brand loses its value from excessive use. Value is lost when a product or a piece of media does not meet the expectations customers have of the brand. Line extensions can lead to brand dilution if the new product does not live up to the brand promise of the original product.

Question 72
Firm uses any existing brand to introduce in market as a new product, brand is classified as:
  • A.Brand Extension
  • B.Sub-Brand
  • C.Parent Brand
  • D.Product Extension
Correct Answer: Brand Extension

The major brand strategy decisions involve brand positioning, brand name selection, brand sponsorship, and brand development.

 

BRAND DEVELOPMENT:

 

Line Extensions/Product Extension: Line extensions introduce additional items in the same product category under the same brand name, such as new flavors, forms, colors, added ingredients, and package sizes.

 

Brand Extensions: A company may use its existing brand name to launch new products in other categories. If a car dealer enters into car insurance business, it will be brand extension. An associated risk is brand dilution, which occurs when consumers no longer associate a brand with a specific product or highly similar products.

 

Multi-brands/Sub-Brands/Parent Brand/Umbrella Brand: A company will often introduce additional brands in the same or different product category. Sometimes the firm is trying to establish different features or appeal to different buying motives. Characteristics of the brand usually tie back to the parent brand, however remain distinct and with their own set of brand standards. It also enables the company to lock up more distributor shelf space and to protect its major brand by setting up flanker brands. For example, Dove, Lux, Sunsilk are sub brands of Unilever, which is the parent brand.

 

New Brands: When a company launches products in a new category, it may find that none of its current brand names are appropriate. If Timex decides to make toothbrushes, it is not likely to call them Timex toothbrushes.

Question 73
Given below are 2 Statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below.Assertion “A”:Luxury brands command price premiums and do not have a strong lifestyle component.Reason “R”:Luxury brands do not require any special considerations in how they are sold.Codes
  • A.Both A and R are incorrect.
  • B.Both A and R are correct, but R is not the right explanation of A
  • C.A is correct, but R is incorrect.
  • D.Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A
Correct Answer: Both A and R are incorrect.

Luxury brands are always sold at premium prices in market due to their high brand value and have a strong lifestyle component, associated with status of a person in society. Luxury brands do require special considerations when it comes to selling as in product placement, target market and mode of retailing as they cannot be made available at any random store and specialized merchandise are set up for these.

Question 74
The set of beliefs held about a particular brand is known as:
  • A.brand personality
  • B.brand image
  • C.brand identity
  • D.brand persona
Correct Answer: brand image

The consumer is likely to develop a set of brand beliefs about where each brand stands on each attribute. The set of beliefs held about a particular brand is known as the brand image. The consumer's beliefs may vary from true attributes based on his or her experience and the effect of selective perception, selective distortion and selective retention.

 

Selective attention: People are exposed to many daily stimuli such as ads; most of these stimuli are screened out—a process called selective attention. The end result is that marketers have to work hard to attract consumers’ attention.

 

Selective distortion: Even noticed stimuli do not always come across the way that marketers intend. Selective distortion is the tendency to twist information into personal meanings and interpret information in a way that fits our preconceptions. Unfortunately, marketers can do little about selective distortion.

 

Selective retention: People forget much that they learn but tend to retain information that supports their attitudes and beliefs. Because of selective retention, we are likely to remember good points mentioned about a product we like and forget good points mentioned about competing products. Selective retention explains why marketers use drama and repetition in messages to target audiences.

Question 75
A discreet and subtle placement where the logo or name of the brand is not visual or neither mentioned. With this kind of placement, it is important to have an original and unique design or packaging that can be associated and recognized to a brand by the audience is called:
  • A.Evocative Placement
  • B.Stealth Placement
  • C.Corporate placement
  • D.Classic Placement
Correct Answer: Evocative Placement

Evocative Placement- A discreet and subtle placement where the logo or name of the brand is not visual or neither mentioned. With this kind of placement, it is important to have an original and unique design or packaging that can be associated and recognized to a brand by the audience.

 

Classic placement - Classic placement that has existed since the practice of product placement was first derived. In this type of placement, the brand appears in the camera’s view and is almost naturally integrated in to the scenario of the movie or TV-show. For example, when Will Smith is wearing Converse shoes in the movie.

 

Stealth Placement- This is a highly discreet and subtle placement that sometimes almost can be undetectable. This type of placement is often well integrated into the scene that can generate a positive effect when the brand is identified due to that it is placed in a movie or TV-show in a natural way that the audience can perceive as more credible. This type of placement does often concern fashion, for example in the movie Drive where Ryan Gosling is wearing a pair of sunglasses from Selima Optique.

 

Corporate placement- With a corporate placement the placement is focused on the brand and not a certain product. It can sometimes be easier to put in a brand instead of a product in a movie for instance by putting the brands logo in the background of a movie, such as the big billboard of McDonalds in the movie The Fifth Element. This kind of placement is best to use if the brand is a recognizable brand for the audience, otherwise it may never be noticed.

Question 76
Which one of the following refers to “attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate, and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competitive brand”? (UGC NET ManagementNov2017)
  • A.Points-of-attributes
  • B.Points-of-difference
  • C.Points-of-parity
  • D.Points-of-purchase
Correct Answer: Points-of-difference

Points-of-difference (PODs) – Attributes or benefits consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competing brand i.e. points where you are claiming superiority or exclusiveness over other products in the category. Points-of-attributes is the same as POD.

 

Points-of-parity (POPs) – Associations that are not necessarily unique to the brand but may be shared by other brands i.e. where you can at least match the competitors claimed benefits. While POPs may usually not be the reason to choose a brand, their absence can certainly be a reason to drop a brand.

 

Points-of-purchase (POP) - A place where a sales transaction occurs. On a macro level, a point of purchase may be a mall, market or city. On a micro-level, retailers consider a point of purchase to be the location of checkout, which can be in-store or online.

Question 77
When 2 separate companies or 2 divisions within the same company agree to place both of their respective brands on a particular product or enterprise, this arrangement is termed as: (UGC NET Commerce Jul 2018)
  • A.Differential Branding
  • B.Cobranding
  • C.Dual Branding
  • D.Both Cobranding and Dual Branding
Correct Answer: Both Cobranding and Dual Branding

The major brand strategy decisions involve brand positioning, brand name selection, brand sponsorship, and brand development.

 

 

BRAND SPONSORSHIP: A manufacturer has 4 sponsorship options:

 

1. Manufacturer’s Brand (National Brand): The product may be launched as a national brand (or manufacturer’s brand), as when Sony and Kellogg sell their output under their own brand names (Sony Bravia HDTV or Kellogg’s Frosted Flakes).

 

2. Private Brand (Store brand or Distributor’s brand): A brand created and owned by a reseller of a product or service. Example, Big Bazaar

 

3. Licensed Brand: Some companies license names or symbols previously created by other manufacturers, names of well-known celebrities, or characters from popular movies and books. For a fee, any of these can provide an instant and proven brand name. Disney, the world’s biggest licensor, reported more than $30 billion in worldwide merchandise sales last year.

 

4. Co-branding: It occurs when two established brand names of different companies are used on the same product. Co-branding offers many advantages. Because each brand dominates in a different category, the combined brands create broader consumer appeal and greater brand equity.

 

There are various types of co-branding as follows:

Ingredient Co-branding − Multiple brands provide distinctive ingredient or component to the carrier brand. For example, Intel chip inside all computers.

 

Product-Service Co-branding − It is a co-branding between a product and a service. For example, Best Western International, Inc. owns and operates a chain of hotels with state-of-the-art amenities and services to its customers. It runs an exclusive rewards program for Harley Davidson owners. The participating riders get lavish privileged treatment at the hotel.

 

Alliance Co-branding − Multiple brand serve the same target audience. For example, Etihad Airways Partners, is a new brand which brings like-minded airlines together to offer customers more choice in flight schedules and enhanced frequent flyer benefits.

Supplier-Retailer Co-branding − Starbucks Wi-Fi started from AT&T in the most number of metropolitan cities in USA since 2008.

 Promotional Co-branding − It is an alliance of a brand with persons or events.

Question 78
Match the items of List - I with the items of List - II which are related to dimensions of brand personality. Denote the code of correct matching. (UGC NET Commerce Nov 2017)List - I(a) Sincerity(b) Excitement(c) Competence(d) Sophistication(e) RuggednessList - II(i) Upper class, Charming(ii) Reliable, Intelligent, Successful(iii) Down to earth, Cheerful, Wholesome(iv) Outdoors, Tough(v) Spirited, Imaginative, Up-to-dateCodes
  • A.a-(v) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii) e-(iv)
  • B.a-(i) b-(iv) c-(iii) d-(ii) e-(v)
  • C.a-(iii) b-(v) c-(ii) d-(i) e-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iii) d-(v) e-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(v) c-(ii) d-(i) e-(iv)

Brand personality is a set of human characteristics that are attributed to a brand name. A brand personality is something to which the consumer can relate; an effective brand increases its brand equity by having a consistent set of traits that a specific consumer segment enjoys.

 

There are 5 main types of brand personalities with common traits:

1. Sincerity- Down to earth, Cheerful, Wholesome are related to sincerity.

2. Excitement- Spirited, Imaginative, Up-to-date are related to excitement

3. Competence- Reliable, Intelligent, Successful are related to competence

4. Sophistication- Upper class, Charming are related to sophistication.

5. Ruggedness- Outdoors, Tough are related to ruggedness

Question 79
Which one of the following is correct statement in respect of co-branding? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2015)
  • A.Co-branding is an umbrella branding of goods of a company.
  • B.In co-branding, two or more well-known existing brands are combined into a joint product.
  • C.Co-branding is the process of combining two brands for promoting brand equity.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: In co-branding, two or more well-known existing brands are combined into a joint product.

Co-brands: A rising phenomenon is the emergence of co-branding (also called dual branding), in which 2 or more well-known brands are combined in an offer. Each brand sponsor expects that the other brand name will strengthen preference or purchase intention. In the case of co-packaged products, each brand hopes it might be reaching a new audience by associating with the other brand.

 

Co-branding:

There are various types of co-branding as follows −

Ingredient Co-branding − Multiple brands provide distinctive ingredient or component to the carrier brand. For example, Intel chip inside all computers.

 

Product-Service Co-branding − It is a co-branding between a product and a service. For example, Best Western International, Inc. owns and operates a chain of hotels with state-of-the-art amenities and services to its customers. It runs an exclusive rewards program for Harley Davidson owners. The participating riders get lavish privileged treatment at the hotel.

 

Alliance Co-branding − Multiple brand serve the same target audience. For example, Etihad Airways Partners, is a new brand which brings like-minded airlines together to offer customers more choice in flight schedules and enhanced frequent flyer benefits.

 

Supplier-Retailer Co-branding − Starbucks Wi-Fi started from AT&T in the most number of metropolitan cities in USA since 2008.

 

Promotional Co-branding − It is an alliance of a brand with persons or events.

Question 80
Two statements are given below relating to the consumer brand selection model.Statement I:As per disjunctive decision rule consumers set a minimum acceptable cut off level for each attribute and choose the first alternative that meets the minimum standard for all selected attributes.Statement II:As per lexicographic decision rule consumers choose the best brand on the basis of its perceived most important attribute.Choose the correct option about the statements from the options given below:(UGC NET ManagementSep2023)Codes
  • A.Statement I alone is correct
  • B.Statement II alone is correct
  • C.Both statements are correct
  • D.Both statements are incorrect
Correct Answer: Statement II alone is correct

Consumer Decision Process:

Consumers use five decision rules: conjunctive, disjunctive, elimination-by-aspects, lexicographic, and compensatory.

 

1. Conjunctive Decision Rule- establishes minimum required performance standards for each evaluative criterion and selects the first or all brands that surpass these minimum standards. In essence, you would say: “I'll consider all (or I'll buy the first) brands that are all right on the attributes I think are important.”

 

2. Disjunctive Decision Rule- establishes a minimum level of performance for each important attribute (often a fairly high level). All brands that surpass the performance level for any key attribute are considered acceptable. Using this rule, you would say: "I'll consider all (or buy the first) brands that perform really well on any attribute I consider to be important."

 

3. Elimination-by-aspects- requires the consumer to rank the evaluative criteria in terms of their importance and to establish a cutoff point for each criterion. All brands are first considered on the most important criterion. Those that do not surpass the cutoff point are dropped from consideration. If more than one brand passes the cutoff point, the process is repeated on those brands for the second most important criterion. This continues until only one brand remains. Thus, the consumer's logic is: "I want to buy the brand that has a high level of an important attribute that other brands do not have."

 

4. Lexicographic Decision Rule- requires the consumer to rank the criteria in order of importance. The consumer then selects the brand that performs best on the most important attribute. If two or more brands tie on this attribute, they are evaluated on the second most important attribute. This continues through the attributes until one brand outperforms the others. The consumer's thinking is something like this: "I want to get the brand that does best on the attribute of most importance to me. If there is a tie, I'll break it by choosing the one that does best on my second most important criterion." The lexicographic decision rule is very similar to the elimination-by-aspects rule. The difference is that the lexicographic rule seeks maximum performance at each stage while the elimination-by-aspects seeks satisfactory performance at each stage.

 

5. Compensatory Decision Rule- The four previous rules are non-compensatory decision rules, since very good performance on one evaluative criterion cannot compensate for poor performance on another evaluative criterion. On occasion, consumers may wish to average out some very good features with some less attractive features of a product in determining overall brand preference. Therefore, the compensatory decision rule states that the brand that rates highest on the sum of the consumer's judgments of the relevant evaluative criteria will be chosen.

Question 81
________ is the added value endowed to a product or service. (UGC NET ManagementDec2014)
  • A.Brand Equity
  • B.Brand Image
  • C.Brand Loyalty
  • D.Brand Preference
Correct Answer: Brand Equity

Brand Equity- A brand's power derived from the goodwill and name recognition that it has earned over time, which translates into higher sales volume and higher profit margins against competing brands or we can say brand equity is the added value endowed to a product or service.

Brand Image- Brand image is the current view of the customers about a brand. It can be defined as a unique bundle of associations within the minds of target customers.  it is the consumers’ perception about the product. It is the manner in which a specific brand is positioned in the market. Brand image conveys emotional value and not just a mental image.

 

The idea behind brand image is that the consumer is not purchasing just the product/service but also the image associated with that product/service. Brand images should be positive, unique and instant. Brand images can be strengthened using brand communications like advertising, packaging, word of mouth publicity, other promotional tools, etc.

 

Brand Loyalty- Brand loyalty is a consumer behavior pattern where consumers become committed to a particular brand and make repeat purchases over time. Companies use creative marketing strategies, such as loyalty or rewards programs, trials, brand ambassadors, and incentives like free samples to build brand loyalty.

 

Brand Preference- A behaviour exhibited by consumers in which there is prioritization of one brand over another in the same category. This indicates a certain loyalty to the product and consistency in its use.

Question 82
Which one of the following is a potential drawback of multi-branding?
  • A.The company’s resources may be spread over too many brands.
  • B.Consumers may become confused about the image of the main brand.
  • C.An over-extended brand name might lose its specific meaning for consumers.
  • D.Different product features can appeal to consumers with different buying motives.
Correct Answer: The company’s resources may be spread over too many brands.

When offering products to the public, branding can help enhance customer loyalty and help the company be more profitable overall. One particular branding strategy you can use is multi-product branding, which involves releasing multiple products with the same brand name. While this strategy can be simple to use, it can lead to some problems.

 

Dilute Brand Name

One of the potential problems with using multi-product branding is that it can delete the effectiveness of the brand name. When consumers see the brand name everywhere on many different types of products, they may not necessarily put the same faith in the brand as they once did. This can lead to lower sales in all of the different product categories a brand encompasses. By sticking to related products in a brand, you often can grab more market share of that particular niche.

 

All Products Tied Together

Another potential disadvantage of using this branding strategy is that it ties all of the products together. In some cases, this can be good, but problems can arise. For example, if your brand covers household products such as soap and cleaners but it also covers chainsaws, one chainsaw malfunction could lead to a bad perception associated with the other products in the lineup. You have to make sure all of the products in your line share the same level of quality.

 

Difficulty in Managing

When you put your brand name on many different types of products, you eventually may have a hard time managing them all. If you restrict your brand name to items that are similar to one other, such as soap, shampoo and conditioner, it is typically easier to manage them. If you start dealing with products that are completely unrelated to one another, such as soap and automobiles, you may have a hard time effectively managing your resources.

 

Expectations on New Products

Another potential problem you may run into using multi-product branding is unfair expectations on new products. For example, if your brand has a certain standard of excellence in the eyes of the public, every new product is scrutinized. If the new products do not meet the standards of the old ones, it can lead to a negative stigma surrounding the brand. Every new product must have all of the kinks worked out before you release it to the general public.

Question 83
Branding seeks:(UGC NET ManagementJun2014)
  • A.to differentiate the product
  • B.to charge differential price
  • C.to sell the product in different countries
  • D.to give attractive name to a product
Correct Answer: to differentiate the product

The process involved in creating a unique name and image for a product in the consumers' mind, mainly through advertising campaigns with a consistent theme. Branding aims to establish a significant and differentiated presence in the market that attracts and retains loyal customers.

Question 84
Consider the following statements:(UGC NET ManagementDec2013)i. Brand equity is a function of brand awareness and brand preference.ii. Product lines tend to shorten over time.iii. The Standards of Weights and Measures (Packaged Commodities) Rules, 1977 provide for the labelling rules relating to packaged commodities.iv. AIDA Model is relevant to advertising as well as physical distribution.Indicate the correct answer.Codes:
  • A.All the above statements are false.
  • B.Only iii is true.
  • C.i, iii and iv are true.
  • D.Only i is true.
Correct Answer: Only iii is true.

Standards of Weights and Measures (Packaged Commodities) Rules,1977 has been introduced under the Standard of weights and measures Act 1976. India has adopted the international standards of weights and measures and now India has revised the standards of weights and measures. There have been certain legislations passes before the act, 1977 was passes and with regards to the said act the standards of weights and measures rules, 1977 was passed.  The main objective here, is to protect the interests of the consumers.

 

A product line is a group of related products under a single brand sold by the same company. Companies sell multiple product lines under their various brands. Companies often expand their offerings by adding to existing product lines, because consumers are more likely to purchase products from brands with which they are already familiar. With passage of time as the companies grow their product line also grows. Hence, Statement II is incorrect.

 

Brand equity refers to a value premium that a company generates from a product with a recognizable name when compared to a generic equivalent. Companies can create brand equity for their products by making them memorable, easily recognizable, and superior in quality and reliability. Brand awareness and brand preference are two dimensions of Brand Equity. Hence, Statement I is wrong as brand equity is not function of these two but are two dimension of brand equity.

 

If you have ever been motivated to take action due to an advertisement, you've likely been influenced by a technique called A.I.D.A, which stands for "Attention, Interest, Desire, Action". This process is used by many marketers in their communications to entice prospects to make a purchase or take a desired action. It is a model for advertising not physical distribution. Hence, Statement IV is incorrect.

Question 85
Match the following. (UGC NET Management Jun2013)List-I (Components of Brand Equity)a. Differentiationb. Esteemc. Relevanced. KnowledgeList-II (Description)A. How familiar and intimate consumers are with the brand.B. The degree to which a brand is seen as different from others.C. How well the brand is regarded and respected.D. The breadth of a brand’s appeal.Codes
  • A.a-A b-B c-C d-D
  • B.a-B b-C c-D d-A
  • C.a-C b-D c-A d-B
  • D.a-D b-C c-B d-A
Correct Answer: a-B b-C c-D d-A

BAV Model Advertising Agency Young and Rubicam (Y&R) developed a model of brand equity called Brand Asset Valuator (BAV). Based on research with almost 200,000 consumers in 40 countries, BAV provides comparative measures of the brand equity of thousands of brands across hundreds of different categories. There are 4 key components of brand equity, according to BAV:

 

Differentiation measures the degree to which a brand is seen as different from others.

Relevance measures the breadth of a brand’s appeal.

Esteem measures how well the brand is regarded and respected.

Knowledge measures how familiar and intimate consumers are with the brand.

Question 86
The Branding Strategy which uses a different brand name for each product is known as:(UGC NET ManagementDec2012)
  • A.Overall Family Branding
  • B.Line Family Branding
  • C.Individual Branding
  • D.Brand Extension
Correct Answer: Individual Branding

Umbrella branding (also known as Family branding) is a marketing practice involving the use of a single brand name for the sale of two or more related products. Umbrella branding is mainly used by companies with a positive brand equity (value of a brand in a certain marketplace). All products use the same means of identification and lack additional brand names or symbols etc. This marketing practice differs from brand extension in that umbrella branding involves the marketing of similar products, rather than differentiated products, under one brand name. Hence, umbrella branding may be considered as a type of brand extension. The practice of umbrella branding does not disallow a firm to implement different branding approaches for different product lines (e.g. brand extension).

 

Individual branding, also called individual product branding, flanker brands or multi-branding, is "a branding strategy in which products are given brand names that are newly created and generally not connected to names of existing brands offered by the company. Each brand, even within a same company, has a unique name, identity and image, allowing the company to target different market segments, tailor pricing and marketing strategies, and separate the image and reputation of different products.

 

In Brand Extensions a company may use its existing brand name to launch new products in other categories. If a car dealer enters into car insurance business, it will be brand extension.

An associated risk is brand dilution, which occurs when consumers no longer associate a brand with a specific product or highly similar products.

 

Family branding is when a company placing the same brand name on all products in a product line, enjoys the distinct advantage of instant recognition, benefitting from the “halo effect” of the brand’s established reputation. A new entry using the family brand name gains instant credibility and visibility from the brand’s established reputation. This leveraging effect has led some firms to enter new fields under the same name – brand franchise extension.

Question 87
Which one of the following can be legally protected? (UGC NET ManagementJun2015)
  • A.Brand name
  • B.Trade Mark
  • C.Brand mark
  • D.Package
Correct Answer: Trade Mark

Indian Trademark law statutorily protects trademarks as per the Trademark Act, 1999 and also under the common law remedy of passing off. Statutory protection of trademark is administered by the Controller General of Patents, Designs and Trade Marks, a government agency which reports to the Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion (DIPP), under the Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

 

The law of trademark deals with the mechanism of registration, protection of trademark and prevention of fraudulent trademark. The law also provides for the rights acquired by registration of trademark, modes of transfer and assignment of the rights, nature of infringements, penalties for such infringement and remedies available to the owner in case of such infringement.

Question 88
The extrinsic properties of the product or service, including the ways in which the brand attempts to meet customers’ psychological or social needs is known as: (UGC NET ManagementJul2023)
  • A.Brand judgments
  • B.Brand resonance
  • C.Brand imagery
  • D.Brand performance
Correct Answer: Brand imagery

The Brand Resonance Model views brand building as an ascending, sequential series of steps, from bottom to top. The steps are as given below:

• Ensuring identification of the brand with customers and an association of the brand in customers’ minds with a specific product class or customer need.

• Establishing the totality of brand meaning in the minds of customers by strategically linking a host of tangible and intangible brand associations.

• Eliciting the proper customer responses in terms of brand-related judgment and feelings.

• Converting brand response to create an intense, active loyalty relationship between customers and the brand.

 

According to this model, enacting the 4 steps involves establishing 6 “brand building blocks” with customers. These brand building blocks can be assembled in terms of a brand pyramid. The model emphasizes the duality of brands—the rational route to brand building is the left-hand side of the pyramid, whereas the emotional route is the right-hand side.

 

1. Brand salience relates to how often and easily the brand is evoked under various purchase or consumption situations.

2. Brand performance relates to how the product or service meets customers’ functional needs.

3. Brand imagery deals with the extrinsic properties of the product or service, including the ways in which the brand attempts to meet customers’ psychological or social needs.

4. Brand judgments focus on customers own personal opinions and evaluations.

5. Brand feelings are customers’ emotional responses and reactions with respect to the brand.

6. Brand resonance refers to the nature of the relationship that customers have with the brand and the extent to which customers feel that they are “in sync” with the brand.

Question 89
Which of the following marketing strategies is/are based on the principle of stimulus generalization?(a) Product line extension(b) Family branding(c) Licensing(d) CounterfeitingCodes
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) and (c)
  • C.(a), (b) and(c)
  • D.(a), (b), (c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (a), (b), (c) and (d)

Stimulus generalization is the explanation as to why many copycat brands looks almost the same as to the competitor but often at a much lower price succeeds in such a cutthroat marketplace. Because they are much cheaper, it is worth the risk in purchasing a product to at least try it especially if it looks and seems identical in the packaging. Marketers use stimulus generalization to devise branding and product strategies. These strategies include family branding, brand extensions, licensing, and look-alike packaging.
