Family branding is the practice of using a company name (or umbrella name) on a set of brands. For example, Heinz puts its name on catsup, canned tomatoes, mustard, pickles, and many other food products. Similarly, Kellogg’s is a family brand for cereals. However, within this family brand, there are recognized individual brand names, such as “Rice Krispies” and “Apple Jacks.”

Brand extension refers to the practice of using an existing brand name to promote new products. The new product may be in the same category as the original brand, or it may be in a very different category.

 

Licensing is lending an established brand name to a new venture. For example, Kellogg’s could license its name to a toy manufacturer, who would then include small facsimiles of Kellogg’s cereals as part of a child’s cooking set.

 

Look-alike packaging means introducing a package that appears to be very similar to existing packages. The hope is that consumers will make an inference that the brand with the similar package will have all of the traits of the original brand, whose package was imitated. For all four of these strategies, (family branding, brand extensions, licensing, and look-alike packaging), the perceptual process of stimulus generalization is crucial.

 

A product line extension strategy is an approach to developing new products for your existing customers or for prospects who do not currently buy from you. Extending a product line involves adding new features to existing products, rather than developing completely new products.

 

Counterfeiting is an illegal activity, involving the manufacturing or distribution of goods under someone else's name, and without their permission. Counterfeit goods are generally made from lower quality components, in an attempt to sell a cheap imitation of similar goods produced by brands consumers know and trust.

Question 90
Statement I: Products are made in factories.Statement II: Brands are made in consumer’s mind.
  • A.Both the statements I and II are incorrect.
  • B.Both the statements I and II are correct.
  • C.Statement I is correct, but II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement II is correct, but I is incorrect.
Correct Answer: Both the statements I and II are correct.

A product’s position is the way the product is defined by consumers on important attributes—the place the product occupies in consumers’ minds relative to competing products. Consumers position products with or without the help of marketers. But marketers do not want to leave their products’ positions to chance. They must plan positions that will give their products the greatest advantage in selected target markets, and they must design marketing mixes to create these planned positions. Hence, it is said that although the products are made in factories, but brand image is first created in consumer’s mind.

Question 91
Not all brand differences are meaningful; not every difference makes a good differentiator. Select the criteria which is applicable in choosing the good differentiator:(i) Distinctive(ii) Affordable(iii) Subjective(iv) Profitable(v) CreativeCodes
  • A.(i) and (ii)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii)
  • C.(i), (ii), (iv)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iv), (v)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iv)

Not all brand differences are meaningful; not every difference makes a good differentiator. Each difference has the potential to create company costs as well as customer benefits. A difference is worth establishing to the extent that it satisfies the following criteria:

 

Important: The difference delivers a highly valued benefit to target buyers.

Distinctive: Competitors do not offer the difference, or the company can offer it in a more distinctive way.

Superior: The difference is superior to other ways that customers might obtain the same benefit.

Communicable: The difference is communicable and visible to buyers.

Pre-emptive: Competitors cannot easily copy the difference.

Affordable: Buyers can afford to pay for the difference.

Profitable: The company can introduce the difference profitably.

Question 92
Consider the following Statements.Statement I:In building brand equity, marketers should be “media neutral”.Statement II:Every brand contact delivers an impression that can strengthen or weaken a customer’s view of a company.Choose the correct option from the following codes.Codes
  • A.Both Statement I and II are correct.
  • B.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct.
  • D.Both Statement I and II are in correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and II are correct.

In building brand equity, marketers should be “media neutral” means a marketer must be open to use any media which helps in achieving the marketing goal. Marketing media must be chosen based on company’s strengths and weaknesses and also effectiveness of a particular media. Therefore, a marketer should evaluate all communication options on effectiveness (how well does it work?) and efficiency (how much does it cost?). Hence, Statement I is correct.

 

Brand contact refers to any information-bearing experience a customer or prospect has with the brand, the product category, or the market that relates to the marketer’s product or service. The product’s styling and price, the shape and colour of the package, the salesperson’s manner and dress, the store décor, the company’s stationery—all communicate something to buyers. In that sense, every brand contact delivers an impression that can strengthen or weaken a customer’s view of a company or can impact companies brand image. Marketing communication activities contribute to brand equity and drive sales in many ways: by creating brand awareness, forging brand image in consumers’ memories, eliciting positive brand judgments or feelings, and strengthening consumer loyalty. Hence, Statement II is correct.

Question 93
The _______________ implies that communicators can use their good image to reduce some negative feelings toward a brand but in the process might lose some esteem with the audience.
  • A.Principle of congruity
  • B.Brand Attitude
  • C.Brand Awareness
  • D.Brand Loss
Correct Answer: Principle of congruity

If a person has a positive attitude toward a source and a message, or a negative attitude toward both, a state of congruity is said to exist. But what happens if a consumer hears a likable celebrity praise a brand she dislikes? Charles Osgood and Percy Tannenbaum believe ‘attitude change will take place in the direction of increasing the amount of congruity between the two evaluations’. The consumer will end up respecting the celebrity somewhat less or the brand somewhat more. If she encounters the same celebrity praising other disliked brands, she will eventually develop a negative view of the celebrity and maintain negative attitudes toward the brands. The principle of congruity implies that communicators can use their good image to reduce some negative feelings toward a brand but in the process might lose some esteem with the audience.

Question 94
Statement I:Luxury branding typically includes the creation of many tangible brand associations and an aspirational image.Statement II:Brand elements besides brand names—logos, symbols, packaging, signage—can be important drivers of brand equity for luxury brands.Select the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct

Luxury Products are perhaps one of the purest examples of branding, because the brand and its image are often key competitive advantages that create enormous value and wealth for organizations. Marketers of luxury products guided the fortunes of luxury brands in a constantly evolving rapidly changing marketing environment. Globalization, new technologies, financial crises, shifting consumer cultures, and other forces necessitate that marketers of luxury brands be skillful and adept at their brand stewardship to succeed.

 

Some of the key guidelines for Marketing Luxury Brands are given below:

(i) Maintaining a premium image for luxury brands is crucial; controlling that image is thus a priority.

(ii) Luxury branding typically includes the creation of many intangible brand associations and an aspirational image.

(iii) All aspects of the marketing program for luxury brands must be aligned to ensure quality products and services and pleasurable purchase and consumption experiences.

(iv) Brand elements besides brand names—logos, symbols, packaging, signage—can be important drivers of brand equity for luxury brands.

(v) Secondary associations from linked personalities, events, countries, and other entities can be important drivers of brand equity for luxury brands.

(vi) Luxury brands must carefully control distribution via a selective channel strategy.

(vii) Luxury brands must employ a premium pricing strategy with strong quality cues and few discounts and markdowns.

(viii) Brand architecture for luxury brands must be managed very carefully.

(ix) Competition for luxury brands must be defined broadly as it often comes from other categories.

(x) Luxury brands must legally protect all trademarks and aggressively combat counterfeits.

Question 95
Which of the following are the type of Co-branding?(i) Same-company co-branding(ii) Joint-venture co-branding(iii) Multiple-sponsor co-branding(iv) Retail Co-branding(v) Wholesaler Co-brandingChoose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii) (iv)
  • C.(i), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)

Marketers often combine their products with products from other companies in various ways. In co-branding (also called dual branding or brand bundling) two or more well-known brands are combined into a joint product or marketed together in some fashion. It can generate greater sales from the existing market and open opportunities for new consumers and channels. It can also reduce the cost of product introduction, because it combines two well-known images and speeds adoption. And co-branding may be a valuable means to learn about consumers and how other companies approach them.

 

Forms of co-branding are given below:

(i) Same-company co-branding: This is when a company with more than one product promotes their own brands simultaneously.

(ii) In Joint-venture co-branding, two or more firms make strategic alliance for target customers such as General Electric and Hitachi lightbulbs in Japan.

(iii) There is multiple-sponsor co-branding, such as Taligent, a one-time technological alliance of Apple, IBM, and Motorola.

(iv) There is retail co-branding in which two retail establishments use the same location to optimize space and profits, such as jointly owned Pizza Hut, KFC, and Taco Bell restaurants.

(v) Ingredient branding is a special case of co-branding which creates brand equity for materials, components, or parts that are necessarily contained within other branded products.

Question 96
________ branding creates brand equity for materials, components, or parts that are necessarily contained within other branded products.
  • A.Spice branding
  • B.Bundle branding
  • C.Co-branding
  • D.Ingredient branding
Correct Answer: Ingredient branding

Ingredient branding is a special case of co-branding which creates brand equity for materials, components, or parts that are necessarily contained within other branded products.

Question 97
Statement I:For a successful ingredient branding, it is required that consumers understand the advantages of a coordinated “pull” and “push” programme.Statement II:For a successful ingredient branding, consumers must be convinced that not all ingredient brands are the same and that the ingredient is superior.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Ingredient branding is a special case of co-branding which creates brand equity for materials, components, or parts that are necessarily contained within other branded products.

 

The requirements for successful ingredient branding are:

(i) Consumers must believe the ingredient matters to the performance and success of the end product. Ideally, this intrinsic value is easily seen or experienced.

(ii) Consumers must be convinced that not all ingredient brands are the same and that the ingredient is superior.

(iii) A distinctive symbol or logo must clearly signal that the host product contains the ingredient. Ideally, this symbol or logo functions like a “seal” and is simple and versatile, credibly communicating quality and confidence.

(iv) A coordinated “pull” and “push” program must help consumers understand the advantages of the branded ingredient. Channel members must offer full support such as consumer advertising and promotions and—sometimes in collaboration with manufacturers—retail merchandising and promotion programs.

Question 98
Match the following.List I (Loyalty Status)(a) Hard-coreloyals(b) Splitloyals(c) Shiftingloyals(d) SwitchersList II (Description)(i) Consumers who shift loyalty from one brand to another(ii) Consumers who are loyal to two or three brands(iii) Consumers who buy only one brand all the time(iv) Consumers who show no loyalty to any brandSelect the correct response using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iv), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)

Loyalty Status - A company can learn a great deal by analyzing degrees of brand loyalty. One caution: What appear to be brand-loyal purchase patterns may reflect habit, indifference, a low price, a high switching cost, or the unavailability of other brands.

Marketers usually envision four groups based on Brand Loyalty Status:

(i) Hard-core loyal: Consumers who buy only one brand all the time.

(ii) Split loyal: Consumers who are loyal to two or three brands.

(iii) Shifting loyal: Consumers who shift loyalty from one brand to another.

(iv) Switchers: Consumers who show no loyalty to any brand

 

A company can learn a great deal by analyzing degrees of brand loyalty: Hard-core loyal can help identify the products’ strengths; split loyal can show the firm which brands are most competitive with its own; and by looking at customers dropping its brand, the company can learn about its marketing weaknesses and attempt to correct them.

Question 99
The term “brand” can be defined as that product or service which has a
  • A.a different name
  • B.a different sign or symbol
  • C.a different design
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

The American Marketing Association defines a brand as “a name, term, sign, symbol, or design, or a combination of them, intended to identify the goods or services of one seller or group of sellers and to differentiate them from those of competitors.” A brand is thus a product or service whose dimensions differentiate it in some way from other products or services designed to satisfy the same need. These differences may be functional, rational, or tangible—related to product performance of the brand. They may also be more symbolic, emotional, or intangible—related to what the brand represents or means in a more abstract sense.

Question 100
Statement I: Consumer’s lives have become more complicated and rushed, thus a brand’s ability to simplify decision-making and reduce risk becomes invaluable.Statement II:Consumers learn and evaluate different brands through experiences with the product and its marketing program to find out which brands satisfy their needs and which do not.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Brands identify the source or maker of a product and allow consumers—either individuals or organizations—to assign responsibility for its performance to a particular manufacturer or distributor. Consumers may evaluate the identical product differently depending on how it is branded. They learn about brands through past experiences with the product and its marketing program, finding out which brands satisfy their needs and which do not. As consumers’ lives become more complicated, rushed, and time-starved, a brand’s ability to simplify decision making and reduce risk becomes invaluable.

 

Therefore, both Statements are correct.

Question 101
Which of the following is NOT a function of brands?
  • A.Brands simplify product handling and tracing
  • B.Brands help to organize inventory and accounting records
  • C.Brands help in better internal communication
  • D.Registered brands makes it safe for the investors to invest in the company
Correct Answer: Brands help in better internal communication

Brands perform various valuable functions for firms. They simplify product handling or tracing and help to organize inventory and accounting records. A brand also offers the firm legal protection for unique features or aspects of the product. For instance, brand name can be protected through registered trademarks; manufacturing processes can be protected through patents; and packaging can be protected through copyrights and proprietary designs. These intellectual property rights ensure that the firm can safely invest in the brand and reap the benefits of a valuable asset.

Question 102
________ provides predictability and security of demand for the firm, and creates barriers to entry that make it difficult for other firms to enter the market.
  • A.Brand Fidelity
  • B.Brand Loyalty
  • C.Brand Duty
  • D.Brand Tie
Correct Answer: Brand Loyalty

A credible brand signals a certain level of quality so that satisfied buyers can easily choose the product again. Brand loyalty provides predictability and security of demand for the firm, and it creates barriers to entry that make it difficult for other firms to enter the market. Loyalty can also translate into customer willingness to pay a higher price—often 20 percent to 25 percent more than competing brands.

Question 103
Endowing a product or a service with the power of a brand is known as
  • A.endowment
  • B.marking
  • C.branding
  • D.tagging
Correct Answer: branding

Branding is endowing products and services with the power of a brand. It’s all about creating differences between products. Branding creates mental structures that help consumers organize their knowledge about products and services in a way that clarifies their decision making and, in the process, provides value to the firm.

 

For branding strategies to be successful and brand value to be created, consumers must be convinced that there are meaningful differences among brands in the product or service category. For example, luxury brands like Gucci and Chanel have become category leaders by understanding consumer motivations and desires and creating relevant and appealing images around their products.

Question 104
Marketers can now apply branding to which of the following categories?(i) a good or service(ii) a store(iii) a person(iv) an organization(v) an ideaChoose the correct option using the codes given below:
  • A.(i) only
  • B.(i), (ii) and (iv) only
  • C.(i), (ii), (iii) and (v) only
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Marketers can apply branding virtually anywhere a consumer has a choice. Given below are the examples of application of branding under various categories:

(i) A physical good: Maruti Suzuki WagonR, or Dr. Ortho medicated oil.

(ii) A service: Vistara Airlines or ICICI Life insurance.

(iii) A store: Decathlon or Shoppers Stop.

(iv) A person: actress Deepika Padukone or tennis player Sania Mirza.

(v) A place: Incredible India!

(vi) An organization: Red Cross or CRY

(vii) An idea: abortion rights or free trade.

Question 105
______ can be reflected in the way consumers think, feel, and act with respect to the brand, as well as in the prices, market share, and profitability the brand commands.
  • A.Brand Equity
  • B.Brand Equality
  • C.Brand Fairness
  • D.Brand Honesty
Correct Answer: Brand Equity

Brand equity is the differential effect that knowing the brand name has on customer response to the product or its marketing. It is the added value endowed on products and services. It may be reflected in the way consumers think, feel, and act with respect to the brand, as well as in the prices, market share, and profitability the brand commands.

Question 106
A perspective used by researchers to study brand equity that helps in identifying the differential effect brand knowledge has on consumer response to the brand marketing is termed as
  • A.Response-to-Branding Approach
  • B.Differential Effect Approach
  • C.Customer-Based Brand Equity Approach
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Customer-Based Brand Equity Approach

Marketers and researchers use various perspectives to study brand equity. Customer-based approaches view it from the perspective of the consumer—either an individual or an organization— and recognize that the power of a brand lies in what customers have seen, read, heard, learned, thought, and felt about the brand over time.

Customer-based brand equity is thus the differential effect brand knowledge has on consumer response to the marketing of that brand.

Brand equity is the differential effect that knowing the brand name has on customer response to the product or its marketing.

Question 107
Which of the following is NOT true regarding a brand’s customer-based brand equity?
  • A.A brand has positive customer-based brand equity when consumers react morefavorablyto a product
  • B.A brand has negative customer-based brand equity when consumers react lessfavorablyto a product
  • C.A brand has indifferent customer-based brand equity when the product is a luxury item.
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: A brand has indifferent customer-based brand equity when the product is a luxury item.

Customer-based brand equity is the differential effect brand knowledge has on consumer response to the marketing of that brand.

 

A brand has positive customer-based brand equity when consumers react more favorably to a product and the way it is marketed when the brand is identified, than when it is not identified. A brand has negative customer-based brand equity if consumers react less favorably to marketing activity for the brand under the same circumstances.

 

There are 3 key ingredients of customer-based brand equity:

(a) Brand equity arises from differences in consumer response. If no differences occur, the brand name product is essentially a commodity, and competition will probably be based on price.

(b) Differences in response are a result of consumers’ brand knowledge which is all the thoughts, feelings, images, experiences, and beliefs consumer associates with the brand. Brands must create strong, favorable, and unique brand associations with customers, as have Maruti Cars (reliability) and Flipkart (convenience).

(c) Brand equity is reflected in perceptions, preferences, and behavior related to all aspects of the marketing of a brand. Stronger brands lead to greater revenue.

Question 108
Which of the following are the marketing advantages of a strong brand?(i) Improved perceptions of product performance(ii) Greater financial market returns(iii) Additional brand extension opportunities(iv) Efficient raw material supply chain(v) Increased marketing communications effectiveness(vi) Motivated workforce in officeSelect the correct response:
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iii), (v)
  • C.(ii), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • D.(ii), (iii), (v), (vi)
Correct Answer: (i), (ii), (iii), (v)

Marketing advantages of strong brands include:

(a) Improved perceptions of product performance.

(b) Greater trade cooperation and support.

(c) Greater loyalty

(d) Increased marketing communications effectiveness.

(e) Less vulnerability to competitive marketing actions.

(f) Possible licensing opportunities.

(g) Less vulnerability to marketing crises.

(h) Additional brand extension opportunities.

(i) Larger margins

(j) Improved employee recruiting and retention.

(i) More inelastic consumer response to price increases.

(j) Greater financial market returns

(k) More elastic consumer response to price decreases.

Question 109
The marketer’s vision of what the brand must be and do for consumers is called as
  • A.brand promise
  • B.brand confidence
  • C.brand security
  • D.brand bond
Correct Answer: brand promise

A brand promise is the marketer’s vision of what the brand must be and do for consumers. Consumers on the basis of what they think and feel about the brand, decide where and how the brand should go and grant permission (or not) to any marketing action or program. New-product ventures such as Pepsi Blue, Frito-Lay Chat Street and Maggie Dal Atta Noodles all failed because consumers found them inappropriate extensions for the brand.

Question 110
Match the following.List I (Components of Brand Equity)(a) Energized Differentiation(b) Relevance(c) Esteem(d) KnowledgeList II (Measurement)(i) brand’s perception of quality and loyalty(ii) brand seen as different from others(iii) consumers’ awareness of brand(iv) brand’s appropriatenessChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(iii)

Advertising agency Young and Rubicam (Y&R) developed a model of brand equity called the BrandAsset® Valuator (BAV). According to this model, there are 4 key components or pillars of brand equity:

 

Energized differentiation measures the degree to which a brand is seen as different from others, and its perceived momentum and leadership.

Relevance measures the appropriateness and breadth of a brand’s appeal.

Esteem measures perceptions of quality and loyalty, or how well the brand is regarded and respected.

Knowledge measures how aware and familiar consumers are with the brand.

 

Energized differentiation and Relevance combine to determine brand strength i.e., a leading indicator that predicts future growth and value. Esteem and knowledge together create brand stature i.e., a “report card” on past performance and a current indicator of current value.

 

Question 111
Which of the following are the 3 factors identified under the BAV analysis that help define energy and the marketplace momentum created by it?
  • A.Vision, Mission and Orientation
  • B.Vision, Company Philosophy and Brand Promise
  • C.Vision, Invention and Dynamism
  • D.Vision, Innovation and Adoptability
Correct Answer: Vision, Invention and Dynamism

The BAV analysis identified 3 factors that help define energy and the marketplace momentum it creates:

(i) Vision: A clear direction and point of view on the world and how it can and should be changed

(ii) Invention: An intention for the product or service to change the way people think, feel, and behave.

(iii) Dynamism: Excitement and affinity in the way the brand is presented

Question 112
The 4 quadrants of the matrix of Brand Asset Valuator Model are
  • A.Niche, Leadership, Unfocused, Eroding
  • B.Close, Dominant, Indistinct, Corroding
  • C.Impulsive, Assertive, Fuzzy, Depleting
  • D.Swift, Insistent, Dim, Rusting
Correct Answer: Niche, Leadership, Unfocused, Eroding

As per the Brand Asset Valuator Model, energized brand strength and brand stature combine to form the power grid, depicting stages in the cycle of brand development in successive quadrants.

 

The 4 types are:

(i) Niche/Momentum: These brands have low brand strength but high potential. They have built some energy and relevance, but are known to only a relatively small audience. Consumers are expressing curiosity and interest.

(ii) Leadership: These brands have become irresistible, combining high brand strength with high brand stature. They have high earnings, high margin power, and the greatest potential to create future value.

(iii) New/Unfocused: These brands, with both low brand stature and low brand strength, are not well known among the general population. Many are new entrants; others are middling brands that have lost their way.

(iv) Eroding/Declining: These brands show why high brand stature by itself is insufficient for maintaining a leading position. They struggle to overcome what consumers already know about and expect from them.

Question 113
Identify among the following Major Brand Strategy Decisions.(i) Positioning(ii) Brand Equity(iii) Brand Name Selection(iv) Brand Sponsorship(v) Brand Value(vi) Brand DevelopmentChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(ii), (iii), (v), (vi)
  • B.(i), (ii), (v), (vi)
  • C.(ii), (iv), (v), (vi)
  • D.(i), (iii), (iv), (vi)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii), (iv), (vi)

Branding poses challenging decisions to the marketer. Major Brand Strategy Decisions involve brand positioning, brand name selection, brand sponsorship and brand development.

 

(a) Brand Positioning: Marketers need to position their brands clearly in target customer's market. They can position it at any of 3 levels. At the lowest level, they can position the brand on product attributes such as quality, selection, style, and innovative features. However, attributes are the least desirable level for brand positioning as can be copied easily by competitors. At second level, a brand can be better positioned by associating its name with a desirable benefit such as Walmart (save money) or Instagram (capturing and sharing moments). At third level, Brands can have positioned on strong values and beliefs engaging customer on a deep, emotional level and eventually generate long-lasting customer loyalty.

 

(b) Brand Name Selection: A good name can add greatly to a product’s success. However, finding the best brand name is a difficult task. It begins with a careful review of the product and its benefits, the target market, and proposed marketing strategies.

 

(c) Brand Sponsorship: A manufacturer has 4 sponsorship options:

(i) The product may be launched as a national brand (or manufacturer’s brand). For example, as when Sony and Kellogg sell their output under their own brand names (Sony Bravia HDTV or Kellogg’s Frosted Flakes).

(ii) Second, the manufacturer may sell resellers who give the product a private brand (also called a store brand or distributor brand). Store brand is a brand created and owned by a reseller of a product or service.

(iii) Most manufacturers take years and spend millions to create their own brand names. However, some companies license names or symbols previously created by other manufacturers, names of well-known celebrities, or characters from popular movies and books.

(iv) Co-branding: The practice of using the established brand names of two different companies on the same product

 

(d) Brand Development: A company has 4 choices when it comes to developing brands. The company can introduce line extensions, brand extensions, multi-brands, or entirely new brands.

(i) A line extension involves extending a current brand name to new forms, colors, sizes, flavors, etc. in one of the company's existing product categories.

(ii) A brand extension extends a current brand name to a new or modified product in a new product category.

(iii) Multi-branding involves introducing several brands within the same category.

(iv) Finally a company may decide that a new brand name is needed, particularly if the power of an existing brand name is declining or the company is entering a new product category.

Question 114
Which of the following is NOT a step of the Brand Resonance Model?
  • A.Ensuring customers identify the brand.
  • B.Establishing the brand meaning in employees’ minds.
  • C.Eliciting the proper customer responses in terms of brand-related judgment.
  • D.Converting customers’ brand response to an intense, active loyalty.
Correct Answer: Establishing the brand meaning in employees’ minds.

The Brand Resonance Model views brand building as an ascending series of steps, from bottom to top as given below:

(i) Ensuring customers identify the brand and associate it with a specific product class or need;

(ii) Firmly establishing the brand meaning in customers’ minds by strategically linking a host of tangible and intangible brand associations;

(iii) Eliciting the proper customer responses in terms of brand-related judgment and feelings; and

(iv) Converting customers’ brand response to an intense, active loyalty.

 

According to this model, enacting the 4 steps means establishing a pyramid of 6 “brand building blocks” (refer image below). It also emphasizes the duality of brands—the rational route to brand building is on the left side of the pyramid and the emotional route is on the right side.

For instance, MasterCard is a brand with duality, because it emphasizes both the rational advantages of the credit card—its acceptance at establishments worldwide—as well as the emotional advantages, expressed in the award-winning “Priceless” advertising campaign (“There are some things money can’t buy; for everything else, there’s MasterCard.”).

Question 115
Match the followingList I(a) Brand Salience(b) Brand Performance(c) Brand Imagery(d) Brand Judgement(e) Brand Feeling(f) Brand ResonanceList II(i) Customers’ own personal opinions and evaluations of brands.(ii) How well the product or service meets customers’ functional needs.(iii) The extent of relationship customers has with the brand.(iv) Customers’ emotional responses and reactions towards a brand.(v) How often and easily customers think of the brand under various purchase situations.(vi) Describes the extrinsic properties of the product or serviceChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv), e-(v), f-(vi)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(vi), d-(iv), e-(i), f-(v)
  • C.a-(v), b-(ii), c-(vi), d-(i), e-(iv), f-(iii)
  • D.a-(v), b-(iii), c-(vi), d-(i), e-(ii), f-(iv)
Correct Answer: a-(v), b-(ii), c-(vi), d-(i), e-(iv), f-(iii)

According to the Brand Resonance Model, creating significant brand equity requires reaching the top of the brand pyramid, which occurs only if the right building blocks are put into place. These building blocks are:

 

(a) Brand Salience is how often and how easily customers think of the brand under various purchase or consumption situations.

(b) Brand Performance is how well the product or service meets customers’ functional needs.

(c) Brand Imagery describes the extrinsic properties of the product or service, including the ways in which the brand attempts to meet customers’ psychological or social needs.

(d) Brand Judgments focus on customers own personal opinions and evaluations.

(e) Brand Feelings are customers’ emotional responses and reactions with respect to the brand.

(f) Brand Resonance describes the relationship customers have with the brand and the extent to which they feel they are “in sync” with it depicting intensity of customers’ psychological bond with the brand and the level of activity it engenders. Brands with high resonance include Harley-Davidson and Apple iPhones.

Question 116
Which of the following is a brand equity driver?
  • A.The initial choices for the brand elements or identities making up the brand
  • B.The product and service and its marketing activities and programs
  • C.Other associations indirectly transferred to the brand by linking it to some other entity
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Marketers build brand equity by creating the right brand knowledge structures with the right consumers. From a marketing management perspective, there are 3 main sets of brand equity drivers:

 

(i) The initial choices for the brand elements or identities making up the brand (brand names, URLs, logos, symbols, characters, spokespeople, slogans, jingles, packages, and signage) — For example, Surf Excel chose the slogan “daag achey hai” (stains are good) for its detergent powder because it felt it unambiguously conveyed do not be afraid of getting your clothes dirty, just do the right thing and Surf Excel will take care of the dirt stains.

 

(ii) The product and service and all accompanying marketing activities and supporting marketing programs — For example, Indian fashion designer, Anita Dongre has developed one of India's most commercially viable designer brands like AND and Global Desi. Positioned as an affordable luxury, the brand creates its exclusive cachet via limited distribution and a somewhat risqué name and rebellious attitude.

 

(iii) Other associations indirectly transferred to the brand by linking it to some other entity (a person, place, or thing) — The Indian beer brand Bira 91 refers to how a Punjabi would call his brother “bira” and “91” is India’s country code.

Question 117
_______ are devices, which can be trademarked, that identify and differentiate the brand.
  • A.Brand Matter
  • B.Brand Elements
  • C.Brand Components
  • D.Brand Factor
Correct Answer: Brand Elements

Brand elements are devices, which can be trademarked, that identify and differentiate the brand. Most strong brands employ multiple brand elements. For instance, Nike has the distinctive “swoosh” logo, the empowering “Just Do It” slogan, and the “Nike” name from the Greek winged goddess of victory. Marketers should choose brand elements to build as much brand equity as possible. The test is what consumers would think or feel about the product if the brand element were all they knew.

Question 118
Which of the following is NOT a criterion for choosing brand elements?
  • A.Memorability
  • B.Likability
  • C.Adaptability
  • D.Functionality
Correct Answer: Functionality

Brand elements are devices, which can be trademarked, that identify and differentiate the brand. There are 6 criteria for choosing brand elements:

(i) Memorable — How easily do consumers recall and recognize the brand element, and when—at both purchase and consumption? Short names such as Tide, Amul and Ola are memorable brand elements.

(ii) Meaningful — Is the brand element credible? Does it suggest the corresponding category and a product ingredient or the type of person who might use the brand? Consider the inherent meaning in names such as Real fruit juices

(iii) Likable — How aesthetically appealing is the brand element? A recent trend is for playful names like Flickr photo sharing, and Motorola’s RAZR cell phones.

(iv) Transferable — Can the brand element introduce new products in the same or different categories? Does it add to brand equity across geographic boundaries and market segments? Although initially an online book seller, Amazon.com was smart enough not to call itself “Books ‘R’ Us.” The Amazon is famous as the world’s biggest river, and the name suggests the wide variety of goods that Amazon sells.

(v) Adaptable — How adaptable and updatable is the brand element? Since 1998, Google’s logo has changed so many times, yet the colors in the logo have never changed.

(vi) Protectable — How legally protectable is the brand element? How competitively protectable? Names that become synonymous with product categories—such as Bisleri, Xerox, Sellotape, Cosco, Scooty — should retain their trademark rights and not become generic.

 

The first 3—memorable, meaningful, and likable—are “brand building” and the latter 3—transferable, adaptable, and protectable—are “defensive” and help leverage and preserve brand equity against challenges.

Question 119
Assertion “A”:Brand elements should be easy to recall and inherently descriptive and persuasive.Reason “R”:If a consumer is not examining much information in making product decisions then brand elements help in quick decision-making.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are true and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is true but R is false
  • D.A is false but R is true
Correct Answer: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A

Brand elements can play a number of brand-building roles. They should be easy to recall and inherently descriptive and persuasive. If consumers don’t examine much information in making product decisions, brand elements should be easy to recall and inherently descriptive and persuasive. The likability of brand elements may also increase awareness and associations. The Michelin tyre’s friendly tyre-shaped boy helps to convey safety for the family.

Question 120
A ________ is any information-bearing experience, whether positive or negative, a customer or prospect has with the brand, its product category, or its market.
  • A.Brand touch
  • B.Brand influence
  • C.Brand contact
  • D.Brand unity
Correct Answer: Brand contact

A brand contact is any information-bearing experience, whether positive or negative, a customer or prospect has with the brand, its product category, or its market. Brands are not built by advertising alone but customers come to know a brand through a range of contacts and touch points: personal observation and use, word of mouth, interactions with company personnel, online or telephone experiences, and payment transactions. The company must put as much effort into managing these experiences as into producing its ads.

 

Marketers are creating brand contacts and building brand equity through new avenues such as clubs and consumer communities, trade shows, event marketing, sponsorship, factory visits, public relations and press releases, and social cause marketing. For instance, Airtel hosts Great Delhi Marathon every year in which athletes from not just Delhi, but also from other parts of the country as well as other countries take part.

Question 121
Which of the following is a secondary source of brand knowledge?
  • A.Endorsers
  • B.Channels
  • C.Alliances
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

One way to build brand equity is, to create it by linking the brand to other information in memory that conveys meaning to consumers. These “secondary” brand associations can link the brand to sources, such as the company itself (through branding strategies), to countries or other geographical regions (through identification of product origin), and to channels of distribution (through channel strategy), as well as to other brands (through ingredient or co-branding), characters (through licensing), spokespeople (through endorsements), sporting or cultural events (through sponsorship), or some other third party sources (through awards or reviews).

Question 122
Internal branding consists of activities and processes that helps to inform and inspire
  • A.Vendors
  • B.Endorsers
  • C.Employees
  • D.Suppliers
Correct Answer: Employees

Internal branding consists of activities and processes that helps to inform and inspire employees about brands Marketers must adopt an internal perspective to be sure employees and marketing partners appreciate and understand basic branding notions and how they can help or hurt brand equity. When employees care about and believe in the brand, they are motivated to work harder and feel greater loyalty to the firm.

 

Some important principles for internal branding are:

(a) Choose the right moment: Turning points are ideal opportunities to capture employees’ attention and imagination.

(b) Link internal and external marketing: Internal and external messages must be matched with each other.

(c) Bring the brand alive for employees: Internal communications should be informative and energizing.

Question 123
A specialized community of consumers and employees whose identification and activities focus around the brand is known as
  • A.Product community
  • B.Brand community
  • C.Shield community
  • D.Badge community
Correct Answer: Brand community

A brand community is a specialized community of consumers and employees whose identification and activities focus around the brand. Brand communities come in many different forms. Some arise organically from brand users like Maruti Suzuki Nexa Cars owner's club. Others are company-sponsored and facilitated, such as TVS Apache Owners Group.

 

Companies are nowadays interested in collaborating with consumers to create value through communities built around brands. A strong brand community results in a more loyal, committed customer base. Its activities and advocacy can substitute to some degree for activities the firm would otherwise have to engage in, creating greater marketing effectiveness and efficiency. A brand community can also be a constant source of inspiration and feedback for product improvements or innovations.

Question 124
Which of the following is NOT a characteristic to identify brand communities?
  • A.Sense of felt connection to the brand by members
  • B.Shared rituals, stories, and traditions of members
  • C.Shared expenses to promote brand by members
  • D.Shared moral responsibility or duty of members
Correct Answer: Shared expenses to promote brand by members

A brand community is a specialized community of consumers and employees whose identification and activities focus around the brand.

 

Given below are the 3 characteristics to identify brand communities:

(i) A “consciousness of kind” or sense of felt connection to the brand, company, product, or other community members.

(ii) Shared rituals, stories, and traditions that help to convey the meaning of the community.

(iii) A shared moral responsibility or duty to both the community as a whole and individual community member.

Question 125
Statement I: Brand Community is a marketing strategy.Statement II: Brand Communities are inherently political and this reality must be confronted with honesty and authenticity.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Statement I is false and Statement II is true

Building a positive, productive brand community requires careful thought and implementation. Branding experts Susan Fournier and Lara Lee have identified 7 common myths about brand communities and suggest the reality in each case:

 

As identified above, Brand community is not a marketing strategy but a business strategy. Therefore, Statement I is false. Also, Brand Communities are inherently political and this reality must be confronted with honesty and authenticity. Therefore, Statement II is true.

Question 126
Which of the following is NOT a brand value creation practice?
  • A.Articulating thebehavioralexpectations within the brand community
  • B.Lending emotional and/or physical support to the brand if the company goes under court-room trials.
  • C.Recognizing variance within the brand community membership and marking intra-group distinction and similarity
  • D.Cleaning, caring for, and maintaining the brand or systematizing optimal use patterns
Correct Answer: Lending emotional and/or physical support to the brand if the company goes under court-room trials.

The Brand Value Chain is a structured approach to assessing the sources and outcomes of brand equity and the way marketing activities create brand value.

 

According to market researchers, there are 12 brand value creation practices divided into 4 categories – social networking, community engagement, impression management, and brand use as summarized in table below:

Question 127
Statement I: Direct approach measures brand equity by assessing potential sources of brand equity by identifying and tracking consumer brand knowledge structures.Statement II: Indirect approach measures brand equity by assessing the actual impact of brand knowledge on consumer response to different aspects of the marketing.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Both the statements are false

Brand equity refers to a value premium that a company generates from a product with a recognizable name when compared to a generic equivalent. Companies can create brand equity for their products by making them memorable, easily recognizable, and superior in quality and reliability. It can be measured either through indirect approach or direct approach.

 

An indirect approach assesses potential sources of brand equity by identifying and tracking consumer brand knowledge structures.

A direct approach assesses the actual impact of brand knowledge on consumer response to different aspects of the marketing.

 

The 2 general approaches are complementary, and marketers can employ both. In other words, for brand equity to perform a useful strategic function and guide marketing decisions, marketers need to fully understand:

(a) The sources of brand equity and how they affect outcomes of interest, and

(b) How these sources and outcomes change, if at all, over time.

Question 128
Arrange the following Brand Value Chain stages in correct order.(i) Customer mind-set(ii). Shareholder value(iii) Marketing program investment(iv) Brand performanceChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
  • B.(iii), (i), (iv), (ii)
  • C.(iii), (ii), (iv), (i)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iv), (i)
Correct Answer: (iii), (i), (iv), (ii)

The Brand Value Chain is a structured approach to assessing the sources and outcomes of brand equity and the way marketing activities create brand value. It has 4 stages.

 

Stage 1: Marketing Program Investment: brand value creation begins when the firm targets actual or potential customers by investing in a marketing program to develop the brand, including product research, development, and design; trade or intermediary support; and marketing communications.

Stage 2: Customers’ Mind-Set: Firms assume customers’ mind-sets, buying behavior, and response to price as a result of the marketing program.

Stage 3: Brand Performance - It means how customers react or respond in the marketplace to the brand which is manifested in market performance data, such as: market share, sales, sales growth, market penetration, (actual) price premium or share-of wallet.

Stage 4: Shareholder Value – Finally, market performance, replacement cost, and purchase price in acquisitions is considered in order to assess shareholder value in general and the value of a brand in particular.

 

Question 129
Match the followingList I (Multipliers of Brand Value Chain)(a) Program Multiplier(b) Customer Multiplier(c) Market MultiplierList II (Description)(i) Determines the extent to which the value shown by the market performance of a brand is embodied in shareholder value.(ii) Determines the marketing program’s ability to affect the customer mind-set.(iii) Determines the extent to which value created in customers’ mind affects market performance.Choose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(iii), c-(i)

The Brand Value Chain is a structured approach to assessing the sources and outcomes of brand equity and the way marketing activities create brand value. It assumes three multipliers that determines the transfer between the marketing program and the subsequent three value stages.

(a) Program Multiplier: It determines the marketing program’s ability to affect the customer mind-set and is a function of the quality of the program investment.

(b) Customer Multiplier: It determines the extent to which value created in the minds of customers affects market performance. This result depends on competitive superiority, channel and other intermediary support and customer size and profile.

(c) Market Multiplier: It determines the extent to which the value shown by the market performance of a brand is manifested in shareholder value and depends, in part, on the actions of financial analysts and investors.

Question 130
Which of the following processes is a consumer-focused series of procedures to assess the health of the brand, uncover its sources of brand equity, and suggest ways to improve and leverage its equity?
  • A.Brand-tracking studies
  • B.Brand valuation
  • C.Brand audit
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Brand audit

Brand Audit: It is a consumer-focused series of procedures to assess the health of the brand, uncover its sources of brand equity, and suggest ways to improve and leverage its equity. Marketers should conduct a brand audit when setting up marketing plans and when considering shifts in strategic direction. Brand audits are important to understand the sources of brand equity and how they affect outcomes of interest.

 

Brand-tracking studies – it collects quantitative data from consumers over time to provide consistent, baseline information about how brands and marketing programs are performing. Tracking studies help us understand where, how much, and in what ways brand value is being created, to facilitate day-to-day decision making.

 

Brand Valuation – It is the job of estimating the total financial value of the brand.

Question 131
Top brand-management firm Interbrand has developed a model to formally estimate the dollar value of a brand. Arrange the following steps involved in Interbrand Brand Valuation Method, in correct order.(i) Financial analysis(ii) Brand strength(iii) Market segmentation(iv) Brand Value Calculation(v) Role of brandingChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv), (v)
  • B.(iii), (v), (ii), (i), (iv)
  • C.(iii), (i), (v), (ii), (iv)
  • D.(i), (iii), (v), (iv), (ii)
Correct Answer: (iii), (i), (v), (ii), (iv)

Top brand-management firm Interbrand has developed a model to formally estimate the dollar value of a brand. It defines Brand Value as the “net present value of the future earnings that can be attributed to the brand alone”.

 

The firm believes marketing and financial analyses are equally important in determining the value of a brand. Its process follows 5 steps:

(a) Market Segmentation: First step is to divide the market(s) in which the brand is sold into mutually exclusive segments that helps determine variances in the brand’s different customer groups.

(b) Financial Analysis: Interbrand assess purchase price, volume, and frequency to help calculate accurate forecasts of future brand sales and revenues. Once it has established Brand Revenues, it deducts all associated operating costs to derive earnings before interest and tax (EBIT). It also deducts the appropriate taxes and a charge for the capital employed to operate the underlying business, leaving Economic Earnings, that is, the earnings attributed to the branded business.

(c) Role of Branding: Interbrand next attributes a proportion of Economic Earnings to the brand in each market segment, by first identifying the various drivers of demand, then determining the degree to which the brand directly influences each. The Role of Branding assessment is based on market research, client workshops, and interviews and represents the percentage of Economic Earnings the brand generates. Multiplying the Role of Branding by Economic Earnings yields Brand Earnings.

(d) Brand Strength: Interbrand then assess the brand’s strength profile to determine the likelihood that the brand will realize forecasted Brand Earnings. This step relies on competitive benchmarking and a structured evaluation of the brand’s clarity, commitment, protection, responsiveness, authenticity, relevance, differentiation, consistency, presence, and understanding. For each segment, Interbrand applies industry and brand equity metrics to determine a risk premium for the brand. The company’s analysts derive the overall Brand Discount Rate by adding a brand-risk premium to the risk-free rate, represented by the yield on government bonds. The Brand Discount Rate, applied to the forecasted Brand Earnings forecast, yields the net present value of the Brand Earnings. The stronger the brand, the lower the discount rate, and vice versa.

(e) Brand Value Calculation: Brand Value is the net present value (NPV) of the forecasted Brand Earnings, discounted by the Brand Discount Rate. The NPV calculation comprises both the forecast period and the period beyond, reflecting the ability of brands to continue generating future earnings.

Question 132
Statement I:Marketers can reinforce brand equity by consistently conveying the brand’s meaning in terms of what products it represents and its core benefits.Statement II:Reinforcing brand equity requires that the brand always be moving back and forth with new as well as old offerings and ways to market them.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Statement I is true and Statement II is false

Marketers can reinforce brand equity by consistently conveying the brand’s meaning in terms of:

(a) What products it represents, what core benefits it supplies, and what needs it satisfies; and,

(b) How the brand makes products superior, and which strong, favorable, and unique brand associations should exist in consumers’ minds.

For instance, NIVEA has expanded from a skin cream brand to a skin care and personal care brand through carefully designed and implemented brand extensions that reinforce the brand promise of “mild,” “gentle,” and “caring.

 

Reinforcing brand equity requires that the brand always be moving forward, in the right direction and with new and compelling offerings and ways to market them. In virtually every product category, once-prominent and admired brands such as Kodak, Nokia, Nestle Maggie, HMT Watches, have fallen on hard times or gone out of business. At some point, failure to reinforce the brand will diminish brand awareness and weaken brand image.

 

Therefore, Statement I is true and Statement II is false.

Question 133
Statement I: When revitalizing a brand, it is important to forget what happened in the past and start afresh with new sources of brand equity.Statement II: A “back-to-basics” strategy can be used to revitalize a brand if the actual marketing program turns out to be the source of the problem.Select the correct option:
  • A.Statement I is true and Statement II is false
  • B.Statement I is false and Statement II is true
  • C.Both the statements are true
  • D.Both the statements are false
Correct Answer: Statement I is false and Statement II is true

The first thing to do in revitalizing a brand is to identifying the sources of brand equity to begin with. Are positive associations losing their strength or uniqueness? Have negative associations become linked to the brand? Then decide whether to retain the same positioning or create a new one.

Sometimes the actual marketing program is the source of the problem, because it fails to deliver on the brand promise. Then a “back to basics” strategy may make sense and it is not advisable to forget what happened in the past and start afresh with new sources of brand equity.

Therefore, Statement I is false and Statement II is true.

 

However, in some cases, the old positioning is just no longer viable and a reinvention strategy is necessary.

There is a continuum of revitalization strategies, with pure “back to basics” at one end, pure “reinvention” at the other, and many combinations in between. The challenge is often to change enough to attract some new customers but not enough to alienate old customers.

Question 134
A firm’s branding strategy, often called the ______, reflects the number and nature of both common and distinctive brand elements.
  • A.Brand design
  • B.Brand plan
  • C.Brand monument
  • D.Brand architecture
Correct Answer: Brand architecture

A firm’s branding strategy often called the Brand Architecture, reflects the number and nature of both common and distinctive brand elements. Deciding branding strategy for new products is especially critical. A firm has 3 main choices:

(a) It can develop new brand elements for the new product.

(b) It can apply some of its existing brand elements.

(c) It can use a combination of new and existing brand elements.

 

Branding Strategy is the number and nature of common and distinctive brand elements applied to the different products sold by the firm.

Question 135
Match the following.List I (Branding Strategies)(a) Brand extension(b) Line extension(c) Category extension(d) Brand lineList II (Description)(i) covering a new product within a product category it currently serves(ii) all products sold under a particular brand(iii) using established brand to introduce a new product(iv) using the parent brand to enter a different product categoryChoose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)
  • B.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iv), c-(ii), d-(iii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)

Brand Extension is when a firm uses an established brand to introduce a new product. For example, Emami, which makes personal care products has extended into edible oils. When marketers combine a new brand with an existing brand, the brand extension can also be called a sub-brand. The existing brand that gives birth to a brand extension or sub-brand is the parent brand. If the parent brand is already associated with multiple products through brand extensions, it can also be called a master brand or family brand.

 

In a Line Extension, the parent brand covers a new product within a product category it currently serves, such as with new flavors, forms, colors, ingredients, and package sizes. For example, Kurkure has introduced several types of flavours through the years.

 

In a Category Extension, marketers use the parent brand to enter a different product category, such as Kingfisher Airlines and Kingfisher Beer.

 

A Brand Line consists of all products—original as well as line and category extensions—sold under a particular brand. For example, Unilever products, P&G products.

 

Branded Variants are specific brand lines supplied to specific retailers or distribution channels. They result from the pressure retailers put on manufacturers to provide distinctive offerings.

 

Parent Brand is the existing brand that gives birth to a brand extension or sub-brand. For example, Nestle, Unilever, P&G

 

If the parent brand is already associated with multiple products through brand extensions, it can also be called a master brand or family brand.

 

A brand mix (or brand assortment) is the set of all brand lines that a particular seller makes. For example, ITC cigarettes, ITC Atta, ITC biscuits.

 

A Licensed Product is one whose brand name has been licensed to other manufacturers that actually make the product.

Question 136
Match the following:List I(a) Brand variant(b) Parent brand(c) Family brand(d) Brand mixList II(i) existing brand that gives birth to a brand extension or sub-brand(ii) specific brand lines supplied to specific retailers or distribution channels(iii) brand associated with multiple products through brand extensions(iv) the set of all brand lines that a particular seller makesSelect the correct option:Codes
  • A.a-(i), b-(ii), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • B.a-(iv), b-(ii), c-(i), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(iv)

Branded Variants are specific brand lines supplied to specific retailers or distribution channels. They result from the pressure retailers put on manufacturers to provide distinctive offerings.

 

Parent Brand is the existing brand that gives birth to a brand extension or sub-brand. For example, Nestle, Unilever, P&G

 

If the parent brand is already associated with multiple products through brand extensions, it can also be called a master brand or family brand.

 

A brand mix (or brand assortment) is the set of all brand lines that a particular seller makes. For example, ITC cigarettes, ITC Atta, ITC biscuits.

 

Brand Extension is when a firm uses an established brand to introduce a new product. For example, Emami, which makes personal care products has extended into edible oils. When marketers combine a new brand with an existing brand, the brand extension can also be called a sub-brand. The existing brand that gives birth to a brand extension or sub-brand is the parent brand. If the parent brand is already associated with multiple products through brand extensions, it can also be called a master brand or family brand.

 

In Line Extension, the parent brand covers a new product within a product category it currently serves, such as with new flavors, forms, colors, ingredients, and package sizes. For example, Kurkure has introduced several types of flavours through the years.

 

In a Category Extension, marketers use the parent brand to enter a different product category, such as Kingfisher Airlines and Kingfisher Beer.

 

A Brand Line consists of all products—original as well as line and category extensions—sold under a particular brand. For example, Unilever products, P&G products.

Question 137
Which of the following is NOT an alternate branding strategy?
  • A.Using individual or separate family brand names.
  • B.Using brand variant names.
  • C.Using corporate umbrella or company brand name.
  • D.Using sub-brand names.
Correct Answer: Using brand variant names.

Branding is endowing products and services with the power of a brand. It is a strong force and hardly anything goes unbranded these days. Assuming a firm decides to brand its products or services, it must choose which brand names to use.

 

3 general strategies are popular:

(i) Individual or separate family brand names - Consumer packaged-goods companies have a long tradition of branding different products by different names. If a company produces quite different products, one blanket name is often not desirable. For example, ITC largely uses individual brand names, such as Sunfeast, Aashirvad, Candyman. A major advantage of individual or separate family brand names is that if a product fails or appears to be of low quality, the company has not tied its reputation to it. Companies also often use different brand names for different quality lines within the same product class.

 

(ii) Corporate umbrella or company brand name - Many firms, such as Patanjali use their corporate brand as an umbrella brand across their entire range of products. Development costs are lower with umbrella names because there’s no need to run “name” research or spend heavily on advertising to create recognition.

 

(iii) Sub-brand name - Sub-brands combine two or more of the corporate brand, family brand, or individual product brand names. Kellogg employs a sub-brand or hybrid branding strategy by combining the corporate brand with individual product brands as with Kellogg’s Rice Krispies, Kellogg’s Raisin Bran, and Kellogg’s Corn Flakes. Many durable-goods makers such as Honda, Sony, and Hewlett-Packard use sub-brands for their products. The corporate or company name legitimizes, and the individual name individualizes, the new product.

Question 138
The use of individual or separate family brand names has been referred to as a ________ strategy, whereas the use of an umbrella corporate or company brand name has been referred to as a ________ strategy.
  • A.House of brands; Branded house
  • B.Branded house; House of brands
  • C.Room of brands; Brand room
  • D.Brand room; Room of brands
Correct Answer: House of brands; Branded house

The use of individual or separate family brand names has been referred to as a “House of Brands” strategy, whereas the use of an umbrella corporate or company brand name has been referred to as a “Branded House” strategy. These 2 branding strategies represent 2 ends of a brand relationship continuum. A sub-brand strategy falls somewhere between, depending on which component of the sub-brand receives more emphasis.

Quiz Attempt #119619

Total Questions: 8
Question 1
Which one of the following structures of the marketing department will be most suitable for companies that produce many products for many markets?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)
  • A.Geographic Organization
  • B.Product or Brand Organization
  • C.Functional Organization
  • D.Matrix Organization
Correct Answer: Matrix Organization

When a company produces many products for many markets, it requires a flexible and multidimensional organizational structure that can efficiently manage both product lines and market segments.

 

 

(A) Geographic Organization ❌ (Incorrect)

This structure is based on regional divisions, useful for companies operating in different geographical locations but not necessarily managing multiple products.

 

(B) Product or Brand Organization ❌ (Incorrect)

This structure is suitable for companies with diverse product lines, but it does not effectively address the complexity of serving multiple markets.

 

(C) Functional Organization ❌ (Incorrect)

This structure is based on specialized functions (e.g., sales, advertising, product development) and is more suitable for companies with fewer products.

 

(D) Matrix Organization ✅ (Correct)

Matrix structure is the best for companies producing many products for many markets because it integrates product management with regional or market-based strategies.

It allows dual reporting where employees report to both product managers and market (geographic or customer segment) managers.

Question 2
Match the following.List I (Organization Types)(a) Functional(b) Geographic(c) Product(d) Market ManagementList II (association)(i) Hub-and-spoke System(ii) Distinct buying preference of customers(iii) Advertising and Sales Promotion Manager(iv) Regional Sales ManagerCodes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(ii) b-(iii) c-(i) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

Modern Marketing Departments can be organized in a number of different, sometimes overlapping ways: functionally, geographically, by product or brand, by market, or in a matrix.

 

Functional Organizations: In the most common form of marketing organization, functional specialists report to a marketing Vice President who coordinates their activities. Functional specialists include Marketing administration manager, Advertising and sales promotion manager, Sales manager, Marketing research manager, New-products manager or Customer service manager. The main advantage of a functional marketing organization is its administrative simplicity. However, it can be quite a challenge for the department to develop smooth working relationships. This form also can result in inadequate planning as the number of products and markets increases and each functional group vies for budget and status.

 

Geographic Organization: A company selling in a national market often organizes its sales force (and sometimes marketing) along geographic lines. For instance, the National Sales Manager may supervise 4 Regional Sales Managers, who each supervise 6 Zone Managers, who in turn supervise 8 District Sales Managers, who each supervise 10 salespeople. Some companies are also adding area market specialists (regional or local marketing managers) to support sales efforts in high-volume markets.

 

Product or Brand Management Organizations: Companies producing a variety of products and brands often establish a product- (or brand-) management organization. A group product manager supervises product category managers, who in turn supervise specific product and brand managers. A product-management organization makes sense if the company’s products are quite different or there are more than a functional organization can handle. This form is sometimes characterized as a hub-and-spoke system.

Hub-and-spoke System: Product-management organization where brand or product manager is figuratively at the center, with spokes leading to various departments representing working relationships. (See the figure below)

 

Market Management Organization: When customers fall into different user groups with distinct buying preferences and practices, a market-management organization is desirable. Market managers are staff (not line) people, with duties like those of product managers. They develop long-range and annual plans for their markets and are judged by their market’s growth and profitability. Because this system organizes marketing activity to meet the needs of distinct customer groups, it shares many advantages and disadvantages of product-management system.

 

Matrix Management Organization: Companies that produce many products for many markets may adopt a matrix organization employing both product and market managers. The rub is that it’s costly and often creates conflicts. There’s the cost of supporting all the managers, and questions about where authority and responsibility for marketing activities should reside (at headquarters or in the division).

 

Hub-and-spoke Systems

Question 3
Which of the following is NOT an alternative in Product or Brand Management Organization?
  • A.Product teams
  • B.Category Management
  • C.Market centered organization
  • D.Brand asset Management Team
Correct Answer: Market centered organization

The Product-Management Organization lets the product manager concentrate on developing a cost-effective marketing program and react more quickly to new products in the marketplace; it also gives the company’s smaller brands a product advocate. However, it has disadvantages too:

(a) Product and brand managers may lack authority to carry out their responsibilities.

(b) They become experts in their product area but rarely achieve functional expertise.

(c) The system often proves costly. One person is appointed to manage each major product or brand, and soon more are appointed to manage even minor products and brands.

(d) The fragmentation of markets makes it harder to develop a national strategy. Brand managers must please regional and local sales groups, transferring power from marketing to sales.

(e) Product and brand managers focus the company on building market share rather than customer relationships.

 

Market centered organization is a type of Market Management Organization.

Few of the alternatives in a Product Management Organizations:

(i) An alternative in a product-management organization is product teams. There are 3 types: vertical, triangular, and horizontal (see given figure). The triangular and horizontal product-team approaches let each major brand be run by a brand-asset management team (BAMT) consisting of key representatives from functions that affect the brand’s performance. The company consists of several BAMTs that periodically report to a BAMT director’s committee, which itself reports to a chief branding officer. This is quite different from the way brands have traditionally been handled.

(ii) A second alternative is to eliminate product manager positions for minor products and assign two or more products to each remaining manager. This is feasible where two or more products appeal to a similar set of needs. For instance, a cosmetics company doesn’t need product managers for each product because cosmetics serve one major need—beauty. A toiletries company needs different managers for headache remedies, toothpaste, soap, and shampoo because these products differ in use and appeal.

(iii) In a third alternative, category management, a company focuses on product categories to manage its brands. For example, Procter & Gamble, a pioneer of the brand-management system, and other top packaged-goods firms have made a major shift to category management, as have firms outside the grocery channel. P&G cites a number of advantages. By fostering internal competition among brand managers, the traditional brand-management system created strong incentives to excel, but also internal competition for resources and a lack of coordination.

Question 4
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Market-centered organizations are the companies that are organized along market lines.Statement II:Xerox converted from geographic selling to selling by industry is an example of Market-centered organizations.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Market-Centered Organizations, a form of Market Management Organization, are the companies that are organized along market lines. For example, Xerox converted from geographic selling to selling by industry. This is an example of market centered organizations as Xerox has re-organized itself into selling by industry which in other words refer market lines.

 

Other form of Market Management Organization is a Customer-Management Organization which deals with individual customers rather than the mass market or even market segments. When a close relationship is advantageous, such as when customers have diverse and complex requirements and buy an integrated bundle of products and services, a customer-management organization should prevail. One study showed that companies organized by customer groups reported much higher accountability for the overall quality of relationships and employees’ freedom to take actions to satisfy individual customer.

 

Market-Management Organization: When customers fall into different user groups with distinct buying preferences and practices, a market-management organization is desirable. Market managers supervise several market-development managers, market specialists, or industry specialists and draw on functional services as needed.

Question 5
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Many companies now focus on departments rather than key processes.Statement II:Departments define company problems and goals from their viewpoint, so conflicts of interest and communications problems are unavoidable.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct

Marketing Relationship with Other Departments

Under the marketing concept, all departments need to “think customer” and work together to satisfy customer needs and expectations. Yet departments define company problems and goals from their viewpoint, so conflicts of interest and communications problems are unavoidable.
