Match the items of List - I with those of List - II: (UGC NET Management Dec 2015)List - I(a) Customer Penetration(b) Customer Loyalty(c) Customer Selectivity(d) Price SelectivityList - II(i) Purchases from the company by its customers expressed as a percentage of their total purchases from all suppliers of the same products.(ii) The average price charged by the company expressed as a percentage of the average price charged by all companies.(iii) Percentage of all customers who buy from the company.(iv) Size of the average customer purchase from the company expressed as a percentage of the size of the average customer purchase from an average company.Codes:
  • A.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii

The correct answer is (C) a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii.

 

(a) Customer Penetration - (iii) Percentage of all customers who buy from the company.

Customer penetration refers to the percentage of all potential customers who actually make purchases from the company. It measures how effectively a company is able to attract customers compared to the total pool of potential customers.

 

(b) Customer Loyalty - (i) Purchases from the company by its customers expressed as a percentage of their total purchases from all suppliers of the same products.

Customer loyalty represents the extent to which customers consistently choose a particular company's products or services over those of its competitors. It is measured by the percentage of a customer's total purchases within a category that are made from a specific company.

 

(c) Customer Selectivity - (iv) Size of the average customer purchase from the company expressed as a percentage of the size of the average customer purchase from an average company.

Customer selectivity measures the average size of a customer's purchase from the company compared to the average purchase size from a typical or average company within the same industry.

 

(d) Price Selectivity - (ii) The average price charged by the company expressed as a percentage of the average price charged by all companies.

Price selectivity indicates how a company's pricing strategy compares to the average pricing within the industry. It measures the average price charged by the company as a percentage of the average price charged by all companies in the same market.

Quiz Attempt #119621

Total Questions: 42
Question 1
Which one of the following is NOT an issue (to be tackled) of conceptual component of a CRM programme?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2024)
  • A.Choosing the technology
  • B.Setting out the objectives in clear terms
  • C.Processing all customer requests coming in through multiple channels
  • D.Putting customers first
Correct Answer: Processing all customer requests coming in through multiple channels

The conceptual component of a Customer Relationship Management (CRM) program primarily deals with strategic aspects, such as setting objectives, aligning customer-centric strategies, and choosing the right technology to support the program. Processing customer requests through various channels is more of an operational issue rather than a conceptual one. The conceptual focus is on designing the overall CRM framework rather than handling day-to-day customer service processes.

Question 2
Which of the following models identifies the strategy development process, the value creation process, multi-channel integration process, performance assessment process and the information management process as its core processes?(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)
  • A.The IDIC Model
  • B.The CRM value chain
  • C.Payne & Frow's Model of CRM
  • D.The SCHEMA Model
Correct Answer: Payne & Frow's Model of CRM

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Payne & Frow’s 5 Processes Model helps to improve Customer Relationship Management (CRM) which makes acquisition and retention of customers a priority. It includes processes that can help to build and maintain relationships with customers. The model was established by Adrian Payne and Pennie Frow in 2005 to identify and assess processes relevant to CRM.

 

The model discusses the relevance of various processes, namely:

(i) Strategy Development Process

(ii) Value Creation Process

(iii) Multichannel Integration Process

(iv) Performance Assessment Process, and

(v) Information Management or Analytical Process in CRM.

 

Each of the above is a cross-sectional, process-oriented approach and are interlinked. They have their own role and function for increased success with CRM implementation. Payne and Frow extensively reviewed literature, along with field-based interactions, to develop a comprehensive process that would aid in developing a sound CRM strategy. Through their research, Payne and Frow stressed the importance of having CRM at strategic level.

Question 3
Match List I with List II:(UGC NET Management Jun 2023)ListI (Customer Relation Group)a. Strangersb. Barnaclesc. True Friendsd. ButterfliesListII (Distinctive Feature)i. High potential profitability and low projected loyalty.ii. High potential profitability and High projected loyaltyiii. Low potential profitability and low projected loyaltyiv. Low potential profitability and High projected loyaltyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a - i, b - iii, c - ii, d - iv
  • B.a - iv, b - iii, c - ii, d - i
  • C.a - iii, b - ii, c - iv, d - i
  • D.a - iii, b - iv, c - ii, d - i
Correct Answer: a - iii, b - iv, c - ii, d - i

Option D is the correct answer.

 

4 Types of Loyal Customers:

 

(i) True Friends: They are the loyalist of loyal customers. They are the customers that not only bring in profit, but also speak highly of your products and promote your business to others. An example of “True Friends” would be the so called “Apple Fanboys” that buy whatever product Apple releases simply because they think so highly of the company.

 

(ii) Butterflies: They are not particularly loyal but have spent money on your products and brought in good revenue. An example of a butterfly would be someone that supports Microsoft in general but buys the iPhone since it happened to be the best available phone on the market.

 

(iii) Barnacles: Here is where some companies, especially B2B companies, find a surprising amount of their customer base falls into. Barnacles are loyal customers, but they are loyal customers that rarely make a purchase and may not bring in much of a profit. A great example would be a customer that buys one cup of coffee at your coffee shop, and then comes in every day for the next month to use your free WiFi without making a purchase.

 

(iv) Strangers: They are those that barely bring in any revenue and are not necessarily loyal to your company. An example would be an individual that occasionally stops into a drug store to buy a stick of gum, but otherwise never uses the store.

Question 4
‘Making the brand a meaningful part of consumers conversations and likes by fostering direct and continuous customer involvement in shaping brand conversations, experiences and community’. The above description pertains to which of the following concepts?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)
  • A.Customer Generated Marketing
  • B.Societal Marketing Concept
  • C.Customer Relationship Management
  • D.Customer Engagement Marketing
Correct Answer: Customer Engagement Marketing

The concept described, wherein the brand becomes an integral part of consumers' conversations and preferences through direct and continuous customer involvement in shaping brand interactions, experiences, and community, aligns with the principles of Customer Engagement Marketing. This approach emphasizes fostering active engagement with customers, encouraging their participation in brand-related discussions, and co-creating experiences that resonate with their preferences and values. By leveraging various channels and touchpoints, such as social media platforms, interactive campaigns, and community events, brands aim to build deeper connections with their audience, enhance brand loyalty, and drive long-term customer relationships. Customer Engagement Marketing transcends traditional marketing strategies by prioritizing meaningful interactions and collaborative engagement, thereby enriching the overall brand experience and driving sustainable business growth.

Question 5
Which of the following are the main issues to be tackled by the conceptual component of Customer Relationship Management Programme?(UGC NET Management Dec 2023)(A) Processing all customer requests coming in through multiple channels.(B) Setting out the CRM objectives inclear terms.(C) Creating a good product and mass marketing it.(D) Putting customers first.(E) Segmenting the marketon the basis ofoccupations.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(B) and (D) Only
  • B.(A) and (E) Only
  • C.(C) and (D) Only
  • D.(D) and (E) Only
Correct Answer: (B) and (D) Only

Option A is the correct answer. The question asks about the “conceptual components” of Customer Relationship Management. Only statement (B) and (D) are true.

Question 6
Which of the following are the characteristics of a high customer-centric organization?(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2024)(A) Market driven(B) Process oriented(C) Value driven(D) Price driven(E) Making competitor irrelevantChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, E Only
  • B.A, C, E Only
  • C.B, C, D Only
  • D.C, D, E Only
Correct Answer: A, C, E Only

A high customer-centric organization focuses on delivering superior value to customers by understanding their needs, creating valuable experiences, and maintaining strong relationships. The key characteristics of such organizations include:

  • Market Driven (A) – These organizations actively analyze customer needs, industry trends, and market dynamics to shape their offerings.
  • Value Driven (C) – The focus is on delivering high value to customers through quality products, services, and experiences rather than just competing on price.
  • Making Competitor Irrelevant (E) – Instead of directly competing, these organizations innovate and differentiate their offerings so significantly that competitors lose relevance.
Question 7
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Management Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:The marketing costs of reaching loyal consumers are much lower because the firm does not have to spend money on advertising and promotion campaigns to attract these customers.Reason “R”:A high level of brand loyalty does not insulate the firm from competition.Codes:
  • A.Both“A”and“R”are correct and“R”is the right explanation of
  • B.Both“A”and“R”are incorrect.
  • C.Both“A”and“R”are correct, but“R”is not the right explanation of (A).
  • D.“A”is correct, but“R”is incorrect.
Correct Answer: “A”is correct, but“R”is incorrect.

In this question, we have two statements to evaluate:

 

Assertion "A": "The marketing costs of reaching loyal consumers are much lower because the firm does not have to spend money on advertising and promotion campaigns to attract these customers."

This assertion is correct. Loyal consumers are those who have a strong attachment to a brand and repeatedly make purchases without much external prompting. For these consumers, the need for extensive advertising and promotional efforts is reduced because they are already familiar with the brand and its products. As a result, reaching out to loyal consumers can indeed be more cost-effective in terms of marketing expenditure.

 

Reason "R": "A high level of brand loyalty does not insulate the firm from competition."

This reason is also correct. While brand loyalty can provide a competitive advantage by retaining existing customers and reducing marketing costs, it does not guarantee complete immunity from competition. Other factors such as product quality, price competitiveness, changing consumer preferences, and new market entrants can still impact a firm's market position. Brand loyalty might provide a cushion, but firms still need to adapt to the competitive landscape and strive to meet evolving customer needs.

 

The correct answer is (D) "A" is correct, but "R" is incorrect. This means that while Assertion "A" accurately states the cost-effectiveness of reaching loyal consumers, Reason "R" is not the right explanation for Assertion "A."

Question 8
Given below are two statements, one labelled as Assertion and the other labelled as Reason. Read the statements and choose the correct answer using the code given below. (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2018)Assertion “A”:Databases assist in market segmentation, especially behavioural segmentation such as developing loyalty segments.Reason “R”:Customer Relationship Management (CRM) databases have become an asset for the analysis of customer behaviour.Code:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A.
  • B.A is correct but R is not correct.
  • C.Both A and R are incorrect.
  • D.Both A and R are correct but R is not the right explanation of A.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A.

The correct answer is (A) Both A and R are correct and R is the right explanation of A.

 

Assertion (A) states that databases assist in market segmentation, especially behavioral segmentation, such as developing loyalty segments. This is correct because databases, particularly Customer Relationship Management (CRM) databases, store valuable data on customer behavior and preferences, which can be used for market segmentation and targeting specific customer groups based on their behavior.

 

Reason (R) states that Customer Relationship Management (CRM) databases have become an asset for the analysis of customer behavior. This is also correct because CRM databases are specifically designed to store and manage information about customer interactions, purchases, and behavior, making them valuable tools for analyzing and understanding customer behavior.

Question 9
Which of the following is NOT main stage in a customer relationship life cycle? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2019)
  • A.Customer acquisition
  • B.Customer development
  • C.Customer satisfaction
  • D.Customer annoyance
Correct Answer: Customer annoyance

The correct answer is (D) Customer annoyance.

 

The customer relationship life cycle refers to the various stages that a customer goes through in their relationship with a company or business. These stages typically include:

 

Customer Acquisition: This is the initial stage where the company focuses on acquiring new customers. It involves marketing efforts to attract potential customers, convincing them to make their first purchase, and becoming aware of the brand.

 

Customer Development: After acquiring customers, the next stage is customer development. In this stage, the company nurtures and builds relationships with these customers. The goal is to encourage repeat purchases, gain their loyalty, and potentially upsell or cross-sell additional products or services.

 

Customer Satisfaction: Customer satisfaction is a crucial stage in the life cycle. It involves ensuring that customers are happy with their purchases, have a positive experience with the company, and receive good customer service. Satisfied customers are more likely to become loyal customers and recommend the company to others.

 

Now, the term "Customer annoyance" is not a recognized stage in the customer relationship life cycle. While it's essential for companies to address customer concerns, complaints, or issues that may lead to annoyance, this is typically handled within the customer satisfaction stage. Companies aim to resolve problems and maintain a positive relationship with customers to prevent them from becoming annoyed or dissatisfied.

Question 10
Companies that are becoming skilled in Customer Relationship Management (CRM) focus on: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2019)
  • A.Understanding the perceived performance and buyer’s expectations
  • B.Giving benefits to the customers by reducing cost
  • C.Developing programs to attract and retain the right customers and meeting the individual needs of valued customers
  • D.Giving the quality in features and characteristics of a product or service that bear on its ability to satisfy stated or implied needs
Correct Answer: Developing programs to attract and retain the right customers and meeting the individual needs of valued customers

The correct answer is (C) Developing programs to attract and retain the right customers and meeting the individual needs of valued customers.

 

Companies skilled in Customer Relationship Management (CRM) focus on building and maintaining strong relationships with their customers. This involves understanding the individual needs and preferences of customers and developing programs to attract and retain the right customers. The emphasis is on personalized interactions, providing excellent customer service, and tailoring products or services to meet the unique needs of valued customers. CRM is about fostering long-term relationships, customer satisfaction, and loyalty by understanding and addressing customers' specific requirements and expectations.

Question 11
Sequence the steps in CRM process? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2020)I. Developing CRM programmesII. Collection of customer dataIII.Analyzingcustomer dataIV. Identify the target customersV. Implementing programsChoose the correct answer from the options given below
  • A.I, II, III, V, IV
  • B.II, III, IV, I, V
  • C.II, III, I, V, IV
  • D.III, IV, V, I, II
Correct Answer: II, III, IV, I, V

The correct sequence of steps in the CRM (Customer Relationship Management) process is as follows:

 

II. Collection of customer data: The process typically begins with the collection of data about customers, which can include their contact information, preferences, buying history, and other relevant details.

 

III. Analyzing customer data: After collecting customer data, the next step is to analyze it to gain insights into customer behavior, needs, and preferences. This analysis helps in understanding customer segments and identifying opportunities.

 

IV. Identify the target customers: Once the data is analyzed, businesses can identify specific target customers or customer segments that are most valuable or have the greatest potential for business growth.

 

I. Developing CRM programs: With the target customers identified, businesses can develop tailored CRM programs and strategies to engage with and serve these customers effectively. This step involves planning and designing CRM initiatives.

 

V. Implementing programs: Finally, the CRM programs and strategies are implemented, which may involve using technology, communication channels, and various touchpoints to interact with and serve customers based on their preferences and needs.

 

So, the correct sequence is (II, III, IV, I, V), as described in option (B).

Question 12
The company can classify customers according to their potential profitability and manage its relationships with them accordingly. Four relationship groups based on potential profitability and projected loyalty are:
  • A.butterflies, enemy, stranger, barnacles
  • B.question mark, butterflies, stranger, barnacles
  • C.true friends, butterflies, strangers, barnacles
  • D.stranger, true friend, enemy, barnacles
Correct Answer: true friends, butterflies, strangers, barnacles

The concept of customer relationship management (CRM) involves classifying customers based on their potential profitability and projected loyalty, allowing companies to tailor their relationship management strategies accordingly. This approach helps companies allocate resources effectively and build the right relationships with different customer groups. In this classification system, customers are grouped into four categories, each requiring a distinct strategy:

 

Strangers: These customers have low potential profitability and show little projected loyalty. There is a mismatch between the company's offerings and their needs. The recommended strategy for these customers is not to invest resources in them, as the potential return is limited.

 

Butterflies: Butterflies are potentially profitable but lack loyalty. Their needs align well with the company's offerings, but they tend to engage briefly and move on quickly. For instance, stock market investors who frequently trade shares fall into this category. The strategy here is to focus on creating satisfying and profitable transactions during their short engagement, capturing as much business as possible in that time.

 

True Friends: True friends are both profitable and loyal. Their needs closely match the company's offerings, and they represent a strong relationship opportunity. The company should make continuous investments in building relationships with these customers. The goal is to nurture, retain, and grow these relationships, ultimately turning them into advocates who promote the company.

 

Barnacles: Barnacles are highly loyal but not very profitable. Their needs have limited alignment with the company's offerings, resulting in a challenging situation. These customers might be similar to smaller bank customers who maintain regular accounts but don't generate substantial returns. The strategy for barnacles involves exploring ways to improve their profitability, such as increasing their purchases or raising fees. However, if these efforts are unsuccessful, it might be necessary to end the relationship.

Question 13
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Marketing mustskillfullyconduct not only customer relationship management (CRM), but Partner Relationship Management (PRM) as well.Statement II:It is always beneficial to explore new potential customers rather than sticking to existing one.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect

Increasingly, a key goal of marketing is to develop deep, enduring relationships with people and organizations that directly or indirectly affect the success of the firm’s marketing activities. The idea comes under Relationship marketing which aims to build mutually satisfying long-term relationships with key constituents in order to earn and retain their business.

 

Attracting a new customer may cost five times as much as retaining an existing one, that is why relationship marketing also emphasizes customer retention.  Companies build customer share by offering a larger variety of goods to existing customers, training employees in cross-selling and upselling. Marketing must skillfully conduct not only customer relationship management (CRM), but partner relationship management (PRM) as well.

 

Customer Relationship Management (CRM) refers to the principles, practices, and guidelines that an organization follows when interacting with its customers. From the organization's point of view, this entire relationship encompasses direct interactions with customers, such as sales and service-related processes, and forecasting and analysis of customer trends and behaviors. Ultimately, CRM serves to enhance the customer's overall experience.

 

Partner Relationship Management (PRM) usually refers to a system or collection of business processes and capabilities that allow a vendor company to communicate and engage with its channel partners. In PRM, companies deepened their partnering arrangements with key suppliers and distributors, seeing them as partners in delivering value to final customers so everybody benefits.

Therefore, Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect.

Question 14
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Customer-engagement marketing goal is to make the brand a meaningful part of consumers' conversations and lives.Statement II:Greater consumer empowerment means that companies can no longer rely on marketing by attraction but they must practice marketing by intrusion.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect

The correct answer is (C) Statement I is correct, and Statement II is incorrect.

 

Statement I is correct. Customer-engagement marketing aims to create a deeper connection between the brand and consumers by making the brand an integral part of their conversations and lives. It involves fostering direct and continuous customer involvement in shaping brand experiences.

 

Statement II is incorrect. Greater consumer empowerment, driven by factors like easy access to information and social media, has actually shifted marketing away from intrusion. Companies now recognize that interruptive or intrusive marketing tactics are often less effective. Instead, they are moving towards marketing by attraction, where they create compelling market offerings and messages that engage consumers willingly rather than interrupting them.

Question 15
Type of Consumer engagement in which customers are playing an increasing role in shaping their own brand experiences and those of other consumers is called
  • A.Customer Perceived Marketing
  • B.Customer Differentiating Marketing
  • C.Customer Performing Marketing
  • D.Customer Generated Marketing
Correct Answer: Customer Generated Marketing

Consumer-Generated Marketing: It is a type of consumer engagement marketing in which brand exchanges created by customers themselves – both invited and uninvited – by which customers are playing an increasing role in shaping their own brand experiences and those of other consumers. This might happen through uninvited consumer-to-consumer exchanges in blogs, video-sharing sites, social media, and other digital forums. But increasingly, companies themselves are inviting consumers to play a more active role in shaping products and brand content.

Question 16
Match the following.List I(a) Butterflies(b) True Friends(c) Strangers(d) BarnaclesList II(i) Both profitable and loyal.(ii) Highly loyal but not very profitable.(iii) Potentially profitable but not loyal.(iv) Little projected loyalty.Codes
  • A.a-(ii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iv) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iv) b-(ii) c-(i) d-(iii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(iv) d-(ii)

The concept of customer relationship management (CRM) entails categorizing customers based on their potential profitability and anticipated loyalty. This enables companies to customize their approaches to managing these relationships, resulting in efficient resource allocation and the cultivation of meaningful connections with diverse customer groups. This classification system divides customers into four distinct categories, each necessitating a unique strategy:

 

Strangers: These customers exhibit low potential profitability and limited projected loyalty due to a mismatch between their needs and the company's offerings. It is advisable not to invest substantial resources in this group, as the expected returns are modest.

 

Butterflies: Butterflies possess the potential for profitability but lack loyalty. Although their needs align well with the company's products or services, they tend to engage briefly and move on swiftly. For instance, frequent stock market traders fall into this category. The strategy here is to focus on creating satisfying and profitable transactions during their brief interactions, maximizing business opportunities within this limited timeframe.

 

True Friends: True friends represent both profitability and loyalty. Their needs closely align with what the company provides, presenting a valuable relationship-building opportunity. Continuous investments should be made in nurturing, retaining, and expanding relationships with these customers. The objective is to transform them into advocates who actively promote the company.

 

Barnacles: Barnacles display high loyalty but limited profitability, as their needs only partially match the company's offerings. This scenario can be likened to smaller bank customers who maintain regular accounts with minimal returns. The strategy for barnacles involves exploring ways to enhance their profitability, such as encouraging higher purchases or adjusting fees. However, if these efforts prove ineffective, it may become necessary to consider discontinuing the relationship.

Question 17
Companies can build customer relationships at many levels, depending on the nature of the target market. Liberty Shoes does not phone or call on all of its consumers to get to know them personally. Instead, Liberty shoes creates relationships through brand-building advertising, public relations, and its numerous Web sites ad apps. This is example of:
  • A.Engaged Relationships
  • B.Basic Relationships
  • C.Full Partnerships
  • D.Deep Relationships
Correct Answer: Basic Relationships

Companies can build customer relationships at various levels, depending on the nature of the target market and their strategies. In the case of Liberty Shoes, where they do not personally contact each consumer but create relationships through brand-building advertising, public relations, and various web platforms, it falls under the category of "Basic Relationships."

 

Basic Relationships involve companies engaging in marketing activities to attract and retain customers but without the depth of engagement and personalization seen in more advanced relationship levels. It is a less personalized form of engagement compared to engaged relationships, full partnerships, or deep relationships, where there is a higher level of interaction and personalization involved.

Question 18
Match the following.List I(a) Market Sensing Process(b) Customer acquisition Process(c) New offering realization Process(d) Customer relationship management processList II(i) Activities in researching, developing, and launching new high-quality offerings.(ii) Activities in building deeper understanding, relationships, and offerings to individual customers.(iii) Gathering and acting upon the information.(iv) Activities in defining target markets and prospecting for new customers.Choose the correct answer using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)
  • C.a-(i) b-(iv) c-(iii) d-(ii)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(ii) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(i) d-(ii)

The correct answer is (B) (iii) (iv) (i) (ii).

 

(a) Market Sensing Process: Activities in gathering and acting upon the information. This process involves monitoring the market, collecting data, and analyzing information to understand market trends and changes.

 

(b) Customer acquisition Process: Activities in defining target markets and prospecting for new customers. This process focuses on identifying potential customers and attracting them to the company's offerings.

 

(c) New offering realization Process: Activities in researching, developing, and launching new high-quality offerings. This process involves the creation and introduction of new products or services.

 

(d) Customer relationship management process: Activities in building a deeper understanding, relationships, and offerings to individual customers. This process is about managing and nurturing relationships with existing customers to enhance their loyalty and satisfaction.

Question 19
Activities the firm undertakes to build mutually satisfying long-term relations with key partner is called
  • A.Partnership Activity
  • B.Partner Relationship Management
  • C.Partnership Management
  • D.Partnership Strategy
Correct Answer: Partner Relationship Management

Partnership Relationship Management are the activities the firm undertakes to build mutually satisfying long-term relations with key partners such as suppliers, distributors, ad agencies, and marketing research suppliers.

 

Companies need to give creative thought to finding partners that might complement their strengths and offset their weaknesses. Well-managed alliances allow companies to obtain a greater sales impact at lower cost. To keep their strategic alliances thriving, corporations have begun to develop organizational structures to support them, and many have come to view the ability to form and manage partnerships as core skills.

Question 20
Who said “the real price of anything is the toil and trouble of acquiring it?”
  • A.Martha Rogers
  • B.Peter Drucker
  • C.Phillip Kotler
  • D.Adam Smith
Correct Answer: Adam Smith

Adam Smith observed over two centuries ago in The Wealth of Nations, “the real price of anything is the toil and trouble of acquiring it.”

 

Customer-Perceived Value (CPV) is the difference between the prospective customer’s evaluation of all the benefits and all the costs of an offering and the perceived alternatives.

 The buyer decides product benefits based on his perceptions of its attributes that can include reliability, durability, performance and resale value. He or she also places higher value on firm’s corporate image and reputation. 

 

Buyer adds up all the economic, functional, and psychological benefits from these 4 sources that are determinants of Customer Perceived Value -product, services, personnel, and image and perceives a particular as delivering greater customer benefits.

 

At the same time, he or she also examines his total cost of transacting with the firm as compare to its competitors, which consists of more than money. Total customer cost also includes the buyer’s time, energy, and psychological costs expended in product acquisition, usage, maintenance, ownership, and disposal. 

 

The buyer evaluates these elements together with the monetary cost to form a Total Customer Cost. Then he considers whether the chosen firm's total customer cost is too high compared to total customer benefits. If it is, buyer might choose its competitors. The buyer will choose whichever source delivers the highest perceived value.

Question 21
_________ is used to break down the market into different buyer-readiness stages.
  • A.Marketing tunnel
  • B.Marketing funnel
  • C.Marketing cone
  • D.Marketing pyramid
Correct Answer: Marketing funnel

The correct answer is (B) Marketing funnel.

 

A marketing funnel is a conceptual framework used in marketing to illustrate the stages a potential customer goes through in the buying process. It is shaped like a funnel to represent the progressive narrowing down of potential customers as they move through various stages, from being aware of a product or service to making a purchase. The stages typically include awareness, interest, consideration, intent, evaluation, and finally, purchase.

 

The term "funnel" is used because, like a funnel where a wide top section narrows down as you pour a substance, the number of potential customers reduces as they move through the marketing stages towards making a purchase. It's an essential tool for understanding customer behavior and optimizing marketing strategies to guide consumers through the buying process effectively.

Question 22
Given below are two statements - one islabeledas Assertion and the other islabeledas Reason.Assertion “A”:No matter how perfectly designed and implemented a marketing program is, mistakes will happen.Reason “R”:The best thing a company can do is make it easy for customers to complain.In the light of above two statements, choose the correct option:
  • A.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • B.Both A and R are correct and R is not the correct explanation of A
  • C.A is correct but R is incorrect
  • D.A is incorrect but R is correct
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A

The correct answer is indeed (A) Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Assertion "A" states that mistakes will happen in marketing programs no matter how perfectly designed and implemented they are. This is a reasonable statement as it acknowledges that even the best marketing efforts may encounter issues or errors.

 

Reason "R" provides a solution to dealing with such mistakes, suggesting that the best thing a company can do is make it easy for customers to complain. This is a valid point because by providing channels for customers to voice their complaints and concerns, companies can address issues promptly and potentially retain customer goodwill.

Question 23
Who among the following is pioneer in the technique of Permission marketing?
  • A.Martha Rogers
  • B.Seth Godin
  • C.Don Peppers
  • D.Phillip Kotler
Correct Answer: Seth Godin

The correct answer is (B) Seth Godin.

 

Seth Godin is considered a pioneer in the technique of Permission Marketing. He coined the term and popularized the concept through his book "Permission Marketing: Turning Strangers into Friends and Friends into Customers," published in 1999. Permission marketing is a marketing strategy that focuses on obtaining the consent or permission from consumers to deliver targeted and relevant promotional messages. It emphasizes building a relationship with the consumer by seeking their permission before sending marketing materials, thus increasing the likelihood of engagement and response.

Question 24
To reduce the customer defection rate, the company must:
  • A.Define and measure its retention rate.
  • B.Distinguish the causes of customer attrition and identify those that can be managed better.
  • C.Compare the lost customer’s lifetime value to the costs of reducing the defection rate.
  • D.All of the above
Correct Answer: All of the above

Customer defection or churn is the loss of customers. It is not enough to attract new customers; the company must also keep them and increase their business. Too many companies suffer from high customer churn or defection and to reduce it, the company must:

(i) Define and measure its retention rate: For a magazine, subscription renewal rate is a good measure of retention. For a college, it could be first- to second-year retention rate, or class graduation rate.

(ii) Distinguish the causes of customer attrition and identify those that can be managed better: Not much can be done about customers who leave the region or go out of business, but much can be done about those driven away by poor service, shoddy products, or high prices.

(iii) Compare the lost customer’s lifetime value to the costs of reducing the defection rate: As long as the cost to discourage defection is lower than the lost profit, spend the money to try to retain the customer.

Question 25
_________ identifies the percentage of the potential target market at each stage in the decision process, from merely aware to highly loyal.
  • A.Marketing conversion rates
  • B.Market Funnel
  • C.Customer Base
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Market Funnel

The correct answer is (B) Market Funnel.

 

A market funnel, also known as a sales or marketing funnel, identifies the percentage of the potential target market at each stage in the decision process, ranging from being merely aware of a product or service to becoming highly loyal customers. The concept of a market funnel is widely used in marketing to visualize and track the customer's journey through various stages of awareness, consideration, and ultimately making a purchase, as well as becoming loyal advocates for the brand. It provides insights into the conversion rates and helps in understanding the customer's progression through the different stages of engagement.

Question 26
The number and value of customers who will repeatedly do business with the firm is
  • A.Customer equity
  • B.Customer base
  • C.Customer capital
  • D.Customer profitability
Correct Answer: Customer base

The correct answer is (B) Customer base.

 

The number and value of customers who will repeatedly do business with a firm refer to the customer base. The customer base represents the existing and active customer pool that regularly engages and transacts with the company. It is a fundamental aspect for any business, and maintaining and expanding the customer base is a key objective for sustainable growth and success. Customer base encompasses both the number of customers and the value they bring to the business through repeated transactions and ongoing relationships.

Question 27
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Listening to customers is crucial to Customer Relationship Management.Statement II:Listening is only part of the story. It is also important to be a customer advocate and, as much as possible, take the customers’ side and understand their point of view.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Both statements emphasize the importance of customer-centric approaches in CRM, making (A) the correct choice.

 

Statement I: "Listening to customers is crucial to Customer Relationship Management" is correct. Customer Relationship Management (CRM) relies heavily on understanding and listening to customers' needs, preferences, and feedback to build strong and lasting relationships.

 

Statement II: "Listening is only part of the story. It is also important to be a customer advocate and, as much as possible, take the customers’ side and understand their point of view" is also correct. Effective CRM goes beyond passive listening; it involves actively advocating for customers, addressing their concerns, and empathizing with their perspective to enhance their overall experience and satisfaction.

Question 28
_________ is the technique marketing statisticians use to extract from the mass of data useful information about individuals, trends, and segments.
  • A.Data Intervention
  • B.Data Mining
  • C.Data Penetration
  • D.Data Identification
Correct Answer: Data Mining

Through data mining, marketing statisticians can extract from the mass of data useful information about individuals, trends, and segments. Data mining uses sophisticated statistical and mathematical techniques such as cluster analysis, automatic interaction detection, predictive modeling, and neural networking.

 

In general, companies can use their databases in 4 ways:

(i) To identify prospects: Many companies generate sales leads by advertising their product or service. The ads generally contain a response feature, such as a business reply card or toll-free phone number, and the company builds its database from customer responses. It sorts through the database to identify the best prospects, then contacts them by mail or phone to try to convert them into customers.

(ii) To decide which customers should receive a particular offer: Companies interested in selling, up-selling, and cross-selling set up criteria describing the ideal target customer for a particular offer. Then they search their customer databases for those who most closely resemble the ideal. By noting response rates, a company can improve its targeting precision. Following a sale, it can set up an automatic sequence of activities that continues communication.

(iii) To deepen customer loyalty: Companies can build interest and enthusiasm by remembering customer preferences and sending appropriate gifts, discount coupons, and interesting reading material.

(iv) To reactivate customer purchases: Automatic mailing programs (automatic marketing) can send out birthday or anniversary cards, holiday shopping reminders, or off-season promotions. The database can help the company make attractive or timely offers.

Question 29
_______ is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer “touch points” to maximize loyalty.
  • A.Personalizing marketing
  • B.Customer empowerment
  • C.Customer value management
  • D.Customer relationship management
Correct Answer: Customer relationship management

Customer Relationship Management is managing detailed information about individual customers and carefully managing customer touch points to maximize customer loyalty.

 

Personalized marketing, or one-to-one marketing, individual marketing is a marketing strategy by which companies leverage data analysis and digital technology to deliver individualized messages and product offerings to current or prospective customers.

 

Customer Value Management (CVM) helps corporations develop tailored products and services to their customers, in order to maximize profits on an individual customer level. The goal of CVM is to move towards mass customized offers and price discrimination based on Willingness to pay (both consumer and corporate), Current customer value and usage profiles.

 

In marketing, empowerment is providing consumers with options, tools and resources to facilitate decision-making, allowing consumers to tailor a product or brand experience to suit their own specific needs and desires.

Question 30
Which of the following statements are correct?Statement-I:Customer Relationship Management (CRM), describes the Company’s optimization of the value of its customer base.Statement-II:Customer Value Management (CVM) focuses on the analysis of individual data on prospects and customers to develop marketing strategies to acquire and retain customers and drive customerbehavior.Statement-III:CRM is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer “touch points” to maximize loyalty.Codes:
  • A.I and II
  • B.I and III
  • C.II and III
  • D.III
Correct Answer: II and III

Customer Relationship Management (CRM) implies building stronger relationships with customers. CRM’s aim is to produce high customer equity, which is the total of the discounted lifetime values of all of the firm’s customers. The CRM is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer touch points to maximize customer loyalty. The drivers of CRM include:

1. Value equity (sub-drivers are quality, price, and convenience),

2. Brand equity (sub-drivers are customer brand awareness, customer attitude, customer perception of brand ethics),

3. Relationship equity (sub-drivers are loyalty programs, special recognition and treatment programs, community and knowledge building programs).

 

Customer Value Management (CVM), which we define as the optimization of the value of a company’s customer base. CVM focuses on the analysis of individual data on prospects and customers. The resulting information is used to acquire and retain customers and to drive customer behavior with marketing strategies such that the value of all current and future customers is optimized.

Customer value management will help you accurately determine what drives value for customers, measure your performance relative to the competition, align efforts, focus scarce resources and create your sustainable competitive advantage.

Question 31
Peter Golder and Gerald Tellis identified 5 factors underpinning long-term Market leadership. Identify among the following which is NOT included?(i) Vision of a mass market(ii) Stability of a product(iii) Relentless innovation(iv) Financial Commitment(v) Asset Leverage(vi) Tapping Potential CustomersCodes
  • A.(ii) and (vi)
  • B.(iii) and (v)
  • C.(i) and (iv)
  • D.(iii) and (iv)
Correct Answer: (ii) and (vi)

Peter Golder and Gerald Tellis identified five factors that underpin long-term market leadership.

 

(i) Vision of a mass market: Having a clear vision of the mass market and understanding its dynamics and potential is crucial for long-term market leadership. This involves understanding the needs and preferences of a broad customer base.

 

(ii) Stability of a product: This factor refers to the stability and reliability of a product over time. A stable and reliable product is important for maintaining customer trust and satisfaction.

 

(iii) Relentless innovation: Constant innovation is essential to stay ahead in the market. Companies need to continuously improve and innovate their products, services, and processes to meet evolving customer needs and preferences.

 

(iv) Financial commitment: Long-term market leadership requires a significant financial commitment to sustain operations, invest in research and development, marketing, and other essential areas that contribute to competitiveness.

 

(v) Asset leverage: This involves effectively leveraging the company's assets, resources, and capabilities to maintain a competitive edge in the market.

 

(vi) Tapping potential customers: This involves reaching out to potential customers and effectively expanding the customer base, tapping into new markets, and identifying growth opportunities.

 

Among the given options, (ii) Stability of a product is not included as one of the factors underpinning long-term market leadership, and (vi) Tapping Potential Customers is also not mentioned in the original factors identified by Golder and Tellis.

 

So, the correct answer is (A) (ii) and (vi).

Question 32
Attributes or benefits that consumers strongly associate with a brand, positively evaluate, and believe they could not find to the same extent with a competitive brand is known as: (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)
  • A.Competitive points-of-parity
  • B.Relational points-of-parity
  • C.Correlational points-of-parity
  • D.Points-of-difference
Correct Answer: Points-of-difference

A marketer could choose amongst two kinds of positioning strategies; he could either opt for positioning on (i) Points of parity (POP) or (ii) Points of difference (POD). Points of parity could be further sub-divided into Category point-of-parity associations, and Competitive point-of-parity associations. 

 

1. Points of parity (POP): Here the product in question is not unique in nature; it is shared by other competitive brands; the product or service offering is similar to that of the competitor. Example: Complan, Milo and Bournvita: Positioned as: All help children to grow. POP has 2 basic forms: 

a) Category point-of-parity: The product or service offering should possess these qualities in order to qualify being a part of the product or service category. These are the bare minimum that all the brands should possess in order to qualify as a part of the product or service industry. Example: All mouthwashes contain antimicrobials; they are also minty. 

b) Competitive point-of-parity: These are developed to fight against and balance out with the competitors’ points-of-difference. Example: Listerine vs Scope: Listerine claims to leave you fresh after a rinse and prevents bad breath; Scope claims that it does the same but in a milder way. Savlon versus Dettol: Savlon does not sting when applied on wound. 

 

2. Points of difference (POD): Here the product or service offering is unique; the positioning is based on the USP (Unique Selling Proposition). The uniqueness should be something that the customers value, and can relate to favourably. This USP leads to differentiation and can thus, develop competitive brand positioning. The product and service offering can be differentiated on the basis of product, service, people, image and public relations etc. Example: Auto color and contrast setting: LG Golden Eye. 


3) Correlational Points-of-parity are those potentially negative associations that arise from the existence of other, more positive associations for the brand.

Question 33
Top firms audit service performance, both their own and competitors’, on a regular basis. They collect ___________ measurements to probe customer satisfiers and dissatisfiers. They use comparison shopping, mystery or ghost shopping, customer surveys, suggestion and complaint forms, service-audit teams, and customers’ letters to the CEO.
  • A.Sample
  • B.Customer Analysis
  • C.Voice of the Customer
  • D.None of above
Correct Answer: Voice of the Customer

The correct answer is (C) Voice of the Customer.

 

Voice of the Customer (VOC) refers to the process of collecting and analyzing customer feedback and opinions about a product or service. It involves listening to what customers have to say, understanding their needs and preferences, and using this information to improve the quality of products or services. In the context of the statement, collecting measurements to probe customer satisfiers and dissatisfiers is part of the VOC process, which helps organizations gain insights into customer preferences and make necessary improvements.

Question 34
The aim of Customer Relationship Management (CRM) is to produce high _______ equity.
  • A.brand
  • B.customer
  • C.company
  • D.financial
Correct Answer: customer

Brand equity can be related to one other important marketing concept, customer equity which is the sum of lifetime values of all customers. The aim of Customer Relationship Management (CRM) is to produce high customer equity. Although we can calculate it in different ways, one definition is “the sum of lifetime values of all customers”.

 

Brand equity refers to a value premium that a company generates from a product with a recognizable name when compared to a generic equivalent. Companies can create brand equity for their products by making them memorable, easily recognizable, and superior in quality and reliability.

Question 35
__________is about making sure the brand and its marketing are as relevant as possible to as many customers as possible, given that no two customers are identical.
  • A.Customer Relationship Management
  • B.Customer Empowerment
  • C.Personalize Marketing
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Personalize Marketing

Personalizing Marketing is about making sure the brand and its marketing are as relevant as possible to as many customers as possible, given that no two customers are identical. Employees can create strong bonds with customers by individualizing and personalizing relationships. In essence, thoughtful companies turn their customers into clients. For, customers may be nameless to the institution; clients cannot be nameless.

Question 36
Arrange the steps of one-to -one marketing in correct order as given by Don Peppers and Martha Rogers that can be adopted in CRM Marketing.(i) Identify your prospects and customers.(ii) Customize products, services and messages to each customer.(iii) Differentiate customers in terms of their needs and values to a firm.(iv) Interact with individual customers to improve your knowledge about their individual needs and to build stronger relationships.Choose the correct option using the codes given below:Codes
  • A.(ii), (iv), (i), (iii)
  • B.(i), (iii), (ii), (iv)
  • C.(iii), (ii), (iv), (i)
  • D.(i), (ii), (iii), (iv)
Correct Answer: (i), (iii), (ii), (iv)

Don Peppers and Martha Rogers outline a 4-step framework for one-to-one marketing that can be adapted to CRM marketing as follows:

(i) Identify your prospects and customers: Don’t go after everyone. Build, maintain, and mine a rich customer database with information from all the channels and customer touch points.

(ii) Differentiate customers in terms of their needs and their value to your company: Spend proportionately more effort on the most valuable customers (MVCs). Apply activity-based costing and calculate customer lifetime value. Estimate net present value of all future profits from purchases, margin levels, and referrals, less customer-specific servicing costs.

(iii) Interact with individual customers to improve your knowledge about their individual needs and to build stronger relationships: Formulate customized offerings you can communicate in a personalized way.

(iv) Customize products, services, and messages to each customer: Facilitate customer interaction through the company contact center and Web site.

 

One-to-one marketing works best for firms that normally collect a great deal of individual customer information and carry a lot of products that can be cross-sold, need periodic replacement or upgrading, and offer high value.

Question 37
While developing customer loyalty programmes, database is often not helpful in (UGC NET Management Jun 2014)
  • A.Identifying prospective customers
  • B.Deepening customer loyalty
  • C.Avoiding serious customer mistakes
  • D.Creating consumer associations
Correct Answer: Creating consumer associations

Data mining allows marketing statisticians to extract valuable information about individuals, trends, and segments from vast amounts of data. This process involves using advanced statistical and mathematical techniques such as cluster analysis, automatic interaction detection, predictive modeling, and neural networking.

 

There is a belief among some observers that having a proprietary database can provide a company with a significant competitive advantage. Companies can utilize their databases in 5 keyways:

 

1. Identifying prospects: Many companies generate sales leads by including a response feature in their advertisements, such as a link to a website, a business reply card, or a toll-free phone number. By collecting customer responses, they build a database. The company then sifts through this database to identify the most promising prospects and contacts them through mail, email, or phone to convert them into customers.

 

2. Targeting specific offers: Companies interested in selling, up-selling, and cross-selling can establish criteria that describe the ideal target customer for a particular offer. They then search their customer databases to find individuals who closely match this ideal customer profile. By monitoring response rates, companies can enhance their targeting precision. Following a sale, companies can set up automated activities, such as sending a thank-you note one week later, a new offer five weeks later, and a special discount offer ten weeks later if the customer has not responded.

 

3. Deepening customer loyalty: Companies can strengthen customer loyalty by remembering and leveraging customer preferences. This can be achieved by sending appropriate gifts, discount coupons, interesting reading material, or personalized communications based on the customer's previous interactions and preferences.

 

4. Reactivating customer purchases: Automatic mailing programs, also known as automatic marketing, can be employed to send out cards for birthdays, anniversaries, holiday shopping reminders, or off-season promotions. By utilizing the database, companies can make attractive and timely offers to entice customers to make repeat purchases.

 

5. Avoiding serious customer mistakes: A cautionary example involves a major bank that admitted to making mistakes due to the inadequate utilization of its customer database. In one instance, the bank charged a customer a penalty for late mortgage payment without recognizing that the customer was a major depositor with the bank. As a result, the customer terminated their relationship with the bank. In another case, two different staff members of the bank independently contacted the same mortgage customer, offering a home equity loan at different prices, unaware of each other's actions. Furthermore, the bank provided only standard service to a premium customer in another country. These examples highlight the importance of utilizing customer data effectively to avoid such mistakes.

Question 38
Which of the following statements are correct? (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)Statement-I:Customer Relationship Management (CRM), describes the Company’s optimization of the value of its customer base.Statement-II:Customer Value Management (CVM) focuses on the analysis of individual data on prospects and customers to develop marketing strategies to acquire and retain customers and drive customer behaviour.Statement-III:CRM is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer “touch points” to maximize loyalty.Codes:
  • A.I and II
  • B.I and III
  • C.II and III
  • D.III
Correct Answer: II and III

The correct answer is (C) II and III.

 

Statement-II: Customer Value Management (CVM) focuses on the analysis of individual data on prospects and customers to develop marketing strategies to acquire and retain customers and drive customer behaviour. Customer Value Management emphasizes understanding and maximizing the value that each individual customer brings to the company by tailoring marketing strategies and actions accordingly.

 

Statement-III: CRM (Customer Relationship Management) is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer "touch points" to maximize loyalty. CRM involves building and maintaining strong relationships with customers through personalized interactions and services, with the aim of increasing customer loyalty, satisfaction, and overall lifetime value.

 

While Statement-I mentions "Company’s optimization of the value of its customer base," it does not accurately capture the concept of Customer Relationship Management (CRM) and its focus on managing customer relationships and interactions. Therefore, Statement-I is not correct.

Question 39
_______ is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individualcustomers and all customer “touch points” to maximize loyalty. (UGC NET Management Aug 2016)
  • A.Personalizing marketing
  • B.Customer empowerment
  • C.Customer value management
  • D.Customer relationship management
Correct Answer: Customer relationship management

The correct answer is (D) Customer relationship management.

 

Customer relationship management (CRM) is the process of carefully managing detailed information about individual customers and all customer "touch points" to maximize loyalty. It involves using technology and data analysis to build and maintain strong relationships with customers, understand their needs and preferences, and deliver personalized marketing and services to enhance customer satisfaction and loyalty.

Question 40
The CRM strategy adopted by Big Bazaar in India is all about -(UGC NET Management Jun 2020)
  • A.Frequency marketing Program
  • B.Club Membership Program
  • C.Structural relationship Program
  • D.Experiential Relationship Program
Correct Answer: Club Membership Program

The correct answer is (B) Club Membership Program.

 

We can conclude that the CRM (Customer Relationship Management) strategy adopted by Big Bazaar in India is primarily centered around a "Club Membership Program." Here is how the content supports this conclusion:

 

Easyday Club Membership: Future Retail Limited, associated with Big Bazaar, introduces "Easyday Club" as part of its strategy. This is explicitly referred to as an exclusive membership program.

 

Benefits for Loyal Customers: It is stated that this program is offered to loyal customers who love coming back to avail a host of benefits. This indicates that the program is designed to reward and retain loyal customers.

 

Membership Discounts: Easyday Club members are provided with a flat 10% discount on every bill as they shop. This discount is mentioned to be in addition to the existing in-store offers. Offering discounts to club members is a common feature of club membership programs to incentivize repeat purchases.

 

Exclusive Monthly Offers: Special offers are exclusively created for club members every month. This practice is a hallmark of club membership programs, where members receive exclusive benefits and promotions.

 

Enhanced Convenience: Easyday Club aims to make daily shopping more convenient for its members by offering free home delivery and the ability to place orders via WhatsApp. These convenience features are designed to enhance the overall shopping experience for club members.

Question 41
Customer Relationship Management performs several tasks and bring several benefits. Identify them out of the following-(UGC NET Management Jun 2020)a. Support cross selling and up selling to existing customersb. Manages customer interactions and customer servicesc. Serves as sustainable competitive advantagesd. Helps convert buyer into profitable customers, build enduring relationship with them and retain them as customers for life.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.b, c, d only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.a, b, c, d- all
Correct Answer: a, b, c, d- all

The correct answer is (D) a, b, c, d - all.

 

Customer Relationship Management (CRM) is a strategic approach that focuses on managing and enhancing interactions with customers to build and maintain strong and long-lasting relationships. CRM encompasses various tasks and benefits that contribute to improving customer satisfaction, loyalty, and overall business performance.

 

a. Support Cross Selling and Up Selling to Existing Customers: Cross selling involves offering additional products or services to existing customers, while up selling involves encouraging customers to purchase higher-end or upgraded versions of products or services they are already interested in. CRM systems can analyze customer data to identify opportunities for cross selling and up selling, thereby increasing revenue from existing customers.

 

b. Manages Customer Interactions and Customer Services: CRM systems help in managing customer interactions and provide efficient customer service. They store customer information, communication history, and preferences, allowing businesses to respond effectively to customer inquiries, complaints, and requests. This improves customer satisfaction and loyalty.

 

c. Serves as Sustainable Competitive Advantages: By effectively managing customer relationships, businesses can create a sustainable competitive advantage. Building strong relationships with customers makes it more challenging for competitors to replicate the same level of personalized service and customer engagement.

 

d. Helps Convert Buyers into Profitable Customers, Build Enduring Relationships with Them, and Retain Them as Customers for Life: CRM aims to convert one-time buyers into loyal and profitable customers by building enduring relationships with them. By understanding customer preferences and needs, businesses can tailor their offerings and communications, leading to customer loyalty and retention.

 

All the provided options (a, b, c, and d) accurately represent tasks and benefits associated with Customer Relationship Management. Therefore, the correct answer is (D) a, b, c, d - all.

Question 42
Which of the following statements are true in the context of CRM (Customer Relationship Management) 2.0?I. Customer interactions are not pre planned but happen in real time.II. Software as a service is the dominant CRM model particularly in small and medium-sized businesses.III. Customer data is typically stored on corporate servers only.IV. Means available for analytics are only standard multivariate statistical procedures such as cluster analysis and logistic regression.V. CRM 2.0 uses massive amounts of structured and unstructured data.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below: (UGC NET Management Jun 2022)Codes
  • A.I, III, IV only
  • B.II, III, V only
  • C.I, II, V only
  • D.III, IV, V only
Correct Answer: I, II, V only

Only Statements I, II and V are correct.

 

I. Customer interactions are not pre-planned but happen in real-time: This statement is correct. CRM 2.0 emphasizes real-time interactions with customers, meaning that companies engage with customers on-the-fly, responding to their needs and inquiries as they occur rather than following pre-planned scripts.

 

II. Software as a service is the dominant CRM model, particularly in small and medium-sized businesses: This statement is incorrect. While Software as a Service (SaaS) has become popular in CRM, it's not the dominant model for all businesses, especially larger ones that might have more complex needs and resources.

 

III. Customer data is typically stored on corporate servers only: This statement is incorrect. CRM systems today can utilize cloud-based solutions, which means that customer data might not be stored exclusively on corporate servers but could be stored securely in the cloud.

 

IV. Means available for analytics are only standard multivariate statistical procedures such as cluster analysis and logistic regression: This statement is incorrect. CRM 2.0 utilizes a variety of advanced analytics techniques beyond just standard statistical procedures, including machine learning, data mining, natural language processing, and more.

 

V. CRM 2.0 uses massive amounts of structured and unstructured data: This statement is correct. CRM 2.0 leverages both structured data (such as customer demographics) and unstructured data (such as social media posts) to gain deeper insights into customer behavior and preferences.

Quiz Attempt #119622

Total Questions: 31
Question 1
The whole channel concept for International Marketing is represented as: (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Seller >> Seller’s International Marketing Headquarters >> Channels within foreign nations >> Channels between nations >> Final Buyers
  • B.Seller >> Seller’s International Marketing Headquarters >> Channels between nations >> Channels within foreign nations >> Final Buyers
  • C.Seller >> Channels between foreign nations >> Seller’s International Marketing Headquarters >> Channels within foreign nations >> Final Buyers
  • D.Seller >> Channels between foreign nations >> Channels within foreign nations >> Seller’s International Marketing Headquarters >> Final Buyers
Correct Answer: Seller >> Seller’s International Marketing Headquarters >> Channels between nations >> Channels within foreign nations >> Final Buyers

The channel concept for International Marketing involves the sequence of steps or links through which a product travels from the seller to the final buyers in foreign markets. The correct representation of the whole channel concept is provided in option (B).

 

Seller: This is where the product originates. It could be a manufacturer, producer, or distributor located in the home country. This is where the product is created and prepared for distribution.

 

Seller’s International Marketing Headquarters: This is the central decision-making unit within the company that handles international marketing strategies. It is responsible for making crucial decisions related to entering foreign markets, positioning the product, setting pricing strategies, and determining how the product will be promoted in different countries.

 

Channels between nations: This stage involves getting the product from the home country to the foreign markets. It includes decisions about transportation modes (air, sea, land), intermediaries (agents, trading companies), financing, and risk management. This step ensures that the product crosses international borders and enters the target countries.

 

Channels within foreign nations: Once the product arrives in a foreign country, it needs to be distributed within that country to reach local retailers, distributors, and consumers. This stage involves setting up local distribution channels, which can include wholesalers, retailers, and other intermediaries. The goal is to ensure that the product is available and accessible to the target audience within the foreign market.

 

Final Buyers: These are the end consumers or businesses that purchase and use the product. This is the ultimate destination of the product's journey, where it fulfils the needs and wants of the customers in the foreign market.

Question 2
Changing Global Marketing Communication for each local market is called _______. (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)
  • A.International Marketing
  • B.Communication Linkage
  • C.Communication Adaption
  • D.International Deal
Correct Answer: Communication Adaption

Communication adaptation refers to the process of modifying or tailoring global marketing communication strategies to suit the specific characteristics, preferences, and cultural nuances of each local market. This approach recognizes that what works effectively in one market may not resonate in the same way in another due to differences in language, culture, values, and consumer behaviour.

 

(i) International Marketing: International marketing refers to the process of marketing products or services to consumers in multiple countries, often taking into account the varying needs and preferences of different markets. While communication adaptation is a part of international marketing, it specifically focuses on the modification of marketing communications.

 

(ii) Communication Linkage: Communication linkage doesn't directly refer to the concept of adapting marketing communications for local markets. Communication adaptation is about making adjustments to the communication itself.

 

(iii) International Deal: "International deal" is not a term commonly associated with the practice of modifying marketing communication for local markets.

Question 3
How to enter in the Global Market? Arrange serially. (UGC NET Management Jul 2016)a – Deciding whether to go abroad.b – Deciding on the marketing organization.c – Deciding how to enter the market.d – Deciding on Marketing programme.e – Deciding in which market to enter.Codes:
  • A.a, d, c, e, b
  • B.a, b, c, d, e
  • C.a, e, c, d, b
  • D.b, d, c, e, a
Correct Answer: a, e, c, d, b

Entering the global market involves a systematic decision-making process that includes various steps. These steps are typically sequenced to ensure a successful entry into international markets. The correct sequence of these steps is as follows:

 

(a) Deciding whether to go abroad: The first step involves determining whether to expand into international markets. Companies assess factors such as market potential, profit opportunities, competitive landscape, and the need for growth beyond domestic markets.

 

(e) Deciding in which market to enter: After the decision to expand abroad is made, the company identifies the target markets for its products or services. This step involves evaluating factors like market demographics, economic conditions, cultural differences, and competitive dynamics.

 

(c) Deciding how to enter the market: Once the target markets are identified, the company must choose the best mode of entry. This decision involves considering options such as exporting, licensing, joint ventures, and direct investment. The chosen mode of entry determines the level of commitment, risk, and control.

 

(d) Deciding on marketing program: After determining the mode of entry, the company develops its marketing program for the target market. This program includes adapting product features, branding, pricing, advertising, and promotional strategies to suit the preferences and needs of the local consumers.

 

(b) Deciding on the marketing organization: As the company enters international markets, it needs to establish an effective marketing organization to manage its operations. This includes setting up sales teams, distribution channels, and local partnerships to ensure smooth market entry and ongoing operations.

 

The correct answer is (C) - a, e, c, d, b. This sequence ensures a systematic approach to entering the global market, considering various factors and making informed decisions at each step of the process.

Question 4
The undernoted items are categorized into which one of the following international product decisions for globalbusiness.(UGC NET Management Jan 2017)Straight extension, product adaptation, communication extension, communication adaptation, product extension, dual adaptation, and innovation
  • A.Product diversification
  • B.Product market segmentation
  • C.Product communication strategies
  • D.Market segmentation and product promotion
Correct Answer: Product communication strategies

The correct answer is (C) Product Communication Strategies. It refer to the approaches and decisions taken by companies when it comes to communicating their products or brands in international markets. These strategies consider how to effectively convey the value proposition, benefits, and features of the product to the target audience while taking into account cultural, linguistic, and market-specific factors.

 

Let us break down the terms mentioned in the question to understand their relevance to product communication strategies:

 

  • Straight Extension: This strategy involves using the same product and the same communication strategy in international markets as in the domestic market. No adaptations or modifications are made.
  • Product Adaptation: This involves modifying the product itself to suit the preferences and needs of the target market. This could also entail adapting the communication strategy to align with the local culture and preferences.
  • Communication Extension: Here, the product remains unchanged, but the communication strategy used in the domestic market is extended to the international market.
  • Communication Adaptation: The product remains the same, but the communication strategy is adapted to match the cultural and linguistic nuances of the international market.
  • Product Extension: In this case, the product remains unchanged, but it is offered to a new international market.
  • Dual Adaptation: Both the product and the communication strategy are adapted to suit the preferences and characteristics of the international market.
  • Innovation: This involves introducing new and innovative products or features to the international market.

 

All these strategies fall under the umbrella of product communication strategies, as they determine how a company presents its product offerings to consumers in different countries. The strategies chosen depend on factors like cultural differences, market preferences, language barriers, and competitive landscape.

Question 5
Which of the following circumstances favour “Sprinkle Approach” for launching products in international markets? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)a. The life cycle of the product is relatively short.b. The competitive intensity of the market is very high with strong and fierce competitors.c. Cost of entry in markets is relatively high.d. Firm has large resources to manage simultaneous product launch in multiple markets.e. The size of the target market is small with low growth potential.Choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a, b and d only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.b, d and e only
  • D.c, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and d only

Option A is the correct answer.

 

The sprinkler approach to market entry involves simultaneous expansion of business operations into multiple foreign markets. Its primary feature is the concurrent entry into these markets, aiming to capitalize on the advantages of early participation. As a result, it represents a strategy with high risk and high potential rewards. In this approach, a company ventures into various foreign markets at the same time, striving to establish its presence, promote the product, and concurrently build a customer base.
