Effects of marketing extend beyond the company and the customer to society as a whole. Therefore, marketers must consider the ethical, environmental, legal, and social context of their role and activities.

 

The organization's task is thus to determine the needs, wants, and interests of target markets and satisfy them more effectively and efficiently than competitors while preserving or enhancing consumers’ and society’s long-term well-being. For instance, LG Electronics, Toshiba, and NEC Display Solutions offer electronic recycling programs, for instance, often providing consumers with prepaid postage to return old items.

 

Therefore, both Statements are correct.

Question 22
Match the following.List I(a) Cause Marketing(b) Corporate Social Marketing(c) Cause related Marketing(d) Corporate Community involvementList II(i) Providing volunteer services in the community.(ii) Donating a percentage of revenues to a specific cause.(iii) Promoting social issues through sponsorships, licensing agreements, and advertising.(iv) Supporting behaviour change campaignsCodes
  • A.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iv) d-(iii)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(ii) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(ii) d-(i)

Types of Corporate Social Initiatives:

Corporate social marketing: Supporting behavior change campaigns. Ex: McDonald's promotion of a state-wide childhood immunization campaign in Oklahoma

 

Cause marketing: Promoting social issues through efforts such as sponsorships, licensing agreements, and advertising. Ex - McDonalds sponsorship of Forest (a gorilla) at Sydney’s Zoo—a 10-year sponsorship commitment, aimed at preserving this endangered species.

 

Cause-related marketing: Donating a percentage of revenues to a specific cause based on the revenue occurring during the announced period of support. Ex - McDonalds earmarking of $1 for Ronald McDonald Children’s Charities from the sale of every Big Mac and pizza sold on McHappy Day.

 

Corporate philanthropy: Making gifts of money, goods, or time to help non-profit organizations, groups, or individuals. Ex - McDonalds contributions to Ronald McDonald House Charities.

 

Corporate community involvement: Providing in-kind or volunteer services in the community. Ex - McDonalds catering meals for firefighters in the December 1997 bushfires in Australia.

 

Socially responsible business practices: Adapting and conducting business practices that protect the environment and human and animal rights. Ex - McDonalds requirement that suppliers increase the amount of living space for laying hens on factory.

Question 23
Match the following.List I(a) Cause Marketing(b) Corporate Social Marketing(c) Corporate Philanthropy(d) Corporate Community involvementList II(i) ITC Group e-Choupalprogram aims to connect rural farmers through the internet for procuring agriculture products.(ii)Computers@Classroomsinitiative of Infosys donated 2,567 computers to various schools and colleges in India.(iii) Ford plans to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions using their EcoBoost engine to increase fuel efficiency.(iv) The Tata Group provides scholarships and endowments for numerous institutions.Codes
  • A.a-(iv) b-(iii) c-(ii) d-(i)
  • B.a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)
  • C.a-(i) b-(ii) c-(iii) d-(iv)
  • D.a-(iii) b-(iv) c-(ii) d-(i)
Correct Answer: a-(iii) b-(i) c-(ii) d-(iv)

Types of Corporate Social Initiatives:

Corporate social marketing: Supporting behavior change campaigns. Ex: McDonald's promotion of a state-wide childhood immunization campaign in Oklahoma

 

Cause marketing: Promoting social issues through efforts such as sponsorships, licensing agreements, and advertising. Ex - McDonalds sponsorship of Forest (a gorilla) at Sydney’s Zoo—a 10-year sponsorship commitment, aimed at preserving this endangered species.

 

Cause-related marketing: Donating a percentage of revenues to a specific cause based on the revenue occurring during the announced period of support. Ex - McDonalds earmarking of $1 for Ronald McDonald Children’s Charities from the sale of every Big Mac and pizza sold on McHappy Day.

 

Corporate philanthropy: Making gifts of money, goods, or time to help non-profit organizations, groups, or individuals. Ex - McDonalds contributions to Ronald McDonald House Charities.

 

 

Corporate community involvement: Providing in-kind or volunteer services in the community. Ex - McDonalds catering meals for firefighters in the December 1997 bushfires in Australia.

 

Socially responsible business practices: Adapting and conducting business practices that protect the environment and human and animal rights. Ex - McDonalds requirement that suppliers increase the amount of living space for laying hens on factory.

Quiz Attempt #119624

Total Questions: 4
Question 1
Which of the following is NOT true about rural markets? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2022)
  • A.Growth opportunities in rural markets are driving companies to them.
  • B.Information and communication technology are the drivers of change in rural markets.
  • C.Socio-economic changes are yet to happen to rural markets.
  • D.Rural consumers shop for grocery, apparels, consumer durables ofagri-inputs in nearby urban shops.
Correct Answer: Socio-economic changes are yet to happen to rural markets.

The statement that is NOT true about rural markets in the given options is (C) Socio-economic changes are yet to happen to rural markets.

 

This statement is not accurate. Rural markets have been undergoing significant socio-economic changes over the years. Various factors, including improved infrastructure, better access to education, increased income levels, and government initiatives, have contributed to the transformation of rural areas. As a result, rural consumers' preferences, buying patterns, and lifestyles have been evolving. Companies recognize these changes and are actively targeting rural markets to tap into their growth potential. So, statement (C) is not true because socio-economic changes have indeed been happening in rural markets.

Question 2
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)Statement I:Only low-priced products will sell in rural India.Statement II:Rural consumers are a homogenous lot.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below.
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.
  • C.Statement I is correct but Statement II is incorrect.
  • D.Statement I is incorrect but Statement II is correct.
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.

The correct answer is (B) Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect.

 

Statement I is incorrect because it is not true that only low-priced products will sell in rural India. The purchasing power and preferences of rural consumers vary, and they are willing to buy products that offer value and meet their needs, not just low-priced products.

 

Statement II is incorrect because rural consumers in India are not a homogenous lot. They have diverse preferences, needs, and income levels, and their preferences can vary significantly from one region to another. It would be a mistake to assume that all rural consumers in India are the same.

Question 3
Which of the following is NOT true about rural markets? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Print media is not necessarily impactful in rural markets
  • B.Rural customer is price sensitive
  • C.No significant change may be required in the advertising copy
  • D.Products should be simpler, easy to use, service and maintain
Correct Answer: Print media is not necessarily impactful in rural markets

The statement that is NOT true about rural markets is (A) Print media is not necessarily impactful in rural markets.

 

Print media can be impactful in rural markets, especially considering that newspapers, magazines, and pamphlets are often used to reach rural consumers with product information and advertisements. Therefore, this statement is not accurate.

Question 4
Which one of the following is a myth about rural markets? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2022)
  • A.All villages are not equally populated.
  • B.Rural buyers me a heterogenous lot.
  • C.Rural buyers are able to discriminate between products and brands.
  • D.Only low-priced products sell in rural markets.
Correct Answer: Only low-priced products sell in rural markets.

The myth about rural markets among the given options is (D) Only low priced products sell in rural markets.

 

This statement is a common misconception. While rural markets may have price-sensitive consumers, it's not accurate to say that only low-priced products sell in these markets. Rural consumers, like their urban counterparts, have diverse preferences, and they may be willing to pay for products that offer quality, value, and benefits that meet their needs. Many brands and products across various price ranges can find success in rural markets.

Quiz Attempt #119625

Total Questions: 10
Question 1
﻿For customers, which are the areas of ethical and social responsibility concerns?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)a) Product safetyb) Fair Pricec) Fair Wagesd) TQMe) Proper disclosures and informationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.c and d only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.a and e only
  • D.a, b and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

The correct answer is option D – a, b and e only.

 

The areas of ethical and social responsibility concerns for customers are:

a) Product safety

b) Fair Price

e) Proper disclosures and information

 

These areas highlight the responsibility of businesses to ensure the safety and quality of their products and to provide accurate and transparent information and price to customers.

Question 2
_______ are the moral principal and values that guide behaviour within the field of marketing and cover issues such as product safety, truthfulness in marketing, communication, honesty in relationship with customers distribution, pricing issue and the impact pf marketing decision on the environment and society.(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Sustainable practices
  • B.Marketing ethics
  • C.Positioning principles
  • D.Corporate social responsibility
Correct Answer: Marketing ethics

Marketing ethics refers to the moral principles and values that guide behavior within the field of marketing. It encompasses various issues such as product safety, truthfulness in marketing communication, honesty in relationships with customers, fair distribution practices, pricing integrity, and the impact of marketing decisions on the environment and society as a whole. Adhering to marketing ethics ensures that businesses operate in a manner that is transparent, honest, and socially responsible, thereby building trust and credibility with consumers and stakeholders.

Question 3
Some bottles of soft drink were supplied by X to Y. Y got injured due tobustingof one of the bottles. Y claimed(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2023)
  • A.Condition as to fitness as quality
  • B.Condition as to wholesomeness
  • C.Condition as to merchantability
  • D.Condition in a sale by description
Correct Answer: Condition as to merchantability

When Y got injured due to the bursting of one of the bottles of soft drink, it implies a breach of the condition as to wholesomeness. This condition is related to the safety and fitness for consumption of the product. If a product, such as a soft drink, is not fit for consumption and causes harm to the consumer due to defects, it violates the condition as to wholesomeness. Therefore, Y can claim damages based on this condition.

Question 4
False and misleading claims and vulgarity in advertisements do not match with:(UGC NET Commerce Dec 2012)
  • A.Aggressive advertising.
  • B.Ethics in advertising.
  • C.Mass level of advertising.
  • D.Sales promotion.
Correct Answer: Ethics in advertising.

False and misleading claims and vulgarity in advertisements do not match with "Ethics in advertising" (Option B).

 

Ethics in advertising refers to the moral principles and guidelines that should govern advertising practices. It involves ensuring that advertisements are honest, truthful, and do not deceive or mislead consumers. It also encompasses considerations of taste, decency, and avoiding offensive content. False and misleading claims as well as vulgarity in advertisements are violations of ethical standards in advertising, as they undermine trust and integrity in marketing communications.

Question 5
Which of the following is not one of principles of Enlightened Marketing?
  • A.consumer-oriented marketing
  • B.innovative marketing
  • C.product marketing
  • D.sense-of-mission marketing
Correct Answer: product marketing

The principle of Enlightened Marketing encompasses a set of guidelines that advocate for a holistic and ethical approach to marketing. It aims to support the long-term well-being of the marketing system and emphasizes the importance of considering consumers' interests, societal impact, and the greater mission of a company.

 

These are the key principles of Enlightened Marketing:

 

Consumer-Oriented Marketing: This principle highlights the importance of organizing marketing activities from the consumer's perspective. It emphasizes the need to understand, serve, and satisfy the specific needs of a defined group of customers. In essence, it's about putting the customer at the center of marketing efforts.

 

Innovative Marketing: Innovative marketing encourages companies to continuously seek improvements in their products and marketing strategies. It stresses the importance of staying open to new and better ways of doing things to remain competitive and meet evolving customer demands.

 

Value Marketing: Value marketing advises companies to invest most of their resources in activities that enhance the overall value provided to customers. This means focusing on real product and marketing improvements that benefit customers in the long run, rather than short-term tactics that offer minimal value.

 

Sense-of-Mission Marketing: This principle suggests that companies should define their mission in broader social terms rather than limiting it to narrow product-centric objectives. By adopting a mission that aligns with societal values, employees gain a stronger sense of purpose, and the company contributes positively to society.

 

Societal Marketing: Societal marketing underscores the importance of making marketing decisions that consider not only consumers' immediate wants but also their long-term interests. Companies following this principle also consider their own requirements and the broader societal interests. Neglecting long-term interests is seen as a disservice to both consumers and society.

Question 6
A form of cheating or undersupply relative to an implicit or explicit contract is known as
  • A.Fraudulism
  • B.Opportunism
  • C.Malpractices
  • D.None of the Above
Correct Answer: Opportunism

The correct answer is (B) Opportunism.

 

Opportunism refers to a form of unethical behavior or cheating in a business relationship, particularly in the context of contracts or agreements. It involves taking advantage of the situation to benefit oneself or gain an unfair advantage, often at the expense of the other party. In this case, it refers to undersupplying or not fulfilling the terms of an implicit or explicit contract, going against the agreed-upon terms or expectations. It's a breach of trust and fairness in business interactions.

Question 7
Identify correct statement.Statement I:Consumerism is an organized movement of citizens and government agencies to improve the rights and power of buyers in relation to sellers.Statement II:Environmentalism is an organized movement of concerned citizens and government agencies to protect and improve people's current and future living environment.
  • A.Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct
  • B.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is incorrect
  • C.Statement I is correct and Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I is incorrect and Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Statement I is correct and Statement II is correct

Because some people view business as the cause of many economic and social ills, grass roots movements have arisen from time to time to keep business in line. 2 major movements have emerged: Consumerism and Environmentalism.

 

Consumerism is an organized movement of citizens and government agencies to improve the rights and power of buyers in relation to sellers. Traditional seller’s rights include:

(i) Right to introduce any product in any size and style, provided it is not hazardous to personal health or safety;

(ii) Right to charge any price for the product, provided no discrimination exists among similar kinds of buyers.

(iii) Right to spend any amount to promote the product, provided it is not defined as unfair competition.

(iv) Right to use any product message, provided it is not misleading or dishonest in content or execution.

(v) Right to use buying incentive schemes, provided they are not unfair or misleading.

 

On the other hand, traditional buyer’s rights include:

(i) Right to not to buy a product that is offered for sale.

(ii) Right to expect the product to be safe.

(iii) Right to expect the product to perform as claimed.

 

Also, consumer advocates call for the following additional consumer rights:

(i) Right to be well-informed about important aspects of the product.

(ii) Right to be protected against questionable products and marketing practices.

(iii) Right to influence products and marketing practices in ways that will improve the quality of life.

 

Environmentalists are concerned with marketing effects on the environment and with the costs of serving consumer needs and wants. Environmentalism is an organized movement of concerned citizens and government agencies to protect and improve people's current and future living environment. Environmentalists are not against marketing and consumption. They simply want people and organizations to operate with more care for the environment. The marketing systems goal should be to maximize life quality. Life Quality means not only the quantity and quality of consumer goods and services but also the quality of the environment, now and for future generation.

Companies are adopting environmental sustainability developing strategies that both sustain the environment and produce profits for the company. Marketers must check into the ecological properties of their products and packaging.

 

Marketers must:

(i) Practice pollution prevention.

(ii) Practice product stewardship.

(iii) Adopt design for the environment (DFE) practices.

(iv) Plan for new environmental technologies.

(v) Have a sustainability vision.

Question 8
Which one of the following marketing practices is outside the purview of the Competition Commission of India? (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Exclusive dealing
  • B.Misleading advertising
  • C.Predatory pricing
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Misleading advertising

The correct answer is (B) Misleading advertising.

 

The Competition Commission of India (CCI) is primarily responsible to eliminate practices having adverse effect on competition, promote and sustain competition, protect the interests of consumers and ensure freedom of trade in the markets of India.

 

(i) Exclusive dealing: This refers to an arrangement where a seller requires a buyer to purchase its products exclusively or a buyer agrees to purchase from a particular seller exclusively. Exclusive dealing can potentially restrict competition by limiting the buyer's choices. Therefore, it falls within the purview of the Competition Commission's jurisdiction.

 

(ii) Predatory pricing: Predatory pricing is a strategy where a company intentionally lowers its prices to unsustainable levels to drive competitors out of the market and establish a monopoly or dominant position. This practice is considered anti-competitive and falls within the purview of the Competition Commission.

 

Misleading advertising: Misleading advertising involves providing false or deceptive information to consumers through advertisements. This practice can mislead consumers, create an unfair advantage for certain businesses, and harm consumer welfare. The Competition Commission is not responsible for Misleading Advertisement. This is under the purview of the Consumer Forums.

Question 9
Match the items of List – I with the items of List – II and select the correct code. (UGC NET Management JUL 2016)List – I(a) Coupons(b) Tie-in Promotions(c) Cross Promotions(d) Price PacksList – II(i) Using one brand to advertise another non-competing brand.(ii) Offers to consumers of savings off the regular price of a product.(iii) Certificates entitling the bearer to a stated saving on the purchase of a specific product.(iv) Two or more brands or companies team up on coupons, refunds, and contests to increase pulling power.Codes:
  • A.a-iii, b-iv, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

The correct answer is (C) (iii) (iv) (i) (ii).

 

(i) Using one brand to advertise another non-competing brand. (Cross Promotions)

Cross Promotions involve collaborating between two distinct brands to jointly promote each other's products or services. This strategy leverages the audiences and customer bases of both brands to generate increased exposure and sales. For example, a partnership between a fashion brand and a beverage company might result in a marketing campaign where customers who purchase the fashion brand's products receive special offers on the beverage brand's products.

 

(ii) Offers to consumers of savings off the regular price of a product. (Price Packs)

Price Packs involve providing consumers with cost savings through various packaging or pricing options. This could include bundling multiple products together at a reduced overall price compared to purchasing each item individually. "Buy one, get one free" offers are also common examples of price packs, enticing customers with value-based discounts.

 

(iii) Certificates entitling the bearer to a stated saving on the purchase of a specific product. (Coupons)

Coupons are promotional tools that offer consumers specific discounts or savings on particular products. These coupons can be distributed through different channels such as newspapers, online platforms, or direct mail. Customers can redeem coupons for a reduced price when purchasing the associated product.

 

(iv) Two or more brands or companies team up on coupons, refunds, and contests to increase pulling power. (Tie-in Promotions)

Tie-in Promotions involve collaboration between two or more brands to create mutually beneficial marketing campaigns. This can include combined efforts such as joint coupon campaigns, contests, or promotional events. By uniting their resources, brands aim to enhance their marketing impact and attract a broader audience.

Question 10
In India, which pricing practice is not permissible?(UGC NET Commerce Jun 2013)
  • A.Penetrating pricing
  • B.Skimming pricing
  • C.Predatory pricing
  • D.None of the above.
Correct Answer: Predatory pricing

In India, the pricing practice that is not permissible is "Predatory pricing" (Option C).

 

Predatory pricing refers to the practice of deliberately setting very low prices for a product or service with the intention of driving competitors out of the market or deterring new competitors from entering. It is generally considered anti-competitive and is not allowed under Indian competition law, specifically under the Competition Act, 2002. Predatory pricing can harm competition and consumer choice, which is why it is not permissible.
